												I'll start by saying I loved the original State of Decay and the two DLC's, I loved them to death so much I bought them twice.  Once for the Xbox 360 and once for the PC.  Now I can say I purchased them a third time, because this one is esstentially the same as the original and the DLC.When I started to hear news of a newer updated version of the game my heart skipped a beat.  Maybe we'd finally get a version of the game that wasn't handicapped by the outdated consoles they were created for.   Did I get that.. well the answer is a yes, and a no.  While the game looks far better than the previous version, it just isn't worth recommending for a full price purchase if you already own the original game.If you don't own the original already, this is a good deal, you get the base game and all the DLC and the patches and bug fixes which were never brought to the original game.  Excuses are just that excuses, saying the patches and bugs weren't possible to fix because the game was restricted by the console release... WHY?  This isn't a console, it's the PC.  Those excuses don't work on this format..Bottom line remains, if you own State of Decay.. save your money, if you don't own the game, the YOSE is the way to go.  Great value for your money, but this HD upgrade was totally  unnecessary and the bugs/glitches should have been fixed in the previous version.

A Screenshot of State of Decay: Year-One
By: Kenuty




 Video Review 


YouTube™ Video: State of Decay Year one Survival Edition PC REVIEW

			My thoughts on State of Decay Year One survival Edition? No. My steam review is listed on the bottom, the top is actual gameplay from the game The remaster was not at all impressive to me and hence...		

Pros + Looks better than the original, supporting 1080p, Lighting and texture looks better, and it runs better at 60 fps.+ New animations and rework, but you wouldn't notice them much+ New missions added in order to entice you to play again+ All dlcs in one pack read to go!+ The game itself has fantastic game play, mechanics, etc. we know this because we've played it. We know this game is great, a year ago or so. Cons - Doesn't feel like a remaster as they claim, a remaster is a perfection of their game and does more than just blow the game 1080p and adding some side missions, bells and whistles here and there.- My titan X is sitting here cold at 1080p because it doesn't support 4k? WTF! The textures are also horrible!.- Some of the bugs in the original carried over insanely laughable, I caught them while starting the game and added it to my video. Zombie glitching around is some examples.- Remastering applies to certain things such as music, some voices, etc.- No multiplayer can ever be implemented in this game (Saw that video)- Charging players for this Update of the game and cutting away the original support ( The main game is gone from the store you can only get the dlcs for the original, but it will be no longer supported in any way or form you have to upgrade to this version for that) You can, however, purchase the original from HUMBLE BUNDLE and add key to steam.- Promises that was told and unkept. They never came to be.- Calling it and emphasizing remaster to insult those that own and know what remasters are in their collections. (Homeworld, Tombraider anniversary collections, etc.)- Veteran players who own the game, do the math on how much you are paying for this game along with having the original+dlc already (This was posted on the forums, 50+$)Game is targeted for new audience.That's all I'll have to say. At least unlike the other reviewers with thumbs up and positive.  I am honest because I have cash to waste on being honest about the game than sucking one for a review copy or  just defending my purchase like a fanboy and sheeps who have absolutely almost no class in what pc gaming quality is about.I am sincerely disappointed and I rarely am since I love video games, and I truly love playing games to review them for fun, however, I do have morals and ethics. I do have hours and hours in the original (Xbox Version), and I love the game but sorry I will not be supporting these types of re-release as legitimate remasters as I have many that do so in the category.By all means if you are a huge fan, love the game or never played it, then enjoy the product and do what you have to do and go ahead and play the game. Don't let my review stop you from what you are doing because it is my opinion, which is more important to me as yours is to you.I'll 100% support you guys again on your next game if you bring us a quality game, especially for the pc versions. Sorry dev do not take this personally, but I will be skipping on this art piece.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
30+ hours inInitially, I liked Year One, but I cannot recommend it now that I've seen the bugs and how little content there was.tl;dr - almost every old bug still exists in the game. I paid good money to improve the game experience and all I got was this reskin (and some NEW bugs!).The base gameI enjoyed the base game with the upgraded visuals. There were also some mechanical tweaks (mainly the vehicles now handle according to Earth gravity) and lovely additions to the soundtrack; it wasn't a new experience, but an improved one. The Freaks got balanced, you didn't get as overwhelmed with tasks, the CLEO drops and reskins brought a little spice into things - it was quite nice revisiting the game I love, warts and all.The new content ran out a bit too quickly, however, and the endgame was boring with the last stretch of missions and looting a little flat as usual, but I felt it was okay value for 24 hours of gameplay. After all, I was getting 2 refreshed DLCs too, right?Dealbreaker DLCBut then there's Lifeline. My first three playthroughs had major game-breaking bugs, and the whole 'refreshed' DLC is riddled with old bugs that have been reported to UD Labs time and again. NOTHING has been fixed, and there is very little additional content for Lifeline - the reskins are lame and there are no new weapons (the CLEO ones suck compared to army stuff).I felt utterly cheated, still do after 8+ hours of gameplay.When Fighting 7/Bladed 7 Kung-Fu Vince falls through a bridge after exiting your vehicle and gets killed by a solo Feral under said bridge, you know your game is ♥♥♥♥ed. Never mind the CLEO missions that don't spawn, zombies that spawn inside the ground, disappearing items, worthless AI, Journal glitching out, wrong voice clips playing for your player character etc.This really put the base game into perspective for me, too. In the end, the improvements were marginal at best and left a lot to be desired.The bottom lineThis remake is way overpriced for what it is - reskins and some extra tunes. The mechanical tuning should have been done for the original, it was borderline bugfixing! I paid good money thinking I would get actual content and bugfixes/polish too, but NOPE. I still love the base game for what it is (it's complicated with Lifeline...), but if you're an old player, don't buy this for the full price, about 70% off would be fair.If you still want to play the same old game and can stand the bugs, that is.New players? Buyer beware. The base game is still one of the better zombie survival games and has unique mechanics that are quite enjoyable, but the devs don't seem to be interested in fixing and expanding the game - and that is a bad, bad sign.

number of helpful: 270 of 288 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7
												I have extremely mixed feelings about this game. I put a good amount of time in the "original" version and then went on to get this one while I had major discounts on YOSE. Yeah, you read that right - major discounts. Here is why I'm conflicted, but ended up not recommending it.The original state of decay (no longer being sold as of YOSE release) was a game that was quite unique. A third person survival game with base defence, the need to gather resources which are actively used each "day", perma-death, social problems (such as people becoming suicidal or overly problematic anger problems), cars, and rpg elements such as the ability to specialize in certain weapons such as: blunt, edged, pistols, shotguns, etc. I honestly cannot find another game like it, though I wish I could. (This is NOT like Dead State). All in all, quite the good game!However, with all good things there are bad. In this case, it's the company itself. When they released YOSE, I supported them due to their explainations. They (undead labs) partnered up with Microsoft and, instead of releasing patches to fix and add things, they decided to re-release the game which was a year old. People who owned the original had to purchase the new version. This sparked a lot of controversy, but I was willing to overlook the issues and even defended them on massive thread wars. But, the more I played it, the more I realized what was wrong.They claimed to have fixed the bugs. They claimed that they would support this version. They claimed a lot, but delivered very, very little. The only difference between YOSE and the original is a combat knife (if you are unarmed) which is useless, a few new weapons, all the car models do not look the same and that's.... pretty much it. Those bugs they squished? Nope. Still there - pretty much all of them. This includes such wonderful bugs as: getting stuck on curbs, having cars randomly twist spin into the air and land on their roofs causing them to explode, fps spike jitters (fps drops down really, really low), characters not responding to commands and continuing to do their last command such as run forward instead of turning around (not fun when you threw an explosive and your character auto runs into it while you're holding the back button), and more. They. Were. Not. Fixed. They even said that they fixed the keyboard and mouse controls - my friend got motion sick from the speed differences as it moves choppy one second and smooth the next. Speaking of keyboard controls, if you use a mouse and keyboard one of the "specializations" is completely, utterly and totally useless!!!!!!! If you put points into Rifles (as in hunting rifles) and you use a mouse and keyboard, you have wasted your specialization and you cannot unspec. What the specialization does is that it increases the "snap headshot" area and range. It has no effect on damage, recoil, range or anything else. It doesn't tell you what the "snap" is, so I looked it up and found out that it literally only works if you use a controller. The reason for this is because it is literally aim assist that auto-snaps to zeds heads. It does not work with M&K, nor are there any other perks for using it.To make matters worse, this version was hardly supported as well. Instead, they decided to work on their next money maker - State of Decay 2, which I will most likely only purchase on an extreme sale, if at all. Even their leadboards, which sparked controversy as well in a different way, were (I don't actually know if they are still) messed up. Example: My score got reset 3 times when I was going to get into first place. I was on level 13 breakdown (the endless mode, before it was "updated") and it claimed I had killed literally 0 zombies. Zero's acrossed the board, while on the lifeline dlc "Undead Chris" had saved over 10,000 civilians with the next person down (in 2nd place) being approximately 30.To close this somewhat confusing review, I guess I would summerize it as this. Is it a fun game? Yeah, I'm still putting time into it on and off as I already own it. Would I say that it was well made? The concept of the game and even it's playability (if you ignore the bugs) is quite good and enjoyable for someone like me. However, would I recommend the game to people? No, not unless it's on a mega-sale such as the Christmas or Summer sales. Do NOT purchase this game at full price if you intend to get it, and keep in mind that it will not get any more support.Oh, that leaderboard controversy I mentioned? The store page for State of Decay (the original version) stated something along the lines of "Play with your friends!" so people purchased the game thinking there was co-op. There is not, there never was intention and it was mistaken. This was before you could apply for refunds on steam, and people didn't want it if there was no co-op as it stated there was. Turns out, according to one of their people, that it meant with the LEADERBOARDS, NOT other players. So you could play AGAINST THEIR SCORE, but NOT with them. That was the controversy.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
 Make a note First of all, if you already own the original game and every available DLC then don't bother buying this unless you are looking for slightly better graphics, a few new weapons and vehicle skins and bug fixes (and new bugs). The game is still pretty much the same experience. And here we go If you are  new  to this game and interested, then I'd most likely recommend buying it. Don't mind the negative reviews on this edition of the game. Instead read the ones on the original one (which is no longer available for purchase at the moment) since they tell more about the experience than these on YOSE. Why? Because most of these tell about how this edition was released only to make money out of small updates and about the bugs that make the game worse. The worst thing is that the original game is not receiving any of the new content and updates that are included in this edition. I can understand the pain and I agree that it's a horrible move, but I'd like to direct this short review specifically towards everyone who has no experience with the original game.I'll let you know about the game's basics and the good and the bad in short. State of Decay  The base game Survival in zombie apocalypse3rd person viewMelee weapons and gunsCarsCollecting loot (from food and medicine to weapons and building materials)Base managementExpanding your communityHelping your neighbors with problemsDoing missions that eventually lead to the end of the game YOSE Day One Edition 2x DLCs: Breakdown and Lifeline Improved graphicsAn exclusive characterTwo new gunsA new car and already existing vehicles with custom skinsNew missions (looting supply crates) The Good and The Bad  Pros +Looting and managing inventory is easy+Combat is alright+Base management is simple and clear+Vehicles are easy to control (most of the time)+Moving alone can actually be really dangerous (it's good to have someone with you)+Graphics are nice... Cons -...but they can get a bit ugly (for ex. in the woods)-Fighting with melee weapons gets repetitive-Missions also get repetitive-Simplicity is a minor impact-Voice acting is propably the most repetitive thing in the game and needs a bigger variety  (same sentences are repeated alot)-Vehicles feel a bit too fragile sometimes-The game is still screaming for co-op-Minor bugs that are close to breaking missions-Performance needs tweaking (fps drops) Nutshell Gameplay: 7.5/10Graphics: 8/10Sounds: 7.5/10 (Including voice acting)Performance: 7/10Story: 6/10 Conclusion Yes, State of Decay: YOSE Day One Edition was propably made only with money in mind and so it should propably be avoided by veterans unless you need this new content and bug fixes + the upcoming fixes for the new and old bugs. In the other hand, this is something that fans of survival games should look into. You can spend alot of time while playing this game. Even I spent over 12 hours on the base game and tried out one of the DLCs (Lifeline) that I have not played before (I did play the original game and the Breakdown DLC back in the day). The other DLC (Breakdown) will leave you with even more hours on your counter. All in all I had alot of fun playing this game. There were quite a few intense moments that are something I've never encountered in other survival games. I played this with a controller and I recommend you doing the same if you happen to have one.Newcomers 8/10 Veterans 5-6/10  "The polished yet dirty version/edition of a fun game" Please let me know if I missed anything. You are also free to give me your own opinions! :) Thank you

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												As a returning player who loved the original State of Decay, let me be honest here, this is a completely unnecessary, controversial re-release that brings nothing of real value that would be so significant compared to the original that it would deserve its own release and the price, even with 33% discount is still way TOO much in terms of value for returning players.YOSE keeps crashing to desktop and overall feels as a slower, less optimized and just more bugged version compared to the original. People who purchase this game as newcomers to SoD "franchise" as well as the returning players deserve smooth and flawless gameplay for the money these developers ask for this game, unfortunately if you think that you're getting flawless game for your hard earned money, I have to disappoint you by saying you better forget it.As for the "remaster" aspect of this re-release, promise of the high quality textures is one of the biggest lies and not only you can see it for yourself in the parts of the game where textures are just ugly and you can't quite recognize what are you even looking at, but also according to developers themselves, PC release is smaller than Xbox One release because in PC release they didn't need to upgrade as many textures to higher quality as they needed to upgrade for Xbox One. This is interesting. Now I don't really own Xbox One, but I wonder if the Xbox One players really have the same ugly textures that show here in my PC version and while the fact that they did not upgrade as many textures for PC as they upgraded for Xbox One should naturally mean significantly lower price on PC, the price is the same even though the value added compared to original is clearly not that significant at all.Smaller difference in the quality compared to original equals smaller reason for anyone on PC to upgrade to YOSE, but wait. Can you really stay away of this re-release and just enjoy the original? According to some players, the original game won't launch for them anymore and as a matter of fact, the original game and its dlcs are replaced with YOSE, so there is no way to purchase the original anymore and no way for original owners to get the support unless they purchase YOSE! So much for optional purchase for the original owners...Let us put that aside and let me say what most of us think anyway, but nobody had the guts to say it out loud:Real fans of SoD expected more from the SoD "franchise" than just a re-release of the same thing they already have and losing the support for the original is a legitimate reason for fans of the original SoD to be mad as they are basically forced to upgrade to YOSE and pay for the same thing again if they don't want to lose support.In other words, for original fans it feels like being stabbed in our backs and I'm pretty sure that we all will remember this and keep it in mind from now on every time these developers bring a new game of any name.EDIT:To be completely fair, I love the little things they added exclusively for original owners and those who pre-order this game (new character who is already one leveled-up badass with unique weapons for original owners and special prepper pack for those who pre-ordered the game) and I also love CLEO items, but it still isn't that significant change that would justify the re-release and especially the price and just like many already said, not only bugs aren't fixed at all, but they somehow managed to introduce new bugs and crashes to desktop that basically render this overpriced re-release unplayable, isn't a "definitive edition" supposed to be clean of all the bugs present in the standard one?Speaking of bugs, here is a little peek...


YouTube™ Video: State Of Decay YOSE - Watch out! Here comes... wtf ?!?! 

			Views: 94		

			State of Decay Year One Survival Edition, now with more bugs and the old bugs remastered to a new level! Watch out! Here comes trouble!		

As an owner of the original release, I would be willing to pay for all the new stuff in form of a regular DLC as an optional "update" even if the price was slightly higher than a regular DLC, but the current price is a ripoff even with 33% discount.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												While I support everyone's cause to end developers with the $$ in their eyes, this is clearly not the right title to be doing it on and the people doing so are misinformed. TL;DR - Developers (who made the game) have no control over the business practice as this still is a Microsoft-published/controlled title. It's a stretch that Microsoft even let this game go on Steam, so don't expect any official support beyond what was already offered. Undead Labs aren't accountable here. This is the remaster of a previously 2-gig sized game, and you are getting out of it what you are willing to pay for it.I'm sitting here reading these "most helpful" reviews from people with much, much less than even 5 hours in the game (a lot of them ironically saying they 'haven't seen anything different or new content-wise yet'), while reviews that are simply people saying they can't start the game (likely because their graphics setup doesn't support Dx11/isn't updated) somehow got upvoted to the most helpful page. Meanwhile, it doesn't take much to see the shameless squad of review-skewers operating out of the vow to upvote every single negative post no matter how meaningless it is and downvote the opposite, so right now it's pretty hard to view an actual, thought-out review of this game (Obviously, don't pretend I'm somehow 'unbiased' or 'more correct' in this situation). I'm going to predict that the amount of people who downvote this post within the next several hours will prove those previous statements (update - accumulation of 247/1053 as of Oct. 5th 2016). For further thought material: For a brisk while post-release, critic reviews on Metacritic for this game were definitely positive, and the problems those reviews mainly have with the game are more about a lack of polish and the fact that it wasn't a complete 'overhaul' like they hoped for, rather than it being a bad purchase or a bad game. Of course, by now, even some of those are under the impression that those "darn corrupt devs" made this to rob us thanks to the keyboard-activism.The issue with the talk of business practice is how obvious it is that nobody is actually looking into the validity of what they are saying - Undead Labs is not in control of the business practice. They are the dev team, it is their concept and ideas that built it, but ultimately, they signed it away to Microsoft for publishing with the XBLA system back in the 360's development stage. Before you assume that it's their fault anyways - remember that the XBLA program exists for small dev teams to have a place to release their game to the console market, and rules must be followed and UL would not have had any choice in the matter (being as small as they were with no resources at the time). Nobody knew the game was going to succeed how it did.What does this mean? Well, it certainly doesn't mean that Undead Labs even had the authority to "screw the customers" if they wanted to (which anyone with half a brain for PR can assume that they didn't). Rather that this is the PC port for the Xbox One version of the game, which sold for the simple reason that SOD otherwise did not exist on current (XB1) gen consoles at the time. Undead Labs has also stated that they cannot update the port without the go-ahead from Microsoft, which does not care about the PC port in terms of promoting their console-heavy exclusive title State of Decay.Now, if you actually care about what's in the game and how it compares to the last version, here is actually new content-wise in YOSE:-New knife-combat (which comes with a bunch of nice badass moves) (One of the bigger changes in the game)-New difficulty arch for Breakdown that extends far beyond the previous 12 levels.-30 minutes of new music-The amount of cars has more than doubled (although most of these come from new variants of already-existing vehicles. There is a classic 80's sedan, SUV, a non-customized version of the modern muscle car, some new tuners, a new classic muscle car and a bunch of new colors and variants for all of them.)-Some balance and physics tweaks-Fleshed out car repair features-New facility options (you can now do stuff like make coffee and convert ammo and stuff like that)-A bunch of new guns-A new type of mission (which is acts as a really nice reward occasionally in breakdown)-New Breakdown Heroes/survivors (including a returning-player bonus)(Milo Eldrige is an example of a new generic survivor for those misinformed souls that think Gurubani is the only change).-Slightly sharper graphics and frame rate (Not even close to a big change)-New visual ground effects, actual fog, etcKNOW WHAT YOU ARE BUYING. THIS IS PROBABLY NOT WORTH 30$ FOR PEOPLE WHO ALREADY HAVE THE GAME.ON THE CONTRARY, IF YOU DO NOT OWN THE ORIGINAL STATE OF DECAY, YOU AREN'T EVEN PART OF THE DEMOGRAPHIC THAT COULD CLAIM TO BE CHEATED. DON'T EXPECT THE REMASTER OF A 2GB GAME TO OPERATE LIKE A 30GB AAA GAME.If you are a new buyer to the series, then yah, buy this. State of Decay is a great game, and this is definitely the better version to get. There is more content, a bunch of smaller features the previous did not have, more community support for it.Despite the generic review claiming the game is 'broken' with 'broken features', the game is far from unplayable. The majority of bugs are physics flaws and bugs are definitely not something the game is bad with.Aside from that, if you are angry about the game not getting enough attention, you can blame MS for trying to make this a cash grab. The developers - who are very attentive to the community on the website - can't even do a DLC until the publishers ask for it. I'm not trying to baselessly shift blame, that is literally what one of the developers said when answering a community suggestion ( https://forums.undeadlabs.com/threads/the-guns.27815/page-281 ). Keep in mind that in that same thread the developer can be quoted as saying that something new might just be in the works as well for the game.

												WARNING TO OWNERS OF THE PREVIOUS VERSION!This "HD remastered" edition of State of Decay on PC does not include updated textures, contains the exact same bugs (except the one useful bug for getting your whole community on the RV in breakdown, that was fixed) and does not contain any noticeable animation improvements. As a game (if you are new) this is the best zombie survival game I've played ever. Or at least the original was. The game is unpolished, despite this being the "remastered version" it fails to fix any bugs, but hey you're new so forget about the old version. If you're okay with having bugs, choppy framerates and a horrible traitorous publisher, then this is for you, as it IS fun.I don't recommend this game despite that, however, as this is what is essentially a paid for patch that doesn't actually patch ANYTHING. Owners of the original are also screwed into buying this version if they want continued support, which would be less unacceptable if this version carried out half of what it promised.One finally note, the store page say "glorious 1080p at 30 fps" like its a good thing. number of helpful: 147 of 178 people (83%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												One of the saddest stories in video game development.TL;DR - While there is a great game buried under here, it's buried beneath an entirely unplayable mess. Don't buy this game until the devs make it very public that they've fixed it, should they ever actually do that. Until then, try and find a way to get the original.*I loved this game when it came out. I remember watching the trailers and having my hopes raised so high at the prospect of an open world zombie survival game of this calibre. And when it came out, it actually lived up to the hype. Somewhere in the outdated graphics, the lack of co-op, the awful sound design, and the disjointed voice acting, was a fantastic game with amazing mechanics. Hours were spent glued to my xbox fighting off waves of zombies, scrounging for supplies, searching every container looking for new weapons (and there must be hundreds of different weapons), building up bases, rescuing survivors and expanding my group.And then Breakdown came out, and I was ecstatic. It's like they realized their weaknesses and limitations, and decided to devote their attention to building their strengths. While the story of State of Decay was decent enough to push you around the map and through events in the game, they now gave us the world as our playground and challeneged us to survive for as long as possible in whatever way we chose. Once again, many hours were lost.And then came Lifeline, and in my opinion, the cracks started to show. It was still every bit as fun as the original, but what I'd hoped would be an entire urban centre to explore, turned out to be almost entirely inaccessible. The map consists of a large city area of which the entirety is inaccessible. The only areas you can explore are the suburban-esque areas of the outer limits of the city, which contain little more than the same houses and buildings you saw in the original. But despite all that, the fun was still there. The story was interesting enough, and being given a pile of new, military grade weapons to mow down zombies with was a blast. So even though the fun was shorter lived than the original, it still held up to its own.And then...this. This terrible, awful, wretched money grab they shamelessly put out. The base game is still there somewhere, but it has been completely buried in a buggy, laggy, entirely unplayable experience. They boast about being remastered in 1080p, as well as improved textures and animations, but the game looks almost no different than the original. The menus are a little sharper, the icons look a little crisper, but the player models, zombies, vehicles, the world itself is unnoticeably different. The only thing that's really changed is that the game can't keep up with itself anymore. Frame skips are constant, even in low texture density areas. Bugs are rampant, with your characters floating in the air or falling through the world, zombies pop in and out of existence all around you, the game crashes to desktop. And just to add insult to injury, the devs are charging more than the base game for this, and have made the original, playable version unpurchaseable. Coming up on a year after its release, the devs have seemingly made no moves to acknowlege that their product is broken, nevermind actually fix this game and make it playable again. One can only hope that day is coming.

number of helpful: 104 of 122 people (85%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												I do not recommend this game because it is so ridiculously glitchy.  Being new to the game, I read the reviews, and despite the negative recommendations because this edition should have been a patch instead of a remastered version, I got it anyways.  The indications of poor graphics performance and poor physics were fairly slight in the reviews, while predominant complaints were the former, so I thought, how bad could it be?  Let me tell you new comers, it's that bad.  Let  me break down the problems this game faces.-sluggish controls;  The action you try to perform may or may not be done on the first button press.  This leads to over zealous and useless button mashing.  -Zombies literally spawn right in front of you and are attacking you before they are visibly spawned in.  This is most notable when the game decides to mess you up, you'll see a few zombies, go whale on them, the music will kick into more serious tones, then you are swarmed with zombies that were nowhere around 2 seconds ago.  You'll start seeing them spawn in right behind a zombie you are executing.-team npcs are obviously programmed to be more of a nuciance than a help. They are notorious about standing in doorways, not attacking enemies until the last second.  They will NOT help you carry stuff, such as supplies you find, which really makes them pretty useless.  You cannot direct them to move, attack or anything otherwise useful.-The camera is not your friend.  Half the battle is keeping up with the camera.  Especially while driving.  Nothing says pain in the @$$ like driving with the WASD scheme and rotating the camera manually.  90% of all car accidents in this game is due to blind spots from the camera nemesis.  When fighting, sometimes all you can see is the back side of a zombie or your head.-Aiming can be a real pain in the nether region.  Scoped weapons aren't truely scoped, as you only zoom in ever so slightly, but the sight is still over the shoulder, and it leads to frustratingly difficult long shots.  Against all survival guide recommendations, spray and pray will end up being the order of the day when you inevitably get swarmed, hopefully you brought enough snacks, painkillers and a backup melee weapon because it's gonna turn into melee when you run out of ammo.-Vehicle physics seem to have been written by a toddler, because the physics are either as stiff as a board or as bouncy as a rubber ball.  Run over a zombie, you may dent your hood, or you may take your vehicle for a tour of the solar system, you're at the whim of random physics.  On that note, if walking everywhere wasn't a sure recipe for disaster because of materializing zombies, it would be easier to walk.-Walls and doors may or may not stop a zombie attack or the flames from a molotov.-Street curb can be an invisible barrier.  Make sure you take a running leap to get up on that sidewalk.-To search containers, you have to position yourself perfectly in front of it, you can't open that cooler lid standing beside it, because that's IMPOSSIBLE, the same goes for entering and exiting vehicles as well as putting items in the storage compartment.-Climbing down a ladder can be a perilous endeavor.  Sometimes you'll climb down normally, othertimes you'll swan dive off the platform.  Oh, did I mention how the useless NPCs like to stand in front of doors?  Yeah, they do that with ladders too.  Feel free to push them off, not that you'll teach them any kind of lesson but you'll feel better...-Last but not least;  the missions are so repetitive, and absolutely pointless...  "<insert name> is in a tough spot." blah blah blah...  The idle NPCs constantly go out, need help, and never bring anything back for the trouble, just a time sink.  You can ignore them, but you'll start having morale problems unless you bring back supplies constantly.  You also run the risk of losing members, especially before you have all your outposts.Oh, and, whoever decided how much items weigh really needs to spend some time figuring out how much stuff really weighs.  If a person struggles to carry an assault pack filled with a hatchet, 30 rounds of 5.56, a rifle, 3 bottles of asprin, 3 MRE, and 3 grenades, I don't think they would be much use in the military, let alone the apocolypse.  And military trained personel who takes 20-30 seconds' to change a magazine?  I'm looking at you Lifeline.  The game has promise, but I think between the dev's ADD and the DRM (i.e.  lack of any community fixes) it's going to be a broken promise.  Graphically and functionally this game is on par with Xbox1 and the PS2 era, though the concept is there for a great modern game.  Very sad, and I wanted to like this game so badly.  My recommendation, if you absolutely must get it, wait for a sale, but I bet you'll still be disappointed.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												I like this game very much and it is fun, don't get me wrong on this. There is afaik not one other game out there which combines Zombies, Basebulding, RPG-Mechanics, Open-World and 3rd-Person-Action in a way worth mentioning. Although the game doesn't play it's potential to the fullest and there was definitely room for improvement, but sadly that wasn't used for this "remastered" version. Honestly I almost see almost no difference graphic-wise, it certainly doesn't look that much better. But that wasn't something I had hoped for anyways. What I had hoped for was an improvement gameplay-wise, but alas they didn't deliver. The same long known bugs that plagued the old game, are also present in this version, the extra Mission type   is nothing to write home about, the Bonus Survivor is bugged, I couldn't even add him/her to my community, the Bonus Gear I can't even recall if it worked. Also they stated that they had reworked the UI, but I really can't tell, because it is still the same unresponsive, lackluster console conversion i had to put up with in the orginal game. It is definitely not tweaked for PC, at least not worth mentioning. Performance-wise I had no problems at all, I ran the game at "Ultra"(haha)-Specs and it ran fluid, almost all of the time (oc'ed nvidia gtx 760). Also many community suggested improvements were neglected, actually I can't tell if any was implemented at all. So the conclusion is that I cannot recommend this game? No. I do recommend it, at least to those who haven't played the original, although I am somewhat disappointed by the developers for releasing this cash-grab. If you never played this game and you like open-world zombie-action with some strategic value, pick it up. It can nerveracking at times, but all in all it is a good game and also worth 28€ imo, but stay away if you already own the orginal!

												Foreword: Genrally, for anyone who never played State of Decay or YOSE and is a huge Zombie Games Fan and needs a fix without touching any of the other "Zombie Survival" Games out there, like DayZ or H1Z1 (which basically are not Zombie Survival Games, but PvP with some...Things "derping" around to sometimes annoy you), then I can say:Try it. (and use Steam Refunds if you are disappointed!)Personally tho:I had a lot of fun with the original State of Decay (mostly with Mods installed!)It had its quirks, small minor bugs and performance issues on my PC, which is strange, since my Specs are good enough. (and this is not limited to my pc...)AMD A8-5600K Black Edition 3.6 GhzEVGA GeForce GTX 9708 GB MemoryWindows 8.1 Pro NState of Decay (not YOSE) ran acceptable with some stuttering and slowdowns here and there, especially while driving around.YOSE, on the other hand, has serious performance issues. Whenever I walk around, run around or drive around, the FPS dips down to 20 or less in a lot of areas. Micro-Stuttering is not even a word for that anymore.I posted about this on the official Forums from Undead Labs, twice.First time, the Community Manager and a Dev "wanted to take a look at it" but suddenly stopped responding or caring about it.Second time, only the Community Manager replied a couple times and then stopped responding.Not only is YOSE a slight cash-grab (you can get most of all the new YOSE features with SoD Mods), the Developers are not the most responsive and caring type...One way to ruin a franchise and scare off existing and potential new customers.I hope Undead Labs learns from their mistakes and their MMO Zombie Survival Game actually will work and run properly...

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
Update 1 on November 19, 2015:Almost 7 months after release, UL has finally released a big content patch. Out of curiosity, I will be reinstalling to see if it addresses some of the bugs I mentioned.Update 2 on November 27, 2015:Everything seems to work fine now. Only took them 7 months to actually patch the damn thing.I really want to recommend this game, but I can't in good conscience tell people to go out and get YOSE given the state it's in. On paper, it sounds great: HD re-release of 2013's State of Decay, all DLC included, bonus missions and new characters for the Breakdown DLC. I got the original State of Decay around the time it came out of Early Access back in late 2013 and it was plagued by bugs that eventually got patched out. So, imagine my surprise when playing the re-release only to discover they brought back the same bugs. To list a few:- Opening up the journal will running or driving will lock your character in that direction infinitely until you press the same direction key again.- Incorrect character voices. A female character will use her own voice to say one line, then switch to another female voice, and then cheer in a deep male voice.- Issues with map geometry, i.e. with a horde right on your butt, you'll sprint across the street only to hit what the game thinks is an invisible wall because the curb is like half a foot above the street.- Wonky car physics, meaning that driving over what you think is a small rock will rocket your vehicle into the stratosphere and kill your character.- Worst of all, the infinite loading screen glitch is back. Anyone who played the original SoD at launch will remember this, where if you switch between characters, the game will load in as the new character, but the loading screen will float in place forever. It's easily fixed by exiting to the menu and loading back in, but this shouldn't be an issue in the first place.It's almost been a month since launch with no patch (other than one to fix the import save function). Until YOSE gets fixed or falls to a price you think is reasonable, I say skip it. If you've not played the original, you can get that and all the DLC for less than $10 or $15 during a sale.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I really wish I could recommend this, because I really really loved the original one. I bought this game on a whim when I found out that I could import my save. To save time for others:TL;DR: Save your money if you already have the original game, because the new content does not validate the price. If however you havent got the game at all, it is worth paying for as the old one is no longer available on steam.Positive aspects:-returning players from SoD get access to an exclusive player with the Nimble trait (reflexes) -new type of car added that has an increased trunk space (6 spaces) with a bit less handling than a modern pickup, but more readily available and just as sturdy.-like original SoD has intergrated controller support available-returning players can import their save from SoD, breakdown and Lifeline-Actions like creating more snacks and coffee are now available at the kitchen-new mission type included in story type and breakdown, gives new lease of life to objects such as timers and talking dolls-new map icons make it easier to see at a glance what kind of missions are available to youNegative aspects:-The game is really badly optimized. This particular game lags even on minimum specs-Some zombies are not rendered correctly, and sometimes the buildings have the same problem. For machines (like mine) that ran original SoD perfectly fine, it seems like this is an issue that shouldn't have been one.-the map looks less smooth and more boxy and cartoonish-for the content that has been added ontop of the old version, it really is not worth the money even with the discount. The added features included in this pack, i would only realistcally pay around £8 at most.-No new voice actors have been commissioned. For when playing breakdown and the like, it can get tiresome to hear the same 6 voice actors over and over in different pitches.-at times, attacks do not connect to the zombies, leading you to waste your stamina swinging wildly while they still come and wreck you.-it is commonplace for your character to glitch into the foundations of the building. Whereas in the original SoD this glitch was only really common for zombies, the glitch has now expanded to affecting player characters-the graphics as a whole just look sharp and horrible as if no edge smoothing has been used at all. in all honesty, I prefer the graphics of the old game.Conclusion:I will probably continue to play this game as i have already spent money on it, but looking back I wish I saw a review like this instead of the generic "This is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cash grab" so i could have just happily stayed with the original. However, if you've never played State of Decay at all, it is a brilliant game, and will recommend you buy this copy as the old one is now not available.

												Decided to make this more coherent aswell as more thorough.Pros:-Same good gameplay from the previous, aborted child, with solid combat.-Good, though run of the mill 'special zombies' (Freaks), the Screamer (Killing Floor Siren though this one disables character while screaming), the Bloater (basically a Left 4 Dead Smoker/Killing Floor Bloatbile hybrid since it doesn't tongue but it doesn't vomit), the Feral (Left 4 Dead Hunter) and the Juggernaut (Killing Floor Fleshpound)Cons:-The tiny inventory started to get on my nerves though I suppose its more realistic, can't expect everyone to take 999 bullets with them every time.-Being bombarded by silly requests when you're trying to do something gets REALLY frustrating.-Only minor but unskippable intros (Microsoft Studios and Undead Labs thingies) are 800x600 regardless of resolution settings-More minor stuff, when coming out of a menu if you try to move characters too fast they will only walk in a straight line regardless of other directional buttons pressed, and the fact changing character even if they are right next to you needs a loading screen, I can understand characters that are outside of base though.-Drops in frame rates, specially while driving and getting to full speed even with graphical settings at minimum, I have 2xR9 270X, since its a mid ranged AMD product I'm not expecting it to rain gold and diamonds but jebus, the bloody framerate drops!!!-No mouse support in menus, I hate these friggin ports that ignore the existance of this excellent creation which would make inventory management so much easier, BUT NO you MAY NOT make our job easier we NEED to make menus confusing.The added content, I've noticed some of it like pallet swap cars, but to me it just seems like a "Turtle Rock did it with Left 4 Dead!!" cash grab though I may be mistaken the further I get in. The game itself looks to me like a lot was put into it like the devs themselves cared for it so I don't really regret buying it, I just hate bad ports which is the problem when they take the easy road of console games, I do appretiate that they spent the time to giving us PC people the game though.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game


YouTube™ Video: State of Decay: YOSE Day One Edition (PC): Impressions (Graphics comparison, gameplay and review) 

			Views: 6,646		

			State of Decay: YOSE Day One Edition (PC): Impressions (Graphics comparison, gameplay and review) The original State of Decay was one of my favorite open world sandbox survival game out there, though...		

State of Decay was a fantastic open world zombie survival game when it was originally released on Xbox Live, but when it was ported to the PC it suffered from multiple problems. Bugs, and poor resolution were some of the most notable issues. Fortunately the core game was so good, many people including myself were willing to forgo any problems that it had, and enjoyed it any ways. What a great idea it is to "remaster" the original! The question though, is Year One remastered enough to justify a $30USD price tag?If you've already played or own the original game is it worth $30? Short answer: NO.Yes, the lighting have been improved significantly, and the texture quality is better, but other than that, there's not much new here. Sure, there are also some extra minor characters added, and now cars have decal (whoopie...), but every thing else about the game is exactly the same. The game advertises improved animations, and combat mechanics, yet I notice little changed about these 2 things. If there have been any changes, they're so tiny, it's barely noticeable. The two biggest improvements are the lighting and texture quality, both could of easily been added as a patch. There are no other notable additions, the model quality is exactly the same, there are no new modes to play, no new areas, no new quests, nothing for returning players. If this was advertised as the definitive State of Decay collection, I would be fine with it. Lots of games like Boarderlands repackage old games into compilations for the benefit for new players, but this was advertised as a remastering. Even the description of the game mislead old fans to believe that there are a ton of new stuff here, when there aren't. Worst off, the most noticeable improvements, lighting, texture quality, and true 1080p, are things that should of been in place when they launched their original port! But instead they decided to charge it to us, as a lazy excuse of a remaster. If you're a returning player to the game, Year One is nothing more than a glorified update patch.Luckily for us, the original is absolutely a stellar survival game, and since they changed nearly nothing about it, it remains a stellar survival game. If you are new to State of Decay, this might be a good time to get into the game, and perhaps Year One is suitable for the new comers. For old time fans who have already played, or own State of Decay, don't bother. It's not worth your money unless you have enough disposable income to justify it. But even then, the practice of selling what amounts to a patch for $30 and misleading old players to think that there are a ton of new stuff when there's not, is not a practice that I can condone.Pros:- Still the same, great State of Decay game- Suitable for any one NEW to the gameCons:- For returning players, there isn't much new- $30 for what amount to a patch is unconscionable- Neither combat or animation have been improved enough to justify it being in the description- The original was a lazy port, Year One is a lazy remastering

												Pros:A little better graphics (Almost no difference) & smoother frame rate.Cons:1. Aside from some graphic improvements & some pre-purchase bonuses, not much has changed in terms of gameplay & features. 2. Bugs are WORSE than the original version. Zombies pass through walls more frequently, cars flying, zombies flying, and still no one is manning the watch tower most of the time. I can overlook the bugs in the original game, but the larger number of bugs in YOSE edition is pathetic.I don't know if it's caused by bugs, or the way the zombie AI is programmed, but zombies seem to know where you are from as far as 3 blocks away. I keep having my survivors killed due to being horded by dozens of zombies who just always know where I am sneaking around. I destroyed a bunch of zombies, and the other groups keep endlessly coming, until my survivors ran out of stamina and get killed. This is truly frustrating. I am unable to search items in the house without being surrounded by zombies from across the road who somehow know I am inside the house. Even worse, the survivors who accompany me are dumb and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pathetic. They just stand there getting mauled by zombies without fighting back. Seriously, what the F**k did the developers do to the AI ???I have played the original SoD, and I will still go back to the original. The zombie AI is more balanced in the original game. The YOSE edition zombies somehow have human detector radar and you can never hide pass them. I keep losing my survivors and desperately look for new ones and train them, only to see them get killed as well. This totally ruins the gameplay. It's garbage.

If you get out of a car to look for something, they'll be there next to the vehicle.I'm all for killing the damn things, but it gets to be annoying after a while. It's still a good game, but it's still rough around the edges.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Okay so this is my first review on Steam. I loved SOD since I first heard the idea back in the day. I bought it on my Xbox (before I converted to the master race). It was innocent, a small company making the game everyone dreamed of. The concept was there, it made me feel for the characters when they were torn to shreds because I was too careless. It was an amazing game. The shoddy graphics and buggy gameplay were the only things hindering this beast of an idea. Everyday that I played this game I wanted to know what undead Labs was going to do to fix it. After a while I grew tired of waiting.3 days ago I logged onto Steam wondering if they had one of my favorite games. State of Decay. There it was $19.99 in all its glory just as I'd left it. Then I saw that Undead Labs HAD been working on it after all! So I bought the game a day before it released. I started the game and was immediately filled with disappointment. The didn't launch properly at first. Then the load times seemed to take forever and day. Finally I spawned in the Breakdown mode as Summer and BAM! Undead Labs told me ,"hey, we made the game better sorta."I play on a surface pro 2. This thing is a monster of a tablet. It can handle skyrim and GTA5 on almost full settings and is amazing. Sure it runs a little warm on those games but who's rig wouldn't?Anyway, there I was on Minimum resolution, minimum graphics and a Small as hell 4:3 display. Black borders all around. V sync on then off. IT ALL RAN THE SAME. Laggy, buggy and zombies jumping through walls. Forget driving. Hordes of zombies were complete chaos. My surface pro through all that was still running ice cold. Like I wasn't even playing a game. To summarize: If you bought the original with expansions don't waste more money on something that is subpar. It doesn't live up to my expectations and frankly I don't know if it ever will. Undead Labs needs to do something about these issues because they're destroying a dream game. All the while♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥a ton of people off. -The Gamer that waited

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												The  original State of Decay was a combination of everything i wanted from a zombie survival game. Building a community, scavenging resources and improving your living conditions during an apocalypse. It had it's own charm and all the annoying things about it (especially the bugs) were tolerable when you considered how small a developer Undead Labs was.Yet i can not recommend this version of the game to anyone, not even people who haven't played the "non-remastered" version.The original version got rid of a lot of bugs through patching but most of those are back in the YOSE edition with the addition of way more annoying new ones (car hit detection where you drive through a whole zombie horde without hurting a single one). A lot of obvious design flaws were not corrected (like adding a simple sorting function to your base inventory) and the visual improvements are nice in comparison but not that noticeable. And for a "polished" version, the framerate is horrendous, even on a decent system.I ended up reinstalling the original SoD, since it has fewer bugs and a lot of awesome mods available, that make the game more enjoyable (and from which the developers should have drawn inspiration on how to improve their game).If Undead Labs will patch it to a playable state and add a little mod support, i'll give it another whirl. Until then, this prime example of a money grab stays off my hard drive.#Update 31.10.2015Apart from a small hotfix right after release, the developer did not address any issues for a full six months.Thankfully modders have not been idle and there are some nice additions and fixes out there that makes it feel like i didn't totally waste my money on this purchase.Now only recommended if you don't own the original and don't mind searching for and installing mods and community made fixes by yourself.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												I have to recommend this game. I cannot in good conscience not do so. You see, I came late to the party, and so bypassed the controversy that followed the release of this 'Year One Edition', which includes the dlcs Breakdown and Lifeline.If you have not played State of Decay, then pay no attention to SOME of the reviews for this game, they are very much biased and tainted by that controversy that happened long ago which you can read more about in one of the other reviews I am sure.This game has a lot going for it. It is very close to the type of zombie-game I was looking for for many years. An actionpacked 3rd person game, much in the style of some earlier 'GTAs', with a focus on base- and resource management.Gather your group of survivors,  recruit new people, complete missions and interact with other survivor-groups. Scavenge for resources to use in upgrading and protecting your base and people; or move your entire base elsewhere on the map! All in a semi-open world yours to explore. Just be careful! Cars may break down, and if you get caught alone during the night by a horde be prepared to run!A word about the dlc Lifeline. To some extent, I found this campaign to almost more enjoyable than the base game. Maybe it was just the setting, which is more urban in Lifeline. The mechanics are the same, although you cannot move your base around in Lifeline. This doesnt matter, as the base you start with in this dlc has a lot of potential and is scene to some great defensive action. Call in snipers and air support as you try to defend your base of operations when the hordes get alerted to your presence, before gathering up your most experienced soldiers and go on a supply run, or try to rescue VIPs. Also. State of Decay has permadeath for your survivors, and actions may have consequences. I lost one of my earliest party members because I didn't get his medicine in time... I didn't know there was an actual time-limit. Be prepared to deal with it!I experienced no bugs, crashes or any other technical issues worth mentioning with the game as of early 2016. No worries.There arent many of these types of games in the 'zombie-genre', which I think is a shame. If you think the same, then I highly recommend Year One Edition to any newcomers.All the best.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												I played the first  State of Decay and the expansions for over 400 hours because I really liked the game. I admit that much can be improved and I was hoping YOSE would be a step in the right direction so I bought it even though they only gave a 33% reduction for a game that was only marginally improved.  However I can't play YOSE because the game crashes my pc.  I play for a random timespan then the screen goes black and poof the pc reboots.  I tweaked settings, updated the drivers and checked everything. No matter what: my pc crashes. My pc is 3 years old and made for rendering movies, which is a pretty intensive process but even when rendering, playing a game, running you tube and various programs at the same time my pc won't crash. I also played a wide range of games  such as Skyrim but only State of Decay causes my pc to crash. As this takes the fun out of the game and  I don't like my pc crashing to the point of no longer functioning I can't continue to tweak and play this game in the hope it won't happen again. And since most reviews confirm that the changes are superficial I can not recommend YOSE based on my experiences.I would also remark that selling a game with almost no viable changes for almost the same price is tantamount to a rip off. But we are now doggy trained to the anything-for-a-profit argument so I guess this signifies the normal pattern in game development. You can see this with the early access  games that never get into full release. At first the idea was to give players the chance to help develop the game, but people quickly saw another way to make a profit: selling unfinished software that does not get into finished state because "it is still under development". Examples are such games as  DayZ and Take on Mars from Bohemia Interactive Simulations, both almost 2 years in early access without a release date. I would advise people not to join the early access release racket. It gives bad companies methods to rip people off,  it makes good companies lazy: they use you for what they should do themselves: properly develop software. And then  finallly they charge you again when the game is released in full.  Yes, people, the game you helped develop, for which you did not get a dime but for which you are charged twice. Come on, people.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												It was fun at the beginning, gathering stuff and survivors, building shelters, shooting Zeds, meeting new friends(NPCs). But after a while it all gets bored.This is what I've been feeling so far:（1）'Oh the construction is down, you gotta do something!' （2）'Oh one of our guys is SAD/ANGER/FEAR/TRAPPED, you gotta do something!'（3）‘Oh we found a survivor out there, you gotta do something!'（4）’Oh hey, I have something I need to deliver to next door, I am a lazy F*ck, so.......... you gotta do something!'（5）'OH could you please take 5 minute drive to the next town to pick up an NPC, then another 5 minute  drive back home to pick up some bullets which you already have on you but we just want you to take more. And at last drive back to the next town so this NPC can get off this dumb car and disppear into a wall. No big deal, we just wanna f*ck things up. So.................you gotta do something!'（6）'Oh you are 6000M away from home? Well, we've heard a survivor got trapped by zombies next door, even if you don't show up, he/she would still survive any way. But if you don't show up in 1 minute, your fame would decrease, well you know, not for a particular reason, just because we can. So.........you gotta do something!'（7）'Oh thanks for inviting me to join your zombie hunt. It's been awhile since I got outside...... OMG!!! Zombies up ahead!! I am gonna stand here and do nothing. But if you start shooting, I am gonna stand in front of your gun and eat all your bullets, so I can destroy our relationship, and I will blame you because you shot me!'  *scumbag NPCsWHY I bother finding all the survivors any way, I gotta do everything myself.And BTW, the building instruction is not clear, I upgraded one of the rooms to level two, and.....................'Oh! looks like we need a library to continue' ......yep just when I ran out of space to build something new. F*CK it.The game concept is nice, I think it works even better on Multi-player mode or Co-op mode(if you guys would make this happen, just saying), but so far, NAH!(*with a sad face)OH , almost forgot......I think I have found a bug, the zombies often spawn inside a house which I just cleared 10 seconds ago. I mean they f*cking came out of nowhere. I spent 30 bullets and some intense melee fight against some wired looking zombies in a house, and 10 seconds later, BAMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM, 5 new spawn zombies standing in front of me. WTF?!CONTINUING MY GAME PLAY AND COMMENTS:(01/08/2016)Well I spent 88RMB ( roughly around 13.3USD) on this game, so............gotta dig deep.PS: all your upvotes and subscribes are awsome!!!Spent some more time digging into the game, well, as above the missions are boring ( mostly), and the building part is kinda out of date.This time, let's talk about AI.The AI in the game is, well, I have been looking on google to find the proper word, but....well, let's just use 'BAD' this time. Yep, it's bad. Here are some exsamples:(1) Always walk in front of your car, you hit one of them? DECREASE FAME!!!!(2) Sometimes they rush into a group of zombies instead of taking them out one by one, they get too much injury, they die, and consequences？DECREASE FAME!!!! This gets worse during missions, especially rescue mission. You got your a*s in danger to get ONE/SOME of the NPC(s) out, when you just want them to get in the car so you can go home and end this sh*t. If a zombie approaches, well, they gonna fight to death. I mean, hey! WTF? Just get in the f*cking car!!!(3) I don't know if it's my fault or AI on this one, if you are driving a pickup truck, the NPCs would mostly choose to sit on the trunk ( I am not sure if it's called 'trunk', if I am wrong, pls tell me ) where they can be attacked by zombies. Why? Because it's Murica???(4) This happen quite often. One of your neighbours ask you to kill a special zombie. When you finish the mission, your neighbour would just walk home, and would be attacked by Zs on the way. That sounds dumb.(5) I gave guns and bullets to everyone in camp, but if I ask one of them to go on a mission with me, they would prefer using knives and pipes, which is more dangerous, because they gotta get closer to the Zs. ( This of corse could be fixed by installing AI MODS to make them choose guns as priority, and I did. But if you guys can fix it 'officially', that would be great )THAT'S ALL FOR NOW.I WILL SHOW YOU MORE NEXT TIME.AND AS ALWAYS.................................STAY ALIVE!!!

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												New stuff:-New cars and car skins-New survivors and lifeline characters can be played in breakdown -New Incindiary shotgun-All weapons in this game can be played in all game modes (breakdown,vanilla and lifeline)-New mission named Cleo There are still bugs and issues from SOD that still exist in this game:-No one is in the watch tower even though someone is assigned this happen often especially in Snyder Warehouse-Survivors ignore the zombies even though they are already inside the base!-Zombies getting stucked for some reason-Random crashes and now more crashes than vanilla version -Survivors nagging about there is not enough materials but actually there is more than enough to build a structure or two-Zombies that were burned to death only shows animation but no fire effect sometimes when using incindiary rounds -Zombie claw attacks penetrate doors-Zombies and players still pass through walled objects and bounce back to their original place like an elastic effect (this happens especially in melee combat inside structures) -Ai still blocks doors when idle -Ai still attacks bloaters in melee -Zombies can climb though barbed fence (this happens in kirkman residence)-Animation issues when you roll over a group of zombies-Zombies pass through walls -Invisble flashlight (like the flash light is on yet survivors are not equipped with one and reminds me of old school CS)-Unfixed exploit where in you get exp on guns when aiming on a zombie who is dying/died because of throwable items (grenade, petrol bomb and a like) -Racksack becomes invisble when dropped and left for a certain duration however it can be still seen because of the marker of its contents and not the racksack itself-History:Ran Away trait is persist and can be only fixed after getting sick-Your progress in breakdown still progress even when you are not playing the game (the game is close/offline progress)and sometimes can cause death to your community if you did'nt finish some quest like locating a missing community member. There is no way you can disable this so far.-If you have tons of weapons in your locker there is no way to sort things out (everything is unorganized and you need to find stuff  that you need manually which is a total eyesore) And even new issues like:-The game starts at windowed mode and solved by using alt+enter-Alt tab will not really tab your window instead it will resize/restore the game-You cannot adjust the graphics in an advance manner in such away that you can only adjust the gamma, resolution and video settings (low-ultra) and not things like shadow, anti-aliasing and so on -Random FPS drop for some reason -Undead labs claim that "Facilities from Lifeline will be available in all versions of the game" however when I try to play breakdown I dont see this facilities as buildable structures like generator for example. Source: https://forums.undeadlabs.com/threads/everything-we-know-about-state-of-decay-year-one-survival-edition.47074/-Zombies teleport when in focus aim-Character change now has loading time for some reason-Animation Issues when in combat at an elevated terrain (stairs for example) that causes animation issues sometimes-Incindiary shotgun shells kills without flame effect does not count for phoenix achievement this happens when managed to kill a zombie at medium range or sometimes at a short distance-Chemical Incindiary damage does not damage zombies immidiately and only triggers when you aggro them (this happens sometimes especially when undetected) -Fires penetrate wallsFixed issues from SOD version:-Unresponsive ai combat system-Pixelated blood/gore-Not so dark when its evening compared to vanilla version making things more easier to see at night-Improved effects like dust particles, oil spill has now better texture and so many others -Juggernauts are nerfed-Ferals are now more dodgy -Improved handling for old school muscle car-Fixed issue on messed up shadows where the bomb is located at lifeline Conclusion:This game is meant to attract new players and as a returning player this is an epic face palm in my face because I am expecting a lot of bug fixes and less issues but instead its the other way around and the devs laziness shows in the game itself like you cant sort out weapons in the stoage, most issues/bugs unfixed and cant even adjust the advance video settings of this game. P.S. If the devs are reading this please don't take this personally but instead a wake up call to fix things up!

Posted: May 1, 2015
												First of all, please allow me to say this: purchasing this game is kinda wast of money.They did remaster the graphic and everything. The journal and radio menus looks different, but just the look is different. You can get the new character and more new items from the gameplay which is very interesting. But that's about it.I feel like they rebalanced the game difficulty but they did that in a horribly wrong way. When I first openned this game and played for 1 hour I deleted it on the spot then I went back to play the first one, I really like the first one better. To be honest I love the Lifeline DLC better from all the chapters, and the reason is that you can start a base with basic amount of resourse and gain influence in a certain ways. But in YOSE you can't get the influence in the old ways. I can't say it's not that easy anymore, I'd rather say its confusing. I think the producer didn't know what players are actually looking for. Instead of making this new edition, they should have just release a new DLC, OR, release a patch for everyone to download. The price on this thing is not that reasonable. I wouldn't suggest anyone other than zombie games collectors to buy this game.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												They took 2 steps foward and 10 steps backwards.  Game is really not worth the time or the money.  The main issues are horrible load screens that take forever to load up the game when started.  For some reason, the game loads every time you change survivors.  Survivors tend to wander off and constantly become missing and gain the stat of "ran away," which is annoying.  The major nerfs on skills.  For example, Mighty weapons ability "sweep," no longer knocks legs off of zombies like it used to.  It however does knock one zombie's legs at a time, which makes it pretty useless.  I do not reccomend getting this game, which should have been a DLC from the start.  If you plan on getting this game, I would reccomend getting the original State of Decay, the only difference would be combat and I guess that it is now in 1080p, which I really do not see a difference and a bunch of nerfs to your favorite abilities.

content:
Posted: January 8
												I played the game long enough and enjoyed it (at least as much as it allowed me to enjoy it), but I do not recommend anyone to buy it.Here are the reasons:- Buggy as hell. There are bugs everywhere is this game. Physics system is really bad. Characters clipping through doors and solid objects... Oh the vehicle physics are disastrous. And UI has some serious issues.- Performance is really bad. I mean really really bad for this kind of game. The performance is garbage really. I can't find anything else to say about it.- Story is meh (for original game) but God, things are so SO SO repetitive. Every day, one of your survivors has an anger or fear problem where you need to take them somewhere and kill some zombies, and bring 'em back to base. These kind of events are really poorly executed. Game throws tons of this kind of missions (like a neighbour needing help or one of people getting stuck scavanging etc..) It is impossible to keep up with it without frustration. But after a while you realize that these missions are not that critical to complete, as punishments for not completing them are not that severe. - AI is really crappy. Good for zombies but not for human characters. They walk on recently molotoved area, then start screaming, burning and running around like crazy. (You also loose trust points for this) In melee combat, they rarely finish downed infected, instead they swing and swing and swing until they run of stamina or get overrun by infected.Breakdown DLC is a total waste of time (and money). You play in same city layout level after level, only getting an increase in difficulty. And there is no story there, just randomly generated events and stuff, nothing interesting.Lifeline is a good DLC for its story and action packed nature of it but even it will frustrate you until you figure out what is what and learn how to deal with incoming horde attacks (Tip: Make good friends with grenade launcher and base vantage point).

number of helpful: 53 of 74 people (72%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												To be honest, I've never expected that much from MMORPG developers trying to make single player sandbox community-building zombie survival game. Endlessly respawning zombies, poor AI, shallow story and primitive gameplay were inevitable, but there's more to it that could've been done right.In the end, there are two points of view: as an xbox console game, even with all of it's flaws and drawbacks, it's a masterpiece not because it's good, but because there is no better alternative. As a PC gaming product, however, it can be described with a single word: mess. Literally none of the game's systems are working good enough. It's been nearly 2 years since original release and it didn't get any better.You can build yourself a base of your liking but there are facilities that are essential to build and those that have completely negligible effects so there is never a choice. On a first glance your people seem to be a community but after a few days you realise that they're just a bunch of drones: they don't establish friend/enemy/couple relationships, events about fights, jealousy or interpersonal dislike are completely random and random community members are 'picked' to participate, when a community member dies two random members will get a morale hit etc so both base and community building aspects are a mess too.What there remains? Hoarding? Your base stash has only 255 slots, so eventually you'll have to waste your time clearing it out every game day or two. Spent two hours gathering supplies to train your characters next day? Too bad, they got overwritten by your facilities' daily output and you have 5 items instead of 105. Character progression? Your favourites will get killed through a wall, when all floor two zombies fall through the ceiling while you're clearing first floor and tear you apart or your car turns over near two zombie hordes because someone inside farted.In the end I can only recommend it as a cheap and glitchy Dead Rising substitute. However you probably should play Dead Rising itself instead.P.S. Imagine yourself a grown up person that claims to be a skilled game developer. This person spends half an hour trying to get inside a blue public restroom and finally pisses oneself just because of being unable to realise that door opens outwards, not inwards. Pathetic? Definitely. Funny? Perhaps, but not so when you realise that it's your employee that you've sent half an hour ago to deliver some very urgent documents which had to be driven across town within 15 minutes or you'd lose a 1 million $ contract.

												THIS IS A SCAM!If you have got the original version of this game, DO NOT buy this one. It is EXACTLY the same, absolutely NOTHING has changed.Pirates. The only addition is one character, and a "special" SUV, which is, yup, you guessed it, identicle to all the rest. Yeah, sure its got a Camo paint job, but when its covered in zombie blood its the same. Same loot space, same health, the lot.As for the character? Meh, they are all the same any way pretty much, just looks a bit different. Sound familiar?Pirates.Also, as of now, there are no mods that work on this version as far as I'm aware, so yeah sure, its not a bad game, but the first one is better, as it can be modded. And it needs modded. The first game wasnt finished, in my opinion, and neither is this one. PiratesDont even buy this if you have money to burn, you'd be better off doing just that. This is exactly what is wrong with game development companys, and Gaming in general, They seem to think that they can do whatever they please, charge you a ridiculus price for it, and get away with it. Imagine it was something like a new car, which claimed it was overhauled, and better than the previous version, but when you buy it, all they have done is change the colour of the seat-covers. Would you be satisfied? I think not.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												I'm reviewing this game as someone who  DID NOT  play the original title. I understand people are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that they have to pay for this having already bought the original.The best way of describing this game is that it's a mixture of Theme hospital(lol), gta, dead rising and DayZ. The gameplay mechanics are massively rewarding and the base upgrading and scavenging/looting system are really well done.I've noticed quite a bit of clipping, lackluster textures for a PC title. and pretty shameful graphic options. On the Ultra preset it looks OKAY. you can expect to run it maxed out @ 60fps on the 6 series of Nvidia cards and above.Driving feels pretty horrible after playing straight from GTA5 also.The gameplay, progression system and rewarding base upgrading together with pretty satisfying combat makes the graphic niggles and driving not such of a big deal, though. Great game so far.
