content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												This is a hard one. I really really REALLY want to like this game. Its got all the elements for what should basically among the best zombie survival games ever. Usable cars, scavaging for loot and supplies, hundreds of weapons, base creation. But the massive set backs completely ruin this game. I'm not talking about the fact is basically the same game as the standard version. But instead things more key to the gameplay. The main thing that ruins this game for me is just how ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and useless the player controlled characters are. They usually cant do their automatically assigned jobs, most of them have no skills at all when you recuit them (apart from special heros), they wont use guns most of time, depending on what gun they have they usually cant effectively use it (seriously what the hell is wrong with ai and shotguns in this game), and none of them seem to understand the importance of always having someone on the watchtower (which as the main/only real defence your actual base has)  leaving you contantly open to attack. It doesnt sound like much but its just so frustrating when all your high level characters permadeath after spending hours training them up, just because they dicided to try to hit the massive boss zombie with a stick, rather than fire an assault rifle at it.The scavenging on this game also feels like a waste of time, in most of my playthroughs i dont bother taking a lot of the supplies as the most common items are way to common, all my bases have enough food to open a supermarket after about 2 hours of playing, whereas materials are almost impossible to find. Along with other low level weapons, melee weapons and pistols are never usually worth picking up, and in most cases even bullets aren't even that worth encumbering yourself with as you typically only use rifle rounds, and after a few hours of play you can just make them yourself. With no console command or no weapons dealer the very rare guns are basically impossible to get. It really needs balancing and the supplies need to be better distributed.Breakdown. The main DLC to play is a nice idea in theory but rapidly becomes boring. All that changed are the zombies slowly level up as you go. I cant believe theres 100 levels of breakdown, My personal best is 6, then i get bored and play something else. With no variation in levels you always start a level, loot the army bases looking for the rare guns, then build up which ever base is your favourite. Theres no side missions or random events to keep the levels fresh, its just a rinse and repeat affair. The only thing that keeps you going is the hope you stumfble along a new weapon, but its not really enough to base a game around. All in all its a game that shows lots of promise but gets let down by a few massive issues that just sap the fun from the game.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												I really want to love this game.  I had 50 hours on the previous version and I have logged 5 hours of what was supposed to be a really awesome SOD weekend for me.  There are a few perks to buying this game:  -The graphics are an improvement.-There are a few bonuses for buying the YOSE edition.-The game is based on one of my favorite games for the PC. The problems that will make me not recommend this game:-There are buggy zombies that appear to morph between/on top of/and around walls.-I have had to restart my computer 15 times in the five hours that I have played!-I have followed every direction on the dev's forum, on their own website, and on recommendation pages that I found on Google, and the longest I have been able to play without a restart is 30 minutes!When I bought the original version of SOD I lived with the glitches because they, at worst, caused the game to crash and there was a fairly forgiving autosave, but this is ridiculous!  This project seems not to have addressed the most infuriating aspect of the original game.  How am I supposed to enjoy a game when I have to reset my PC every 20 minutes?  Then I get the joy of finding that one of the developer's solutions is to reduce the resolution of my monitor to 1280X720!  If one of the selling points of this patch was the resolution upgrade, why wasn't it taken into account that PC gamers would have high quality monitors?  Overall I will say that I am having a great time with this game, and if the dev offers a substantial update to help with stability issues, I will change my review, but I can't recommend that anyone buys this game without taking into consideration that you will have moments of mad fury when you are driving back to your home base and your screen suddenly jerks to a stop... try to remember where you were at your last autosave, because your truck (that was probably full of supplies) is probably still all the way out there.For me, I will not play this game again until a patch comes through.  I regret spending the money on a studio that sold me a broken product.

												I beat the original and decided after a year of letting this ferment, I'd see if Undead Labs fixed the glaring bugs or just let it rot...( I didn't actually play recently, I was watching a live feed of someone else-For the record)I loved the initial game. The concept was amazing!  It was something no one had dared to do , and it was FUN.Story was kinda shoddy, but eh all zombie movie plots are so I digress.So as I dust off the canister or Trioxin, and see where we are...I warn you...It's not pretty...It's still rotting...sadly. *cough cough*Still have zombies spawing inside established bases, cars still go airborne if hitting the fat f&^ks, same useless survivors unable to♥♥♥♥♥♥without my assistance, BUT we added new bugs...oh boy...like on horde clearing waves, there are twice as many as before, your awesome car takes double the damage so running them over like before, which is the smart play, is not always the option. Oh and the bomb activated locations on your map that you stragetically build to prevent such a thing, yeah...no longer effective. it blows a horde apart but somehow a few survive the blast. Petty? Um no...it was a f#$king bomb. They should ALL have been eliminated. They set the RNG to place survivors who untie their shoes and get stuck in a garage simultaneously with another one who lost their flashlight and now is also trapped in a workshop 20 minutes apart so you have to pick who you make it to, oh and the one you don't pick who would have joined your posse of ineptitude and made it not suck so bad, is always the one who was awesome. Played both versions of this game and have yet to come across a survivor to join who didn't suck. Evidently there are those who have abilities like medic,mechanic,marksman, therapist etc however, I have never come across ONE. I find the drunk,angry,sad,emotionally unstable, unable to get along in any group setting, who need constant supervision or they randomly wander off and I have to save A-F%^KING-GAIN useless ones. *sigh* And I am refering to the ones you randomly aquire who somehow have a radio to talk to us to save them but have no F#$King idea about anything else when you actually get there, and NOT the one where its all sandbox...so the main game and not the DLC is what this refers to...before I get the hate mail. I actually had more fun killing them off and trying to recruit/find/win the RNG lottery ones who didn't suck...Seriously...I was like...*welp, you have anger management issues, have run off 4 times in an hour and a half and I can't take you out on your own to help you because you got hurt while running away...oh you're healed? Used up my infirmary and meds to save your useless♥♥♥♥♥ NOW you want to whine again?? Ok lets go.....and you won't need any weapons, this will be quick. Why are we getting out of this car in front of that horde, oh you'll see you whining B&^ch...*Never found a one with super human abilities like how to open a can of food, turn a screw with an actual screwdriver and not a pencil, could handle a gun without it going off within the base p!ss!ng everyone off...etc, So let this game be a lesson to us all, in the event of a zombie apocalypse, your neighbors are going to get you killed unless you fed them to the hordes...And after year 2 they have not addressed a single complaint/bug/issue-nada. But they took our money tho as quick as possible.I hate you undead labs for breaking my heart again...and since I inhaled that gas earlier...why am I starting to think brains are yummy...ItchyScratchy

If I was ever to buy and Edition of State of Decay it would be this edition and I would recommend this edition to any new players over the original, espeshilly if there looking at getting any DLC at a same or later date. number of helpful: 55 of 84 people (65%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												ORIGINAL REVIEW / TL;DR:Best zombie game on the market. All it needs is co-op, and we're getting that with State of Decay 2.NEW REVIEW:I didn't expect this to become the top review, so I'm rewriting this review...First off, many of the negative reviews for this game are those who bought SoD before YOSE came out. I agree with these negative reviewers that this is a sham deal on the publisher's part making people pay for a repackaging of the game. YOSE is essentially SoD with all the DLCs and improved graphics, so if I had bought SoD before YOSE came out, I'd be upset too.State of Decay is certainly a different type of zombie game, as it is one that you can play at your own pace and unlike many other zombie games you actually work to try to form a civilization out of the apocalypse. I haven't played every single zombie game, but I've played ones like L4D, CoD Zombies, The Walking Dead, DayZ, 7 Days to Die. SoD is definitely my favorite out of these because it couples an open world with characters that have personalities that can grow onto you. So I guess you could call this game a cross between the Walking Dead and DayZ.Another thing that makes this game more interesting is character death. Once a character dies in a playthrough, they stay dead for good. This has resulted in me deleting my save at one point because my best character got killed in an attack. It certainly changes the dynamic of the game, and even the characters who remain alive address the death of a character.The game is very well developed mechanically. I never ran into any game breaking glitches during my first playthrough, if any glitches at all, honestly. The game is good on this aspect, although the game still has a bit to be desired in the graphics department. I don't mind that seeing as this game is about two years old and never saw a physical release until YOSE released on Xbox One. Now for actual gameplay:In short, the game is fun to play. Melee combat (which is the majority of what you'll be doing in SoD) flows very smoothly, with fluid hacking, slashing, and swinging animations. It doesn't look like you're swinging at air when you're trying to fight off zombies. Shooting is also a lot of fun. The reload times are pretty realistic (meaning they're not very fast). This can make or break the game for you, depending on who you are, but I personally love it. You also can't spray everywhere with automatic weapons and hit your targets like you can in other shooters. I think the devs did a great job overall with combat.Driving is okay, I wish the vehicles were a bit faster/more durable than they are. Also on vehicles, they can't be modded with things like bullbars, armor, etc. Although the driving in game isn't great, it isn't unbearable either. It works well for what it is, and running over a horde of zombies is always a blast. Scavenging is also a lot of fun. Essentially, you comb through buildings, landmarks, etc. for supplies to bring back to your settlement. The types of supplies vary (food, medicine, ammo, etc.) When you find supplies, you can only carry one rucksack-full at a time, so it's always best to bring a vehicle with you and possible other people from your settlement to scavenge with you. Supplies also don't respawn in the buildings you scavenge as far as I know, so you can play at your own pace as long as you can find supplies. I'm sure anyone can finish the game before they run out of places to loot so this isn't really a problem.The single complaint I have about this game is that there's no multiplayer, but that doesn't really stop me from having a lot of fun with this game. It has so much replay value. Co-op will be coming in SoD 2, though.I barely scratched the surface of this game while writing this, there is so much more to this game than what I went over. It is certainly worth full price in my mind, so give it a go. Definitely buy it if you see it on sale, though. You won't regret it. 9.5/10.

												Consider this a first impressions. This review will be updated as I play more of it, yes despite this being a negative review I will be playing more of it.So, how do I feel after playing the 'beautifully remastered' version of one of my favourite games? Rather disheartened and more than a little disappointed. Even within just over 30 minutes of gameplay I can see that not much has changed and by no means is this remastered.If you already own the previous version then keep playing that. This so far offers not much in the way of improvement never mind anything new in the way of gameplay.What I will say is that the trees look so much smoother and lighting is simply amazing compared to the original. Most textures are that bit smoother but where it really starts to fall apart is the people. I don't know if they look worse or if it is because the background looks better that the flaws/faults of their rather... clunky features just seems to shine through. Oh and for those who have played the previous version remember what a delight it was to have zombies clipping halfway through walls/windows and such? Yep. Still happening.I realise I do not have that much time in this game but as somebody who has put in close to 100 hours into the original game and owns the DLCs for the original after half an hour I just feel rather disappointed and wished to warn those who have the game, do not pick this version of the game! For those of you who do not have the original and want to pick this game up, wait. Wait for half price or some decent patches because this 'remastered' game in its current state is not worth it.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												So all in all I enjoy this game. It has an interesting take and decent game mechanics. The game itself hits the zombie killing itch really well. There are some glitches here and there, but nothing I found to be game breaking. However, I've pretty much called it quits over one flaw. It randomly crashes. Not even gracefully. When it crashes randomly from what appears to be some graphical coding issue it gets trapped at a black screen. It is in full screen so it gets annoying trying to break it loose and kill the process. Not very difficult, but it really tries my patience. On principle I'm going to not recommend this game. Code hygiene is a basic. I understand crashing in mod-able games like with the TES series since things are more malleable by design. Even if a game has a crashing glitch it should at least redeem itself by way of a graceful CTD, and provide a crash dump to aid in troubleshooting.

												I love State of Decay, I've sunk over 200 hours into State of Decay, State of Decay is one of my favourite games ever. This? This is not State of Decay, at least not like I remembered. You might think that a Remaster, the so-called "perfect version" of this game would have less bugs or at least not add any new ones, right? Wrong. This version is BUGGIER than the original! I've seen zombies phase through walls like they are ghosts, zombie spawning seems off especially with regards to the specials (why the heck are there 3 ♥♥♥♥ING BIG UN'S spawning right next to each other on a street?) mission starts are off, its slower, I have to put the graphics to the lowest setting just to have a BARELY PLAYABLE experience. Why did I pay all this money for what basically amounts to a re-paint? There seems to be NO new content, I just do not see the value.Long story short, I do not think this game is worth the asking price if you have the original version. Other than some cosmetic changes there really isnt that much here. If you dont have the original, sure, buy it, it is a good game still. If you do, dont. Stick with the original. Like I said, I've sunk over 200 hours into that version. I doubt I'd do the same for this one.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												I had fun with this game, but I can't recommend it due to a number of issues.The story:The storyline is extremely bland and forgettable. The story takes place in a cookie-cutter American zombie apocalypse universe. No suprises here. The characters and dialogue are just as bland as the setting. In all fairness, the storyline in Lifeline is actually somewhat interesting. It's still not great, but it actually has some suspense and drama to carry it forward.The voice acting:It seems like the minor survivors are voiced by 2, maybe 3 actors in total. I was regularly saving survivors with the same voice as Marcus. You'll hear the same lines of dialogue over and over again. Many of the character models are recycled too, it seems. The gameplay:The combat is pretty fun. Popping zombie skulls open with a well-placed bullet is always fun - can't really go wrong with that. The melee combat isn't too bad either. It's all pretty simple, but I don't really have any big complaints.Mechanics:Base management is simple and boring. There's no real strategy or depth to it. It feels really lazy, and it's a big missed opportunity to add some much-needed depth to the game. Base defense is buggy and obnoxious. My biggest complaint about the game is inventory management. There are several different types of painkillers that do the exact same thing but take up separate precious inventory slots. Weapons occupy backpack slots, whether or not you're holding them in your hands. The trunks and truckbeds in this game are the size of a suitcase apparently. A small pistol takes up the same amount of space as a grenade launcher. There's a weight system, but it only really exists to punish you for carrying the wrong combinations of items - it's not something you really care about, it's just an annoyance. You'll find yourself making constant trips back to base to drop off loot. I feel like I spent most of the game tediously managing my inventory and running loot back to my base.Summary:Driving around running over zombies is pretty fun. And there are lots of different guns to shoot zombies with, which is fun. But unfortunately the game suffers from a depressing lack of depth and polish.

Something that should have been done originally from the contents release.I've resorted to playing the original game again. Albeit with some spite.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												This is the closest thing to a proper single player zombie game that's ever been invented.  I recommend this game hesitently knowing how scummy the devs are that made the game (they released a very buggy game and then re-released it with bug fixes and charged full price rebranding it as a new game).  That being said, the game is actually so good I'm willing to put aside my morals and say if you are looking for a proper single player zombie game, this is the best that you will find.It still has some bugs, and there are many things I wish they would change, but overall the game kicks♥♥♥♥♥  Things I wish were changed:-I wish they made the game mod-able so we could see awesome community driven content-I wish there was a proper element of human vs. human combat and politics.  As it stands the game is really just humans vs. zombies-I wish there were more maps for the sandbox mode, or better yet randomly generated maps-Along the same lines I wish you could make your base in any structure on the map-I wish that the "management" aspects of the games allowed you to pause the game.  I'd like to review my characters while back at home base and make plans for my base without half a day worth of gametime passingThings I love about this game:-The combat is very well done.  When you are overwhelmed by zombies there is always a chance to beat the odds and survive, which feels absolutely epic when you pull it off, but at the same time the brutal death scenes and permadeath make the death sting that much more. This entire portion of the game is beautifully executed.  A+-The base building and managment aspects of the game are far better than I expected.  It is so fun having a base and a community of survivors you have to care for.  This is one of the coolest aspects of the game and something I haven't seen properly done in any other zombie games (they usually just focus on you as a sole survivor).  There's room for improvement here but as it stands it is the best you'll get from this genre of games.-If you are a fan of The Walking Dead, this is the closest game you will find to emulating that experience.-The map is very well designed and the main storyline was actually pretty decent.Overall it's the best Zombie game out there and I don't foresee any others surpassing it any time soon unless some amazing Fallout 4 zombie mod gets made.  If you can look past your morals and just buy this version of the game you'll have a good time.

content:
Posted: March 30
												Walking dead meets GTA:---THE PROS---- Great graphics, the day-night cycle is just right and when the night comes you will be scared- Fun to build bases, outposts, drive around, collect stuff - Good performance on my GTX Graphics card, doesn't lagg at ultra- Plenty to do, you will care for the people you play with, you will build them the way you want to, play them the way you want to- Good story indeed, its not linear in any way, you arrive at your first base and you are free to do what ever you want but if you ignore some things ,some quests, your base's moral will slowly fall down what could lead to a guy or girl leaving or even killing themself so you really immerse yourself into the game- As previously said its immersive, you will really feel like you are in a zombie outbreak town- Small detail but you can climb stuff like for example in the witcher 3, it feels really good to do so- Has trading cards and achievements---THE BAD---- It's really hard to headshot zombies due to them moving very zombie like, yeah it is realistic but no need for that much of real life - Would be so cool if we could make our own guy in the game and dress him up, that would be much more awesome but thats a small detail- No multiplayer, I would be so happy if a game like this would be coop or online mp---OVERALL---It's an absolutely amazing game, you will play for hours just exploring and building up bases, listening to the soundtrack and feeling isolated from the real world.Score: 9/10

number of helpful: 55 of 92 people (60%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												To all of the grouchy Squidwards who are poised to strike and dislike, you can gripe and complain about the way I wrote something very informed and to-the-point, but make it be known that I honestly couldn't care less. That goes ditto for doing it on other peoples' reviews. It's just pointless. But anyways...State of Decay, in my opinion, comes with three games. The base game and its two expansion packs, but the thing is that all three each share their own style of play, which I'll break down. If any of these are to your liking, I insist you buy this game. Once I've finished covering the three different games, I'll explain the similarities. Sound good?State of Decay; base game, is my least-played mode despite how story-oriented it is. I can't put my finger on what the hell I don't find attractive in it, but bottom line, I don't put much time in it. Still, it gives you the tutorial of everything SoD-related, and has a strong emphasis on the caretaking of NPC's, and trying to escape certain doom. If you want a zombie game with a plot, and one that is more focused on keeping yourself and your community in this apocalypse alive, this should be a steal for you.Breakdown; my favorite, goes for a neverending, open-world experience that was highly requested of the developers. Breakdown has no end - unlike State of Decay and Lifeline, which both end once you finish all of the quests, Breakdown has no plot-oriented quests or ultimate ending. It's entirely focused on gathering loot, building a community, slaying zombies, and just seeing how far you can get before you ultimately lose everybody you love. Breakdown is the best part of State of Decay: YOSE, because of how limitless it is. If you want a zombie game that stresses open-world, limitless zombie survival with a sole focus on PVE, Breakdown was brought down from heaven and into the Steam Store, just for you.Lifeline is a considerable challenge. It turns the difficulty up to the highest mark, and makes the gathering of resources much harder, so as a result, my Army FOB started out healthy and strong, and is now looking like my local Pizza Hut (the one with the bullet hole in the window). To add further insult to injury, unlike Breakdown and State of Decay, which have zombie "assaults" as mere skirmishes with hordes that pass by your settlement, this one has zombies that mass up and slam you in overwhelming waves. It's actually kind of frightening. If you want a serious challenge, Lifeline provides.All three games share the same mechanics and controls - one big thing about State of Decay is permadeath. Each character has one life. Nobody (except for one character in Breakdown) has plot armor; everybody is highly susceptible to being torn in half (the zombies seem to favor that execution over all others), and as a result should be treated with extreme caution. What puts great stress on this point is that each character has different skills and talents, which can be leveled and improved, so that makes them even more precious.In stiff contrast to Dead Island, for example, there is an equal focus on melee and firearms, which I do like since I adore guns. Just as well, since, like Red Dead Redemption: Undead Nightmare, Zeds only go down with a bullet or a baseball bat to the cranium (headshots), with the exception of any .50 caliber weapons, which can kill zombies with one shot anywhere, fire, and explosives/explosions. Guns are especially useful when you consider that these zombies are actually quite sharp - they move fast and attack fast. As a developer said in an interview, if you're dealing with say, two zombies in close proximity; no sweat if you know what you're doing. More than two, and things get problematic. Melee encounters with hordes are desperate pleas for death.So ultimately what this game offers is three different variants of the same game, but they all share the same focus on building a community and rescuing other survivors. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												In spite of the glitches and diamond-in-the-rough quality, I am a big fan of the original State of Decay on Steam. To play it with fewer glitches, a few new moves, and a few new cars was completely worth the $20 (for a previous owner) cost of admission. However, I regret it now. It refuses to play properly on my system no matter how I tweek the resolution and other graph settings. It chugs and sticks and isn't even as smooth as the first edition. For me, it's been unplayable.  From the start, at the ranger station, I lost voices before Ed was attacked. There were times when I couldn't gather the duffle of supplies.There were some other changes to expect that were not present previously, and they that are debatable changes. There are many more zombies. It is difficult to accomplish missions because of the additional hordes. Driving a car creates zombie pride day every moment. They swarm at the sound of a vehicle. Stealth walking is the only way to travel in peace. Infestations are much bigger.They could have fixed the glitches. They could have added just a little new dialog and a few new voices. They could have made it playable without the chugs and lack of control from the frame rate slow downs (Saving Maya a gruesome death stating right next to a car door). Instead, they took my $20 and gave me an unplayable game.Thanks Undead Labs.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Now that the original version of State of Decay is not available on Steam Store any more, it no longer makes sense to me to compare the two versions and try to make your point pro or against upgrading to YOSE. So, I deleted my previous review and wrote a new and more general one instead, mainly for those who are not yet familiar with State of Decay at all. EDIT: The DLCs are still available for the original version, but the main game is not.In my opinion, this is quite an underrated game in general, and to me the best zombie game I have purchased so far. I can't say that I'm a huge fan of the genre and have tried even nearly them all, but I have seen my share of gameplay for quite a few of them. Anyway, I feel that the user review aggregate doesn't do State of Decay itself as a game any justice, because of the controversy the YOSE edition caused with it's pricing weighed against it's added content which many felt was next to nonexistent.First of all, I really like the combat system that actually has more depth to it than at first meets the eye. The variety of different melee and ranged weapons and the personal skills and abilities of different individuals make many different character builds viable and add to the replay value. The range of weapons is nicely complemented by the crafting possibilities of different explosive and incendiary weapons for horde control. Not to mention the use of different vehicles not only as a means of transport, but also as a quick and relatively safe way of  thinning out the densest ranks of zombies. Yet the most compelling point to me is the importance of scavenging and resource management, which with different home base upgrades adds a strategic aspect to the game. Where to build your outposts, what resources to stack and how to best put them to use are questions you have to constantly ponder to best suit your preferred way of surviving. Chance also plays a role here as the composition of your group of survivors, their traits and proficiencies have an effect on which may be the most beneficial way to go on each playthrough.I highly recommend this one to anyone who doesn't mind a bit of thinking and planning in addition of the merciless slaughter of the undead.

												The idea, setting and beginning of the game ist just great - but after some time it starts to become more something like a day at work - so much to do, a lot of things do not work out, time is always of the essence, and the people in your "staff" start to do a lot of crap when youre not looking. content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												First off, this is a zombie game. Nothing like taking a pipe and whailing on an undead until your arm is tired.That being said this game is horrible in every other regard. Asside from being dull as dish water its basically GTA/SR style games with zombies as cops. Seems fine except zombies spawn out of nowhere in an unending flood. You never feel a sense of accomplishment when you clear a building and 10 new ones spawn outside and come running in that werent anywhere nearby before. Houses seem to be zombie magnets, stay ouside in the fresh air and open fields where they cant get you. Clearly these where gamers before they died.Questing is broken as can be often completely removing a side quest if a main one or new side decides to showup. Toggling the map to search for it turns up nothing.AI is broken, while at times humorous, very annoying. God forbid you want to make a quick getaway while your partner tries to make up his mind what door he wants to get into deciding to take a leasurely stroll into the drivers side bumper for a few minutes while zombies run up, bend him over the hood and introduce him to prison♥♥♥♥♥♥ This is not a rare bug, this will happen almost any time they approach the front side of the vehicle you get into. Dont forget you can flip a car just by hitting a small bump cause the physics are garbage. Or you know. Decide outside the base is a great idea during a zombie seige. Zombies will often glich out when climbing and shooting them has a good possibility of them just teleporting to the otherside for quick easy access to your yummy delicious flesh.AI are stupid in the matter of guard towers, they dont use them even though they are avaliable. When they are an actual designated structure they often leave them unmanned because they are "tired" and no one takes their place. Not that someone with a shotgun is any good at hitting anything further than the base of the tower anyways. Might as well be shooting cottonballs out of a shotgun if you're  further than shoving it down a zombie's throat. Most item durability is a joke. Zombie hoard? Get in a car and run them over cause your generic tools wont last the fight, firing a gun is a waste of time cause it just generates more zombie spawns.My mind is still boggled how a small tri town of maybe 1000 residence can have so many zombies. The way I ran over zombie hoards I should have had the entire populous cleared in ten minutes.On top of all this I felt bases were generically useless and left me with little customizing or results of what was there to the point I wondered why they even bothered. The lack of realism in any sense just left me laughing. Like a Juggernaught walking to the gate of a chainlink fence when it should be able to walk through. Or better yet. Lets board up these windows but not let us shoot through the boards instead the boards will break no matter where you shoot. These are all lazy♥♥♥♥♥mechanics you expect 15 years ago.

content:
Posted: February 7
												Overall:  Yes, recommended.  It has a story line that is above-average, game-play is above-average, graphics are above-average (considering when made).  Everything is essentially above-average.  It needs a bit of work, but still worth buying, especially on sale.Pros:Story - A bit fast-paced at times, without much explanation for the "why", but it's not the worst.  Immerses the player adequately.  Playable Characters - Each character seems unique and has their own personality.  I believe there are over 100+ characters/NPC's in game.  Characters/NPC's will bicker between each other and do small missions (i.e. scavenging) on their own.  A nice touch.  Makes the base camp feel like the NPC's are contributing without you having to do everything.  They also defend the base on their own.Game-play - needs some polish, but it's still enjoyable.  Melee (blunt, edged, heavy weapons, etc.), gun-fighting (all types of pistols, rifles, SMGs, shotguns and sniper rifles), and vehicles (cars, trucks, SUVs) sum up the way to kill zombies.  3rd person perspective only - pro or con based on your taste.  Works great while outside.Base-building - definitely one of the best characteristics.  Build up the infirmary, food storage, tower, workshop, etc. to provide various benefits for your group.RGP-like - can level up various skills.  Not very intricate/complex, but enjoyable.Weapons degrade over time and need to be repaired.Scavenging - fun to scavenge.  Grab a survivor to watch your back though, especially at night, and hop in a car (more cargo space than your backpack).Radio - can call in scavengers to help bring back supplies, back-up (SWAT), artillery, new home base relocation, etc.  Of course, you have to complete missions to unlock many of these.2 other DLC's that are included in YOSE which change things up a bit.Cons:3rd person only - pro or con.  Can be problematic when entering buildings and small rooms.  Cannot see threats until the character is fully in the room due to 3rd person.-Driving - one area that really needs a patch.  It...just...doesn't....feel right...the turning and handling is a bit strange; also, accelerating and decelerating does a weird zoom in & out which distorts vision - hard to drive and recon the area b/c of it.  -Closing Doors - ugh, an area that is very annoying.  Sometimes you'll close them without a problem, other times you have to maneuver the character a bit before you can close doors (time consuming) - not good when being chased by a zombie horde.-NPC's / AI - weird glitches occasionally such as:  will stop accompanying you for no reason - happened twice to me; when escorting AI to destination, they've stopped moving just outside the objective (I had to physically push them into the objective to complete the mission - happened twice).  Companions like to block doorways - not game breaking, just an annoyance, you can roll through them or even push them out of the way.  They also like to spazz out and take their time when loading into vehicles - again, not game breaking, just needs a patch.Rated 7 out of 10.

number of helpful: 20 of 30 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												From the screenshots, descriptions and reviews the game looked promising but I am quite disappointed: The world feels empty, you can find items only in scavengeable locations, there are no drops from zombies. There are a lot of cars everywhere but all their trunks are empty. There is no really any goal. You are being spammed with very repetitive missions (kill zombie/rescue survivors/clear location/scout area/collect resources). Within a few hours of gameplay you have the largest available base with all buildings constructed. Except a few buildings' upgrades there are no upgrades in game. You cannot add weapon/armor to your car or craft and attach a scope to your weapon. You can attach silencers to weapons which are destroyed after 10/30/50 shots. You cannot detach silencer or replace is with a new one. The world is small and easily accessible. One of the first missions is to drive to the other end of map which takes only a few minutes. Cars don't have fuel. They can blow up if you drive over zombies too much. Poor choice of items. Melee weapons, range weapons, usables (medications and grenades) and that's it. There are no armors and an assault rifle takes same space in the inventory as 3 grenades. There are two types of backpacks giving you either 8 or 10 slots for items. Weapons statistics are not shown. For melee weapons you have absolutely nothing other than it's cost. For range weapons there are a few icons but without any descriptions you have no idea what they mean. AI of your fellow survivors is very poor. They will not attack zombie if it is rushing at them until it hits them. They often get stuck in buildings or are unable to get in cars. You may be just being killed by two zombies and they will be standing a few meters away and watching. No save/load. Game saves automatically and if you die the character is gone, you can still play as another character though. I did not really enjoy having to copy save files. The game is not prepared for multi-screen setups. It blacks out non primary screens. If you minimize it, it switches from fullscreen to window and there is no setting to switch it back. You have to search on forums for a magic alt+enter combination to bring it back to fullscreen, and this combination is not even in the controls. There is no borderless windowed mode.

												What I think about this so called remasterHonestly after playing about 15 mins of playing this I thought is was a complete waste of money and do not recommend purchasing this at all.The so called graphics improvements are noticeable (if only the slightest) in what I think giving the game a more cartoony feelFrom what I saw there was one new vehicle and some of the others had been remodeled/reskined, there were a couple of redesigned items and a fancier inventory, survivors, home management screenI all so think there were a couple of new zombie animations and the airdrops are a nice addition but honestly this is only really worth being a $5 dlc for the original game which I thought was one of the best zombies games I've played in a long timeBut if you have already played the first game and found it very enjoyable or your new to SOD and looking for a great game to play, you may forgive the $20-30 dollar price that is asked for this butI diden'tIn ShortAudio - Hasn't changedVisuals - Slightly ImprovedGameplay - only a few little additionsoverall, this is not worth the price that it is currently selling for(Edited because someone wasn't happy with me trying to save the person reading this some money)

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												First off i would recommend to buy it on a sale but if you think this game got everything you want for a zombie survival game, who am i to tell you what to do.You start at the lake where you spent some time with your friend but then some cannibals (because they dont seem to know what a zombie is) are trying to get a piece of you.Here i tell you a bit of the content:-Base building: After a while you find your destination to your first home the church at those homes you can resupply, rest, switch your character, etc. If you are sick of the little room you have you can get a new home with more space BUT you can only have one base. Also you can choose what your base contains for example more beds or a garden to produce food.-Zombies: Normal zombies are fast or not its a surprise, but the troublemakers are the freaks. Freaks are mutated zombies with special abilities like pin you on the ground or just smash you. Every Zombie is sensitive to sound so its an advantage or disadvantage, because while they can hear you they can also hear fireworks and other distractions.-Survivors: You can get more and more survivors to join you, but you have to win their trust. Every survivor is different and if they die they stay dead. If your character is tired or wounded you can choose one of the other survivors in your home.-Map: The map is large and contains small towns, big cities, farms and a military base.-Cars: In this game you can choose between a medium cast of cars some have more place in the trunk, others are faster, etc. But cars make a lot of noise wich attracts the undead and you are driving a car not a tank so it dont take much to destroy them.-Loot: You can find everything you need to survive weapons, snacks, firecracker, ammo, painkillers, everything. But you are not the only one taking the supplies you need to keep your home stocked with food, ammo, medicine, building materials and oil.-Gamemodes: In "State of Decay:YOSE" you get 3 modes but they arent that different. The modes are: State of Decay (basic), Breakdown (Harder than the basic mode with big hordes attacking your home in waves) and Lifeline (Basicly the basic gamemode except you are the military)-Conclusion: I enjoyed State of Decay because its a solid survival game with great gameplay elements and this game makes sure you wont run out of zombies. I hope i could help you out with this little review, have a lovely day!

I had a lot of fun with this one but wouldn't recommend it for someone looking for an arcade-style third person shoot'em up.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I usually don't write reviews but I think this game deserves one. Looking at the negative reviews, most of them seem to complain about the fact that people had to buy this game again. I do agree, that was a bad move for the reputation. But as a fresh player I have fresh opinions. I don't have many hours in this game but I bet there will be a plenty more.My first thoughts were just about: "Zombie GTA!" I just thought it played very much similar to GTA games. When I got deeper, I realized that this game was just what I had hoped for. It's what I actually look for in a zombie game: You have to think carefully what amount of zombies you can take up and not just go full rambo through a horde. And another aspect: Human survivors. Most zombie games seem to make the player the only survivor or, if the game is online, there are other players. There aren't many zombie games out there with actual human NPCs.Another great aspect is how the world lives on even if you're not playing. If the character is tired or injured, just quit the game for a couple of hours and they will be ready for action again. Good for me since games with unlimited action tend to make me bored after too much playing.If this is what you're looking for, I recommend giving this game a try.

(Mind you, Steam counts is off)If you've never played a game, I would reccomend because State of Decay is unique because its like GTA (Graphics & Realism-ish) & Saint Row (Sprint + Melee) with Survival/Zombies/Post-Apocalypse, but blocks your grind...wait for updates.NoteI do not hate this game (cause Coder/Prog/Art worke hard and I got tired of RE (Expect ReRev1 & Raid Mode) taking down corps who destroy population, and the rest of the world is left unscathed hence Why I came up with Perishing Rain/RE Extinction Movie A Game)...read credits and want to know who is the director?), I in fact nearly cried when I realize it wasn't what I excepted and had to refund the first time.Inventory & Items- Small inventory, Vehicle Trunks have less/equal/more slots than/to Large/Small Backpack (Happy for No weight limit in Cars/Trucks)===Runout of slots faster than weight and a limited to Stacking Items (Marcus can Stack 4 Chips w/Large Bag & Maya stacks 3 Chips w/Large Bag...WHY???)===Large Backpack has 2 slots more than Small & you can't drop items, you can only destroy, no Equipment screen so equipment takes up slots (Could add 2 Slots (Simple) more or a Tab (Advance, Check Discussions for my Idea) for Equipment and you can't store items in places you found them- Being Overcumbered here is better than Skyrim, can Run, can't Sprinting, but cars are plenty- Party Members can't take stuff, weapons or items/unless I befriend them...... Bag Has few more slots than Minecraft's Quickslots)...4 Slots Without Bag, +4 Slots with Small and +2 with Large (Rugsack don't Add Slots)===And if you find another Bag -not referring to rucksack- its not like you put stuff in it, drop it, store it somewhere, carry it or have/escort someone else as they carry it===When you equip, nothing really happens unless the bag is bigger or too small- Food should be eaten on a daily basis (GTA San Andreas w/MGS Peace Walker Rating System) while Meds should only be used for injury===Food should restore back small health w/high Stamina and be easier to gather ===Meds should restore health at high rate/stamina at low rate, but hard to find -Not just hard in amount, but say Zombies in Hospital like how you have it===Needed to Mod in order to get Stats on Weapons and items too so you don't know how good something is and I don't know if you can dual weapons (Most likely Can't) and auto-switch when they break (Also I discovered there is Workshop for Cars)Driving is Awesome++ Happy you can drive (Fallout 3 & 4 don't have vehicles unless you mod), have storage (Only accessible from outside, but Journal/Inventory is accessible from inside), get dragged out of vehicle if door is gone (Love that), scrape zombies of vehicle by running into/besides things or suddenly stopping (Koodos for that), you can drive & drift like a wheelman/vin diesel with the brake and if the vehicle flips over or explodes you go automatically flying out the vehicle (Cause technically everytime a car flips over in GTA I exit, so thumbs up on that)- Can Door Attack (So Can Ai), but can't shoot or hit with weapons from vehicle (At least Aim from Car in 1stPS or 3rdPS and Party covers Blind spots, Front Passenger Covers Right/225 DEGs & In a Pickup a Back Passenger can cover all/360) - (*After Reading Update* after Refunding, so *ignore the following*) *I don't know if they have User defined customization/Re-enforcing/upgrading/repairing*/cleaning (Add Mesh to Windows, Grill Guards/Shovel/Different Exit=Roof, Clean Blood off, Repair, Gas up/Siphon/AddGas, etc)*===I tried to park into a Workshop and nothing happen, must have not fullfill something/update*, but I was kind of hoping Mechanic would be a Skill that a Survivor has and you could ask for repair and they would send you to find parts...That Extra Locker Slot for Quest Items?...Focus on Skills Please, Wrench Double as Weapons/Tool===This could be fun when trying to start a car/battery while zombie surround, but hey so is going to the workshopDLCs (*Unsure) - DLCs are Spinoffs (1.99 Stories) with slight differences/advantages (Wish DLCs where in Base)===Lifeline gives you lots of guns -cause your the army- but *no commanding/tell a person where to stand*, ===Breakdown has a bunch (~20) characters you can play from...I wonder if I meet them all in each storylineHow Saving Works- Saves only when missions done. - In an open world -miles away from destination-, that leans to Linear World more than Resident Evil 1 (If being realistic is fun, then I wouldn't be able to Mario & Luigi on a zombie's head...takedown moves)===Can't switch characters mid mission and your character gets tired as time goes on (And you can't sleep in a bed either...there isn't enough for you)What are Ai/NPC like - Couldn't command Ai...even down to Ed (First Guy your with...save his life)...feels like another game where I'm doing everything and everyone does nothing or help fight (Skyrim had a good/lite system for Commands, Hold Interact > Point at Targets: Floor=Wait There, Chair=Sit There, Item=Pick up Item and Enemies=Attack That, well leave where waiting to Attack,)...could instead Wait Mode > Command > Gambits (FF12)- I'm the one barricading (cabins & church...mission too), moving stuff from vehicle to vehicle & couldn't tell Ai where to stand to wait...some teamwork when fighting a horde and were all hiting the same zombie...No excuses you had space for 4 Emotional Actions, Throws Arms up*...What are you waiting for?- No Far warning when Ai is tired (Just run home)From Cabin To Church- Got to Church, unloaded stuff (5 meds I found at a warehouse w/car) and notice an Influence system (Like Currency, very good system, but can't make mistakes), Meds only have 5 Influence and I found that strange cause firecrackers & molotovs where equal and weapons had more...should have Market Stock Exchange System=What you need is worth more (I suggested already)- So I went to my jampacked SUV Yukon during First time Tour around Church and got MISSION FAILED/Romance???...came back and found out they badly needed Meds...that system is so linear, I know there is a mission with my name on it saying I have to go somewhere and find meds and bring it back (HAHAHAHA there was predictable)- Yeah meds are needed, but the weapons are worth more *Update Type-Med Rucksack/MedCase is what they wantCabin People (I found out there is no swimming or maybe lake is blocked)- I wonder if I store more meds/Rucksack would they (Cabin People) still be alive? Cause if we had to go to Church -can't command AI- who can drive in a car and fool (Thinking of Saints Row 3 hence why I kept Interacting in and out of SUV while nearby another car in Decay)Only reason I rebought the game after refunding it cause I heard of SoD2 rumor, possible Mods**, found I can overlap some keys and I sounded very arrogant...I wonder if its going to be Deja Vu (Already Seen) the same way I hoped for when I heard of SoD:YOSE for Xbox1 in Metro Newspaper (Too early for Mods**)Final ThoughtsWould refunded again (might not happen cause Steam Admins...Update* I did and it went through), reccomended if this is your first game.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												State of Decay is probably one of the most best immersive low budget zombie sandbox game i have ever come across.Especially being around since the first initial release of State of Decay, completing that made me want to know what else happened and what other senarios will occur in another story. Pretty much the entire game i have done the main + side missions and loot buildings of all sorts for specific or random goods to advance my safe haven of community i built.Pre much too much to explain, its literally a adventure. Maybe not for the first 20 minutes of gameplay cause of the typical zombie approach but after that its all action and adventure / stragedy survival !Down part is that they could have updated the original release of State of Decay, but notice that a lot of bugs have been fixed and more features have been added it was probably not so easy for the developers to just update as they probably reconfigured the framework they started building at 0.1Alpha. So i do not mind spending that extra bit of cash for it hopefully this time they should take more care of their framework and make the game struture more dynamic for them to update for State of Decay 2 (Which is actually being released soon i hear from Machinima!) It will contain Co-op gameplay which is something that i dreamt about for this game!!!! Anyways. Yeah.Story line 9/10Vehicle mechanics formular: 5/10Weapon & Fighting mechanics formular: 6*5/10Zombie AI & Friendly AI mechanics: 5/10Looting and Survival: 7/10I rate overal 7/10. Great game.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												You will enjoy this game for at least 10 hours I assume.  After that you be wondering how this amazing game got so lost. Lets start with the good:-Graphics are well done, buildings and houses and car mechanics all great.-It's a sandbox game and has base building.-Game controls are fairly easy to use and generally work well.-"Zombies" are realistic and can have a slight jump factor.CONS:-Gets old fast.-you will constantly be having to go out and rescue people that wander off your base or be forced to settle disputes within your people almost constanty.  -You can never have more than one person with you at a time except for very limited "quest" circumstances.-Resources are not infinite and neither are cars "although they can be fixed".-"Special Zombies" can be tough at times.. you come out of a house and haven't saved in awhile and one of the huge zombies kills you.. well you're dead and that's it.  You just lost that person that you could have had since day one and was your best player.-WHEN YOU LOG OUT THE GAME KEEPS PLAYING... so when you log back in some people could be gone or heaven forbid dead and your resources will be gone just about.  The longer you are logged out for the worse it is.-Story is hardly worth bothering with.. it's mundane at best.How this game should be:-Open world sandbox.-Single player good story.-YOU pick the teams that go out and scavenge for food and tell them where and when to go.-Make parties bigger than just a small group of 2.-get rid of all the annoying distress signals "your people only leave the base if you tell them to"-Need more materials in more places so you can play longer.-Have more freedom on basebuilding and job assignments.Do I think you wil enjoy this game? Sure but there is no way I can recommend this game for 30$ wait till it is 75% off before you even think about it.  I wanted to love this game.. sad.. really dissapointed stupid distress signals.. completely ruin the game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Please bear in mind this review was left at the time of release and may be out of date. I cannot change the review because I no longer own the game (had it refunded/removed). If the bugs have been resolved, great, but my review will remain the same, just remember it's out of date so take it with a pinch of salt.I don't often leave reviews. If I do it's either a) the game is fantastic beyond words or b) the game is so awful that people need to be warned to stay away.This is nothing but a cash grab, and not even a remotely good one at that.I can't comment on the game itself, because I've not played it. I've not played it because I can't face playing it due to the many pre-game play bugs I've already encountered within the first 5 minutes of loading, which are ruining it for me.It's 2015. Yet this 'remastered' 'game' is worse than the original - wow!I have a brilliant computer, which far exceeds the top end specs for this game. My monitor is not great, it gives off a lot of glare because of the material the screen is made from. Therefore I use a 7 year old matt-effect monitor, made from a similar material to the screens of the paperwhite Kindles, resulting in next to no glare or migraines.This 'remastered' game looks no different to the original, despite my graphics card being 3 times better than the machine I had when I played the original release. The 1440 x 900 resolution I use for every other game I have (and without issue), isn't supported by this game. Yes it's in the list of resolutions, but if you actually choose 1440 x 900, you're greeted to lines around the screen (no fullscreen), about 1.5 inches of the game screen not being viewable, going off the right side of the screen, and the task bar constantly shows up and superimposes over the 'not fullscreen fullscreen.' Pressing alt+return to force 'fullscreen' works, until randomly your taskbar superimposes over the top.I'm a little OCD, so I can't play a game with 1.5-2 inches of the gameplay off the side of the visible monitor. Games shouldn't be released like this in 2015. I've tried all of the staff suggestions and none of them have provided a satisfactory screen/resolution or fixed the 1440 x 900 issue, which they haven't even agreed is a bug yet.Multiple complaints on their forums about resolutions and they release a bug fix patch neglecting the resolutions issues.For almost a month people complained about resolution incompatibilities and nothing was done. Poor service.Avoid until they a) fix the many bugs and b) offer some additional content. The 'remastered' features are not, I repeat not, worth buying this for.I no longer own the game, removed/refunded.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												I rarely finish games anymore, because I just haven't got time. Yet I've beaten State of Decay five separate times - each one more fun than the last. I don't know why this game is so much fun to me, but it is.The negative reviews on this game are due to the versioning and price. This is essentially a re-release of the original game, with a few tweaks. They sold it for full price, and I bought it. Is this worthwhile, if you have the old game? No, probably not. But the game itself is so good, and so engrossing, that I don't mind having essentially bought it twice.Do yourself a favor and pick this up if you haven't played it.State of Decay is a true open-world game. There isn't really a main character, per se - you can and will control multiple people. Your first main character can die. You will lose people you care about. You will be responsible for the deaths of friends. It's heartbreaking and terrifying and difficult and frustrating and sometimes it's not fair. But because of that, it's engrossing and wonderful.

Posted: April 9
												I played the original State of Decay before playing this one. Apart from some resolution settings and a view graphical changes, I can hardly tell the difference between the old and updated version of the game.However, this version comes with all the dlc included which is nice.This game is an interesting zombie game as most of them set you up as a zombie killing machine where practically nothing can stop you. In this game, you can easily be overwhelmed by 2-3 zombies; but that what makes this game fun compared to other zombie games. You are not a hero, you are a just a random person looking to survive in the zombie apocalypse. And you'll survive by scavenging, building a base (in preset locations) and dealing with the morale and personal issues of everyone within your community. Overall, I'd say its not a difficult game as long as you use your head and don't go full Rambo.I would totally recommend this game for aspiring zombie killers everywhere.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												This a great game for any fan of the post apocalyptic survival genre. The game puts you in charge of several survivors as they struggle through a zombie outbreak (Explained in the story mode).You get to manage the survivors home, and its different upgrades, which all add something different to the survivors (Kitchen/training room/ sniping tower, etc). You can control each and every survivor that is in your group as long as you befriend them (which can be done easily) and then use them to scavenge or go out on a killing spree against zombies.The story mode is decent enough to be played through a couple times, it explains why the outbreak happens and introduces the main characters. But where the game really shines is in the "Breakdown" mode, where you start on level 1 with just one survivor and your goal is to find a van and "move on" to the next level. While searching for the van you come across other survivors you can help and have them eventually join your group. Now this is a fun mode in itself, but add a couple of simple to instal mods and Breakdown suddenly turns 100 times more fun and enjoyable.The game does have a few issues, like zombies spawning out of nowhere and getting you potentially killed at higher levels, but you learn to manage it (as you should be using survivors with Ninja-sneak perk anyway). Overall its a really fun game that I'd recommend to any zombie/survivor fan.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												Pc version on Win 10 64 bit.I think I have enough hours played in order to make a totally informed opinion.  This game is quaint but if you love it, you really love it and can't put it down.  Year One Survival Edition has game and both expansions, has upgraded graphics and new characters and content.What it is:  a mix of a shooter/hack n slash, base building, leveling of skills and base facilities, driving, making items, finding items, and going on various random missions.The first game is a run through with built in tutorial, and is story driven.  The second is the open sandbox mode and has 99 levels that get harder, faster, and nastier (bosses get more numerous and start getting perks they didn't have before).  The third game is a set mission driven, base denial type game that sees the zombie apocolapse from the military viewpoint.You will need a graphics card capable of DX11 but don't expect UHD graphics.  Gameplay immersion is awesome and you will jump out of your seat if you round a corner and a zombie does a leap attack or the wife grabs your shoulder to get your attention (yes, I jumped out of my skin and she is still laughing).  Any game that gets you that involved is something worth playing.The downside is the engine they had to use sometimes allows zombies to go through closed doors and some other collision effects.  I would have liked to see the company continue working on the game to polish minor points that could be improved but you get used to the glitches and they really don't detract from the game much.Death is permanent for that character but you just transfer to the next playable character.  You have to work at morale so that the others in your house are friends, thus playable.  If you don't like "death is final" games and just like to die, get up, continue, rinse and repeat then this game is not for you.  I personally like the fact that you have to play intelligently and wisely so you avoid death situations, get really upset when you lose a hero that you invested time in, but sign a huge relief if you survive the encounter and limp back to base to tag out to another hero.As of this post I am at Breakdown level 58 and ready to move on to 59.  I think you will like the game but watch out for the feral zombies because they are the worst!

content:
Posted: March 14
												Whenever I attempt to describe State of Decay to people who have never played the game, I find myself describing the game I want State of Decay to be--and the game that Undead Labs attempted to craft--more than the game that State of Decay actually is. State of Decay wants to be many games--chief among them the first video game to properly capture the community survival elements of a Dawn of the Dead film in mechanical terms (as opposed to the narrative terms of Telltale's The Walking Dead)--and, at its best moments, it creates a sense of community, tension, and character agency matched by few of its peers. But for each moment of spontaneous, unscripted story wonder that State of Decay generates, it is also one glitch, bug, or broken feature away from drawing you completely out of its experience.THE GOOD- Creates legitimate sense of community among your group of survivors-  Permadeath adds tangible tension to every outing- Building up base & team feels like a less pessimistic George Romero filmTHE BAD- Omnipresent bugs ranging from humorous to game-breaking- Controls lack finesse for more hectic action sequences- Multiple modes of play fail to meaningfully feed back into one another- World lacks distinct sense of placeIn my opinion, I give this a 6 out of 10.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												Theres a lot of griping of how horribly "broken" this version of State of Decay is compared to the original. As someone who has been playing SoD since launch day (on the Xbox 360) I can honestly say that this version is perfectly acceptable. Its not a massive upgrade over the original version, but there are some marked improvements. Ive noticed next to no bugs not present in the original, and my only issue with starting it up is I had to go into properties and add "-fullscreen" to make it fullscreen.State of Decay has never been perfectly polished, its janky and funky looking and its physics are strange and kinda broken. But it does what it sets out to do in a way few other games can match, and compared to my experiences playing the 360 version on day one, this is a huge upgrade. If you are looking for a open world zombie survival game thats a bit more serious than dead rising, but not nearly as hardcore and unforgiving as DayZ, that has more of a focus on surviving as a group than as a individual, look no further.

content:
Posted: January 9
												Loving this game so far! Has a pretty neat story, (typical of a zombie survival situation in the country). Great controls (most of the time!). A lot of complex base management and character customization (for skills, rather than appearence). Overall, a really fun game. for 30 bucks, it comes with both dlc which would have been cheaper than the original + the dlc (this costs 30 right now, original+dlc would have cost about 4 dollars more). On top of some nice graphical improvements and bug fixing!Some people are complaining that they can't support a company who re-releases a game a year after it was made just to fix some graphics and bugs. A "Paid for patch". But that's not what this is, its their own version of a "Game of the year edition". Games and companies have done this for years. A Prime example would be bethesda with fallout and skyrim. they've always re-released their games as special editions with all the dlc included. they didn't even improve the graphics, it was just a straight up re-release. And worst of all, they charged the price of a full 60 dollar game. This is half that with a really decent amount of content. I'd say it at least rivals fallout 3, maybe rivaling skyrim. One thing to note is the game can get a bit grindy at times. I often find myself just going back and forth between my base and town gathering one or two types of resources because they're used so heavily. only to get on a few days later to find all of that resource completely drained. There are things you can make and do in game to ease this and i've just not made it that far but it's still a small gripeThe other issue i have with this game is that it tends to expect alot of foreknowledge of you as far as the way things work. I had no idea you could recruit neighbors if you had enough trust with them and talked to the right people. Nothing in game seemed to tell me this (granted i could have missed it. The tip dialogue seems to be either really short and specific, or very long and vague). I ended up watching a youtube series and saw someone able to do this. Which is somethign at the time i had wish i had known.The main thing is it rarely tells you how things work. It doesn't explain outposts. It doesn't explain recurting members or how you become friends with people (so that you can take control of them). it doesn't explain how much time you have left for missions in any way other than hearing "some of these things are running out of time here" over the radio. Which, when you have 20 "things" on the map, it makes it hard to descern what exactly they want you to do.One last major dissapointment is the lack of co-op or really any mutiplayer aspects. This game just screams, two friends riding in a car bashing heads in and would benefit GREATLY from something like that. I have however heard the sequal (which was announced last year) will contain multiplayer (as far as i'm aware) so we'll have to wait untill then!Overall, a super fun game, some mechanical issues but nothing that can't be solved with a bit of research on the wiki. I've had to do that for many a game before so seeing it here is not unprecedented. I'd definintely suggest this if you're a fan of the zombie survival management game.

content:
Posted: February 21
												Survival Zombie-RPG ALMOST done right. This game is what I had hoped Dead Island and Dying Light would be on release. Gameplay: 9/10Survival Aspect of the game went above and beyond my expectations and probably the best one I’ve experienced in this genre:-	Declining Group Resources-	Timed Missions-	Community Building/Morale-	Camp upgrades-	Character perma-deathYou have all of these aspects to manage, all while trying to keep your played characters alive during missions, which incidentally update simultaneously, adding more pressure to your already stressful playing environment.RPG Aspect of the game is what I feel took a hit. Character building is fairly shallow. Aside from the general character stats, there isn’t enough character development in-game. Skills are fairly shallow and doesn’t do much to differentiate playable characters from each other, aside from their weapon specialization.Graphics: 7/10Not the prettiest of games, but that was never a strong point of this genre. Dying Light was probably one of the few exceptions to this, and maybe RE 5/6/7 (although I can hardly classify RE5&6 as Survival Zombie RPG). Regardless, it passes as an ok-game in terms of visuals. Music and Sound: 8/10Music in-game gives me a very Left 4 Dead-esque impression. Aside from Nostalgia, tension in the game is really well matched by its music and ambience. I think it’s really well done. As for voice-acting, it’s fairly bland, you can also easily notice recycled voices. This, however, I can forgive. Western RPG Games, in general, has yet to catch up to Japan’s voice-acting quality in terms of game characters only Bethesda, Bioware, Ubisoft and some select W&B games really stand out. Plot and Story: 6/10I haven’t gone too far in the game yet to make a credible conclusion, however, I’m not impressed so far. However, this in my opinion is also forgivable, being that the game is a Zombie-Surival RPG game. The premises of the game itself limits the variety in story I think.I highly recommend this game to fans of the genre, but if you are a perfectionist I’ll give my warning ahead of time. There are just too many instances that can happen that will “F*** up” your perfect run. If you’re this type of gamer, be ready to restart your gameplays at least a couple of times.

number of helpful: 39 of 72 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 15
												I have no illusions about how I'd survive in a zombie apocalypse. I'm not the fastest, the most prepared, the most agile, or the most sensible. The uncertainty of such a dangerous, nomadic lifestyle, where vital resources could simply not exist wherever you choose to go; I find it demotivating, a response that would prove deadly. But, in spite of this, I've always had a fascination with zombie survival games (i.e. not the arcadey shmups like Resident Evil 4 or Bulletstorm). There's something about that delicate balance between horror, stealth, action based combat, strategic base building, economic management, and curshingly bleak drama to be found in a deadly, crumbling world, all wrapped up in an emergent, player-driven story. It's a heady 7-ball juggling act that many attempt but few do well. Often the game can only juggle one or two at a time. Often, some balls are just dropped altogether.Make no bones about it, State of Decay is brilliant. I've played my share of zombie survival games, and just about every single one of them has left me slightly unfulfilled, thinking about the potential the genre has to be great. And, when I do, State of Decay is the game I keep asking for.With the exception of perhaps the drama, State of Decay juggles all the balls with aplomb. You are an ordinary person, on holiday with a friend, when zombies strike. After a small tutorial, you're then basically free to explore the massive area, looting resources, building outposts that net you resources, finding people to help (or do missions for), or just to walk around killing zombies. You can approach the zombies as stealthily as you want, either by sneaking up to them and smashing their brains on nearby objects, shoot at them with the firearms of your choice, by just running away, or any combination in between. Zombies will naturally spawn in various locations, and there are no progammed jump scares, so the horror is completely organic.You also are only human, so after enought time and exertion, your character will become fatigued, which lowers maximum fatiue. That's when you have to return to base to rest. You can then talk to another NPC to take them out on a mission, or even convince them to join you on a scavenging hunt. The base can be upgraded using scavenged materials, which affords a variety of benefits. Bases have running costs too, so the scavenged materials must address these needs. Plus, killing zombies affords benefits to your base, as it naturally should; the fewer zombies around, the less damage they'll do to the base and its morale.On top of all this, there is a story, and missions for you to complete. So there is drama, although not all of it emergent. It's a delicate balance between story-driven purpose and sandboxed fun. There's plenty of reward for exploring and doing your own thing, but at the same time, you don't feel like it's all pointless.As the big red thumbs down indicates, after such glowing sentiments, there is a big ugly "but" coming. BUT, as much as State of Decay expertly realises some high ambitions, and as much as it is the game I keep asking for, I'm not sure if it's the game I want to play. The problem is that surviving in State of Decay feels a little bit too like the real thing (obviously I don't mean "the real thing" literally!).First and foremost, there's State of Decay's most controversial feature: real time passing changes things in game. Remember when I talked about the running costs of bases? They subtract from your base's total every 24 hours IRL. It's also not the only thing that changes IRL. I came back to a game I had stopped playing, and found that several of my people were either dead or missing, which is potentially a big problem. Bases also chew up building materials like nothing else, which is essential for various upgrades.This ties into my second gripe, which is that resources are more or less finite. Once a place is looted, it doesn't magically spawn new resources. With certain upgrades, it's possible to convert certain resources into others (e.g. food into fuel, by a process of making biodiesel), but other resources (such as building materials) cannot be manufactured or converted at all. So, it is possible to arrive at a situation, after many hours of play, where you no longer have access to any building materials. Plus, when a base can't cover its running cost in materials, this causes a very large hit to the morale, which can cause people to run away, so refusing to collect them until you need them is not a good option either.The people are finite too: once you run out, that's it. The game doesn't generate any people procedurally, and once your last person dies, that's game over. It accumulates to a rather off-putting thought: that the time you spent slacking off and exploring, or the hours spent making mistakes and trying to learn the various mechanics could cost you the game down the road. I don't think the game is that unforgiving in the end, but the thought is discouraging nonetheless.That kind of pressure can really work well in a roguelike game (e.g. Invisible Inc -- great game, by the way!), but State of Decay is too long, and doesn't have enough procedural generation to work on that level. While the economy of zombies is very much dynamic, and makes the world feel alive and dangerous, the missions are exactly the same every time you attempt them.So, despite the obvious brilliance of State of Decay, it's a tough title to recommend. I appreciate more as a piece of art than a game, and not because the graphics are especially pretty. It's that hardcore ideal that I hold zombie games up to, conveying both the intoxicating freedom and the unforgiving hopelessness of surviving in a zombie apocalypse. The problem is that it conveys it too well. I'm hoping that anyone who actually reads all of this will not be discouraged from buying and trying this game. Most gamers just want a game they can be entertained by, and on that basis alone, I can't really recommend State of Decay. But if, like me, you can appreciate an innovative, indie take on a tough formula, even if it can be unpleasant to play, I wholeheartedly recommend trying it out.
