number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 12
												I don't know where to start with this game. Apparently there's no intro-- I start a new game, the scene opens and I'm standing by water being attacked by zombies. Not even time to get my bearings, adjust to the physics of the game, make any necessary changes, or even process a storyline. Following this my main character acts completely nonchalant about what's going on, apparently unbothered by either the zombies attacking him or, if he's unaware they're zombies, the fact that he just murdered three people.The controls are not good. The movement feels awkward, turns are awkward, the camera is also awkward. I suspect gunplay would not be particularly fun in this game and the melee (at least at the start) is mindless mashing.Following the very abrupt introduction (i.e. appearing with no context or character/story build-up whatsoever), I make my way to a nearby ranger cabin and am greeted by someone who acts like I know exactly what's happening. Here, take these supplies and head back out to secure the area! And I, seeming to lack interest in the background of this situation, unable to express shock or horror at the unfolding situation, agree to do this with no particular need to question this man. I head back out to explore the area, climbing a water tower to assess different points of interest. This is pretty cool and finally begins to ground me a bit. I manage to access the menu system (which, for some unknown reason, does not default to the Escape key but instead picks a random button on my mouse) and am fairly bombarded with information. It's not an excessive amount of stuff-- it seems they struck a good balance between depth and accessibility-- but it's still a lot to take in at once and with no real tutorial. I manage to access game controls and can finally fix the y-axis reverse and change some of the hotkeys.Following this I begin to explore and seek out quest locations. However, my minimap is not 'locked' but changes as my facing changes-- again, I can't comprehend why this was done. So I have a difficult time orienting myself in the pursuit of static locations. I also realize that the movement isn't getting much better, even after adjusting the camera sensitivity. I find a few cabins, beat down some deadites, and enter to see what appear to be items strewn all over. Yet the cabin is described as empty and there's nothing to loot. I noticed the same thing in the ranger station-- lots of goods lying around that can't be picked up. I find this strange and an immersion breaker.A few minutes later I realize that I am already bored and have no real interest in trying to adapt to the game's clunky controls, no real sense of world immersion (largely due to the horrible 'plop you in with no context'), and am getting no enjoyment whatsoever from the combat. I log out after about twenty minutes for the second time since I picked the game up, recalling that I had tried once to play, didn't enjoy it, but wanted to give it another chance.Now I know it's not a fluke. The game as a whole might be fun, and it might have been more acceptable before I got into the Fallout series, but at this point I just can't comprehend some fo the developer decisions or the lacklustre beginning-- which is generally among the most important parts of a game and should be polished quite a bit before release.Scoring this game would be difficult because I haven't given the breadth of it much of a chance. So I will say 5/10, but if you can get past the issues I've outlined here, or really, really love zombies, the system seems interesting enough to warrant a 7.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Ignore 90% of the negative reviews. They are angry at this being practically a "Game of the year" copy, where all of the DLC and updates are included. Seriously, read some of them, they're pretty salty over nothing. As for the complaints about graphics, perhaps they just need to upgrade their hardware, because I've ran into very few stutters as some have claimed. You do see a little flickering on some distant images, but its really not bad at all. This game is absolutely fantastic, ranking well into my top 10 favorite games of all time; and that says a lot considering how many fantastic titles I've played in my lifetime. This game really makes you put in the effort to keep everyone alive and satisfied, without feeling grueling and overbearing. I waited until i put in over 10 hours before deciding to make this review, just in case it was an easily beat, or at the very least quick to beat kind of game. I can say without doubt, i'm not even close to half way though, and that's without touching the DLC yet. So please, give this game a chance, especially if you can while its on sale, you wont regret it. Even if its no longer on sale by the time you come across it, its well worth full price. I recommend this title to anyone into survival games, games similar to The Walking Dead, or just looking for a game to invest time in. Rating 9/10 (Would me a solid 10 but only a a very rare select few titles get a 10 in my book.)Cons- Zero. I've yet to find anything about this game to warrant a con. Small things, like a few minor graphics issues are to be expected from a game that's not made by some super development corporation. These people obviously worked their asses off.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Where to begin?  Lots of negativity in this one but not from me.Many are pessimistic here because, indeed, this should ave been little more than a patch rather than a total new release.  So, some had to double buy.  However, that stated, this comes with the DLC of Breakdown and Lifeline that the original one had to purchase them seperately.  Here shows, once more, waiting for that right time to buy, instead of getting immediately at release, can be a good thing.  Many games have updates not patched immediately, but held until complete and packaged together wit their expansions then.One thing, I desperately wish I could use my controller with this one.  Keyboard functions are nominal, but can take that precious second to reach that finger over that would have saved your life by rolling/sprinting away.  I only feel, using a controller I may not have had to restart so many times.  If I had a controller, the way it saves may not be so bad!  Death is perminant for every character, and between that and using the keyboard, completion of the game is possible but improbable. Visually, the game is stunning, grim, dark, amazing, and terribly terrific.Audio does cut in and out at times, and is extremely important as your char gives you clues on if you can outpost yet or not a place, and radio from home base updates missions still to do/new on map.  A text caption backup at the bottom of the screen exists, but is far from full proof.  Once I loaded a relatively young game up, at the church, we had our gate per usual but the wall wasn't there.  People were running freely from the church to the parking without using the gate.  Now, this may speed up their little scavinging runs, but what if we had a horde come through just then?My biggest dislike though is glitching through walls.  It happens pretty frequent, especially when a juggernaut does it when you're trying to pitch him fiery cocktails and not get the NPCs or yourself wasted during a besieged mission.Tip, at all costs, avoid a jugger when elements would otherwise force you to face it one on one in the open.  Avoid jumping into a horde on the other side of a window to try to kill the juggie at a distance.  Just run away to fight another day.  Strategical retreats, also, are noble.  Especially when twenty something people depend on your continued existence.  You need not tell them you ran away from fighting another thirty zombies, just tell them about the seventy before that you killed over dinner.  You are the apocalypse hero, so tell your story, your way.  History remembers the words of the winner, but dead things tell no tales.  Worry not, for the zombies you ran from will not tattle on you!Okay, I've mentioned many little nuances, and few large good things.  All those nuances though remove very little from appreciation and immersion for me.  Overall out of a rating of 100, I rate this a 99.  Great product here, UL

												FLICKERING SHADOWS!!!!!! Seems to be an issue with nvidia cards, i use 3 nvidia titans, horrible flickering shadows unless i turn lighting effects off, Makes the game completely unplayable----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Found fix in steam forum originaly posted by Faydark (thank you soooooo much as this is my favorite zombie game of all time on console) In gameplay look at a glitched shadowpause game and change your aspect ratio and confirm settingpause game and change aspect ratio back to desired setting and glitched shadows will be fixed for the rest of your play session (note: you may have to do this several times for it to work, so far for me, no more tham 5 times)(Note#2: In my experience, if toggling the aspect ratio a few times does not fix the problem, changing the resolution fixes the problem, then you can change back to the desired resolution and the problem should remain fixed)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Again thank you soooooo much Faydark!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!-----------------------------------------------------------------------Best zombie game ive ever played, really makes you think about decisions, love the permanent death feature, makes every encounter insanely intense, love the setting (kind of reminds me of blackfoot idaho) every house and structure is explorable and lootable. love how you can barricade windows and♥♥♥♥♥♥and create a fortress in any building. Story and voice acting are top notch, i actually feel bad if one of the characters dies

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												I know there are a lot of bad reviews about this game but honestly most of these im guessing are problems with their computer not the game because i run this game on high graphics and I get no problems whatsoever. Sure the companions in this game are not the most useful but they do help. One companion could be the diffirence between you getting a lot of resources and a zombie ripping your face off. Vehicles are super useful especially since 1. they can kill zombies really easily, 2. they can carry supplies in the trunk, and 3. there are a lot of them. Also i'll tell you right off the bat that this is a "year edition". Year editions like for example "game of the year editions" aren't remastered versions. Year editions are just the original game but with a little bit better graphics and all the DLC but at a lower price. Your not going to get incredibly better graphics with this edition just a little bit better. If your looking for a single-player version of games like Day-Z or H1Z1 then this game is for you. So to sum it all up. 1. not many problems.2. companions are useful.3. vehicles are super useful.4. a little bit better graphics.5. all DLC.6. decent combat.7. pretty good survival aspect.8. decently interesting story and characters.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I definitely have never understood the negative reviews surrounding this game.  Sure, the updated YOSE edition only included an entire 1080p graphic overall, loads of bug fixes, and new playable characters/items/vehicles/zombies in Breakdown... But, you didn't have to buy the "update."  I did, and I don't regret it at all.  I'm honestly waiting with baited breath for a new one to be released!  I want more content!  MORE!I have dumped hours upon hours into this game and I can truly say that it is awesome!  There's a level of difficultly that you can set for yourself--depending on your play-style.  I'm a more casual player, doing a lot of stuff just for the story and team-building that this game allows.  Some of the tasks *can* get repetative after a while, but, you can always choose to ignore them.  The developers made sure there was plenty to do to keep you busy.If you like survival, zombies, RPG, adventure, and discovering new play-systems with a twist--then SoD is for you!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												State of Decay, to date this is quite literally my favorite zombie game. SoD gets it right on so many levels, the main characters truly have character and the voice acting is actually pretty decent. This is an old game I had it on Xbox live and put far more time into it there than on steam. If you like survival horror games this one has one of the better replay value that I have found, rpg elements let you build characters base building to fill the needs of the camp.Needless to say you can tell I'm a fan, but I will say there are some consthis is an old game the graphics are a bit datedthe zombies never die out they just keep coming this kinda leaves me with a feeling of failure at the end of each play though as these are supposed to be small towns how many 10's of thousands of people could there have actually been there, sometimes hoards spawn in places that have been totally cleard instead of roaming from uncleard areasthe zombie killing can get stale, you spend alot of time conserving ammo with meele combat which is a little clunky and not very deepand the biggest con of all no multiplayer, the new game is supposed to have multiplayer of some kind.all in all I would recommend it but not a full price even moreso now that their is a new game coming, but I bought it twice at full price and still feel like my value was through the roof.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												State of decay does not have the worlds best graphics but it compensates (I think) in gameplay and challange. This game is not flawless (no game is) ocassional glitches are annoying but not a deal breaker, zombie hords are constant and never ending.  Anyone in this game can die, and I mean ANYONE! my biggest pet peeve is when the zeds swarm you and you have no way to stop a character from dying.  Zombies (zeds) are way too awair of their surroundings making stealth a moot point accept in the very beginning. The story is not very compelling but still enjoyable.  Guns are helpful but tend to lead to  more zeds coming to attack you, melee is dangerous and comes with it's own shortcomings.  This game is not for the ill-tempered or easily annoyed because you will have both happen to you.  Stealth needed to be better, more options for building forts all would have added to the enjoyment of this game. You end the game walk away only to come back and discover that all your safehouses have been overrun, Half the people you rescued are dead, (for no reason) and in general moral sucks. Yet when you left the game everying was on a highnote, so not having everything you have worked hard to achive suddenly fall apart while you were not playing the game would definatly been better, no would make more sense. Despite all this I have still enjoyed this game and would reccomend it with a warning, its your fault if you put you fist through your monitor.

												Yes. I played the first and owned the DLC's for it. AND LOVED IT. It wasnt perfect in terms of stabability but State of Decay was one of the BEST zombie games I have played. content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												I'm not going to lie there are many things wrong in this game from invisible enemies, clipping though walls and stairs, finicky controls, lag which has gotten me almost killed on several ocassions, and non consistant doors, which sounds like I'm being picky but when zombies can walk right through our defenses if the gate isn't closed I'd like all the doors to be consistant. Either I have to shut them myself or they shut automatically but in this game half the time the doors are automatic and half the time they're not.Still I recomend this game because the concept and the basic mechanics are sound. This is one of the most realistic zombie games that I've played and I like that it revolves around a sense of community instead of you being a lone wolf trying to do everything. And while it can get annoying to have been playing for 20 minutes for your survivor to get fatigued and you either have to switch out for someone else or stop playing for a while, I feel like it works with the realisim. No one can do everything all the time as much as we want to.

												While this game got some backlash for going "YOSE" I still feel like this game is worth the money especially since you get all of its DLC.Pros:>For a game that was put out in a rush, its a very unique game that accomplishes what other game could not.>Large map with TONS of lootable buildings, camp sites, ect. Its safe to say that 99% of the buildings are lootable.>Fun and dynamic base building with several choices to where you can set up your base.>Has a good mix of challenging and relaxing moments.>You can play as any suvivor you rescue or meet.>has a good mix of different types of missions so your not always doing the same thing.>Has a huge varity of guns (uses the names of real guns) and melee weapons along with many types of ammo, grenades, food/snacks, vehicles, and distraction items.>Fun DLC that adds many more hours of gameplay.>Has replay ValueCons:>The game still has bugs but none that i found were unbearable.>Zombies keep respawning in looting areas despite already killing them.>Has a cap on what can fit in storage but iv only hit it once and im a huge pack rat.>Cant keep playing after you finish the main story missions.>Have to reset the game every time you want to swithch to DLC.>No multiplayer (although State of Decay 2 is fixing that -

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												there are a lot of negative reviews on this game from disgruntled PC gamers who feel like the original port should never have been sold and that this version should have been the PC version from the begining. This is not a review of indignant entitlement.This game is NOT Hugely different from the original, there are a few new questlines, some tweaks, characters all have a combat knife so when their melee weapon breaks they don't do repetetive kicks like they did. There are a couple new weapons and the campaigns all share vehicles and weapon drops.The part that doesn't get talked about much is that the graphics engine is substantially improved, it wasn't just a texture package, the UI, shadows, and geometries were also improved, resolutions run higher and the framerate is actually better. there are mods on the nexus that can make the original game much better, but they don't approach the visual fidelity that the YOSE version does. I bought this game in part to support devs that built something unique. I both this one and the original on sale, and i don't regret either. IF you've never played the original this game is EPIC, its on my top 10 all time games list, next to titles like Skyrim, Lego Marvel Superheroes, Bioshock, Tomb Raider, X3TC/AP, and Command and Conquer 3.if you've played the original and wish to see some improvements, most of them are here, there are also mods to correct the few remaining flaws on this one.

												Having played this for as long as I have, I have just a few comments:-it doesn't have wonderful graphics-it has no happy endings-you can't kill other players (read what you buy before you buy it)-you have to save NPCs-you have to earn acheives by actually doing them, not by cheesing them somehow-you have to create and maintain viable communities.It has great replay value, you get to kill lotsa zombies, and if you have a moderately decent PC, knowledge of keyboard commands in Windows, you can easily have a fun gaming experience saving NPCs at the same time. content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I feel people are being totally unfair to this release. This is one of my favorite games of all time and this version adds a lot, great new characters, new weapons, new missions, a variety of much needed new vehicle skins, new animations, along with better graphics and slightly better performance. People think because they bought the original version they are entitled to the remaster, but that's not usually how things work. I had no problem buying this game twice. This game is worth every penny. I've got way more out of it than most $60 AAA titles, so even buying both versions of the game and all the DLC I feel I'v well gotten my money's worth. Plus I love to support the developers of this great game. If you already have State of Decay, and don't think it's worth it to buy it again, than don't buy it. The original version is still great. If you absolutely love SoD and can't get enough, than $30  I keep both installed and mod the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of the original version.For me State of Decay YOSE is tied with Telltale's Walking Dead for the greatest zombie game of all time. It makes me sad this has "mixed" reviews becuase some people felt entitled to a free copy.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I love zombie games.   This game is a lot of fun and I can get lost just doing random stuff even in this small world.  Then theres always a but...The FPS in this game is just super unstable.  I have a R9 380 and I bounce around not "stutter" but BOUNCE from around 60 to -30 fps depending on whats going on.   It doesn't make the game unplayable but I had this edition on my Xbox One when I still owned it and only repurchased it cause I thought I could end up playing it at a constant smoother 60fps.  That was not the case.  If you own the original and don't really care to play the DLC I wouldn't recommend purchasing this but if you want a new open world zombie experience and not too worried about story elements this one is a good buy.  Would wait for it to be on sale though.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												This game is exactlty the same as the non-YOSE edition, except with all the DLC included and a couple minor things, more car skins... etc.   The graphics dont look much better if at all better than the original on PC.  If you were to buy one of them definintely buy this one, but dont buy both unless you're a huge fan.  Highly recommend this game, it's been a while since i played it now and everytime i see screenshots for it i get the itch to play it and it's hard to resist it...  may be one of my favourite games of all time, and i've been playing a long time...My original review for the non YOSE edition:Longest review i've written, and i dont like long reviews but i cant stop talking about it.I recommend anyone who tried this game to play at least until you've gotten to the church, which is fairly early on. I stopped playing it as i didn't understand the point of the game or what to do. Not a lot is explained to you very well but you can figure it out over time. I get really engaged in this game and it feels very real. When your favourite character dies, they're gone forever. No loading a savegame to bring them back.In the game, you can drive vehicles plowing through hordes, gather resources, rescue survivors, change home base locations to better suit your needs and build and upgrade your base as well for other purposes. There is a storyline and a definitive "end" to the main game, which i was worried it didn't have at first. However, the "Breakdown" DLC allows you to keep playing the game forever by reaching the next level after repairing an RV each time and driving to a new location, which is just the same exact map that has been completely reset except on higher difficulty (up to level 6 i believe, afterwards it's the same difficulty).I highly recommend this game, i cannot stop playing it, and i definately recommend the "Lifeline" DLC as it's a new map and more of a story based timeline, with daily seiges on your base you have to defend. More ammo and supplies are available in this DLC also. You also get to drive on abandonded highways and get caught in "Danger Zones" which is fun too.Only problem i have with this game is you never see anyone else on the map outside their camps, no one else is ever driving around, walking around (unless walking home from a mission, even if you're there to drive them home). You friends in the game never use guns or the weapons in their hands either when fighting. A lot of people criticize the way your friends go on missions and get stuck and never seem to do anything on their own. I actually like this, it gives you more to do. The game does get a little repetitive after a while too but if you switch between the DLCs it changes it up. Another problem which is debatable, is that time passes by without you actually being game, even though it's an offline game. The game simulates the time spent offline (to a point) when you start the game next. Despite all this i'm not sure this game could be any better.

												SoD : YOSE Is one of the few zombie games that I would advise others getting just plain simply because it is just so fun, tho granted it is quite repetitive and you feel like you are babysitting your survivors all the time, the amount of times I just spam my buttons for an execution just to see it happen is unreal.I shan't lie in saying I was rather disapointed when I heard that we were finally getting a game which you could barricade things in order to survive only to find out that 3 thin pieces a wood accross a window would be sufficient and nothing else, cannot barricade doors or place massive wooden panels accross sadly... content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Bottom line up front: Think a less comical Dead Rising without the stun-locking psychopathes with more than one playable character, Left4Dead-style special infected and some Walking Dead scavenging. It's no flawless diamond, but it's FUN. Don't let the "Mixed" rating fool you. If you look up the original State of Decay (that's not longer available for purchase), you'll see it had plenty of people praising it. Most of the negative reviews for SoD seem to be original owners who were upset they bought the special edition and found it didn't offer much more than the original.The difficulty is sneaky, and I mean that in a good way, like when you try to sneak up on a lone zombie, only to realize (too late!) that there was a cluster of zombies standing just out of sight, or when you leap out of a window to make a quick get away, only to land right in the path of a zombie horde. The tension can ramp up quick, and a moment of carelessness can result in a deadly chase.Houses that aren't cleared every so often can get infested, leading to more freaks (special infected) and hordes wandering around (and even wind up attacking your home base). To compensate, you can build outposts, set traps and recruit more survivors to defend your home. It's a fun feature and it's nice to know you can create small pockets of (relative) safety.My rig isn't high end by any means (Laptop, 5th Gen. Intel Core i3, integrated HD graphics), so I have to run it on minimum graphics, but it rarely chugs. Occasionally, a zombie will be standing in a wall, or I'll swing endless at a zombie and the hits won't register until I dodge away (not sure if that's a graphic problem on my end or a bug). That's about the worst problem I've encountered in my 20 hours of gameplay.Give it a chance, especially if you can catch it on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												If you're into survival in general and Zombies in particular this is a game for you. With three different playstyles; Storydriven (State of Decay), level based (State of Decay: Breakdown) where you can reset the game to reach a higher difficulty in the next level, and last but not least the Military perspective (State of Decay: Lifeline) on a City map specific for that story.The story told as well as the game in general emphasizes the building of a community of survivors and the teamwork required. Despite it being a Single-Player game only, they succeed quite well in portraying the everyday struggle of a (albeit fictional) Zombie Apocalypse.However it does get repetitive, the narrative could have been expanded upon. Especially in Breakdown this becomes obvious, but if you aren't annoyed by that one issue you're free to enjoy the game on higher and higher levels of difficulty with each new level you reach. I have noticed some glitches related to the graphics, specifically the lighting and shadows which is unrelated to the game functionality and I do not know if this is a problem on my system only or a general issue with the game. It is only noticeable in the early morning hours of each 24 hr cycle so I think it's a minor issue.In Lifeline you get all the cool Military Hardware so desired in the other two versions of the game. Based on a story where a team of soldiers find themselves isolated in a City full of Zombies, their only support being Helicopter supply drops hence the name of the title; Lifeline. Once the storyline is completed you are given the option to continue playing and save as many civilians that you can find (still alive) or end the story and the game to finalize your score.Overall a very enjoyable game. It's a shame there is no Multiplayer mode, though.

number of helpful: 15 of 33 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												For all of you looking for a true zombie survival game, you've come to the right place. You're going to spend a ridiculous amount of time having stories to share with your friends unfold before your eyes.The base game has an enjoyable story, though it's the sandboxy feel that goes along with it that makes this game an excellent one. You are continually capable of working toward your next story goal at your own pace, though if you're like me you'll find the majority of the game is spent exploring, collecting supplies, building up your base, dealing with other survivor groups, gaining skills for you survivors, etc. Every character has a unique backstory and there are -a lot- of survivors out there that you might run into and have join you.The base building is simple, yet very enjoyable as well. Depending on what skills your survivors have, different options are available and you have plenty of options available to you. Do you want to be able to support more survivors? Build a bunkhouse and a garden so that they have a comfortable place to sleep and food to eat if your scavenged supplies run low. Looking to cut back on the sneaking around and really take the fight to the zombies? An infirmary will keep your survivors healthy and a munitions shop will keep them well armed. Just remember, even healthy, well armed survivors might run into a challenge when facing off against the 'freaks' or special zombies.The Breakdown DLC removes the deep story aspect of the the vanilla campaign, though it adds a brand new achievement system that unlocks 'hero' survivors that, more often than not, are more capable than your average survivor. This mode also has 'Breakdown Levels', each time you complete one you move on to the next, more challenging phase, with new survivor achievements to unlock.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the zombie survival genre. I'd been looking for a game like this for a very long time and was extremely happy when I installed it and truly learned what it was all about. Enjoy and I'd love to hear your stories!

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												The negative reviews are unwarranted. Boo hoo, you guys had to pay for an enhanced edition of the game...they do it all the time. If people really didn't want this happening, there'd be more of an outcry for it to you know...not happen. People are stupid. This game's great, I can't wait to dive in for more. The general feel of it is nice, I get the uneasy feeling that at any moment my base could fall to pieces (and I like that for whatever reason. The combat is pretty swell, except I wish the AI companions were a bit more prone to using guns. The vehicle controls are really kinda floating and don't feel quite right but you can manage as long as you're not going too fast. The base management is a nice touch that I enjoy immensely. I also like the friendship system where you can basically befriend folks and get them to go on hunts, missions, scavenges, etc. with you. Basically, get this game if you've been interested, it's totally worth it so far for me.EDIT: I'd also like to note that I have had no bugs, so the people who are reviewing saying that...maybe Google your issue before complaining mindlessly on here. I'd appreciate it and so would a lot of other people who know this game's better than you're letting on.EDIT 2: If you're having issues on Windows 10, just do searches. People have more than likely found solutions. Use your brains before giving the game a thumbs down.

 Rating 9.5 / 10 I'm a big fan of State of Decay, I got it on day one on xbox 360 and probably played around 300h. Got it on the first week for PC and played 134h. Now I just got this version and I'm not disappointed. I just started and I noticed a lot of stuff that I really enjoy. Still got bugs, but oh well.   Animation (Walking, attacking,different zombie walk)  Mechanic ( changed the kick of unarmed for a grab and stab attack <3 )  New cars (new cars and different colors for old cars)  New breakdown character ( character from lifeline DLC )  New icon for the map  More zombie on map   New music  New HUD  I don't know what people expected.. It's the main game just with more stuff, it's not like they were making a new game. It's just a different and better experience.

												Please do not be turned off by the negative reviews. If you think its a bad game because of them, you need to reconsider. The game is very good in itself, ive played nearly 200 hours of it for the xbox 360. Most of the negative reviews are only from people who are dissapointed that it is not too different from the original. The new version of the game includes new vehicles, survivors, missions, and a pretty nice graphics remake. While this doesnt add up to be TOO much content, its enough to keep the game fresh. Even in its own, the game does not get boring easily. Plus, the fact that it comes with both of the DLC for the game justs the price. Its kind of dissapointing when I see people hating against the game as a whole because the update wasnt that impactful, and they dont even realize that the price comes with the DLC included. If you have never played the game before, and like zombie games, I highly reccomend that you try it out. I got the game for 360, played 200 hours, and decided to buy it again for the PC.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												DISCLAIMER: I played the original State of Decay, on PC, and loved it despite all its flaws.So what about SoD:YOSE? Well, it's more of the same minus the most obvious flaws, that's mainly  the weirdly behaved renderer, which seemed to render at 720p internally, then upsampled everything to whatever resolution you had chosen, doing so without any sort of filtering. So it looks a lot better now. Still no antialiasing option in the game's menus, but you can always force that from your video-card control panel.The engine still isn't very good at streaming the world geometry in a fluid fashion, so the fps still drops significantly at times, slowing the gameplay down A LOT in the process, but that usually doesn't last for more than a second. Might also be a lot less noticeable on a SSD, I'll have to give that a try...Lastly, the quests' progression will still get stuck when some random zombies forget to get into the quest area and you'll still have to either chase them down or wait for them to despawn in order for the mission continue.In conclusion, I'd say it's not exactly the facelift I was hoping for. The graphics still look sort of dated, the engine still can't handle the size of the map (I could fit the game 8 times in RAM, but the engine insists on swapping and streaming from the HDD like it's 2008), the zombie AI still gets in the way... But you know what? It's still a great survival/resource management game, probably the best in the zombie flavor: numerous quests, some generic, some unique; nice story; great character management/progression system. Plus you get all the DLCs, which are pretty good. I'd say you get a lot of game for your money... even if some small part of me still wishes it would have been released as a free update for those who already had it, because if you only sort of liked the first iteration, I'm not sure what little changed can justify buying the game a second time. Me, I had a great time with it, and I'm having an even better time with this one.TLDR: Is it worth a buy? If you like the zombie survival genre and didn't get the original game, yes. Definitely. If you already have State of Decay, you may give it a pass, unless you really liked the game or you feel the horrible upscaling-with-worst-possible-filtering engine prevented you from truely enjoying it.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Perfect game for anyone who loves building a team of kick♥♥♥♥♥zombie survivalists as well as feel immersed within a zombie apocalypse.I was thoroughly impressed with the amount of fixes that were made on this version of the game. I love the additions to the loyal fans and love how modding has progressed within the game.During the campaign, you look at the survival of 3 main characters. Marcus, Ed, and Maya. You find them stranded at the very start of the game. You are invited to join another enclave of survivors who are in the same position. As you progress you are introduced to new characters and the military's involvement within this apocalypse. You are constantly bombarded with quests that will allow you to help your community prosper as well as the characters you favour most but make no mistake the dead are still there.If that was too laid back and easy for you then the first edition of DLC will help you get that difficulty increase you desire. Unlike in the story, during 'Breakdown' you start off as one character with the forever loved radio girl, Lily Ritter. You are tasked with finding an enclave to take shelter in and help them thrive. While you are collecting resources and battling the dead you will be looking for an RV. A large vehicle which you can fit up to 7 survivors on to progress to the next level. As you increase in level, so does the difficulty. Introducing fewer resources for you to take home. More deadly special zombies which will tear your characters up one by one and faster zombies to make sure you are always on your toes.If that's too grindy for you and you'd like to play a story with a bit more then 2nd edition of DLC is perfect for you. Looking at the military's involvement far from the home that you are used to in the Campaign and Breakdown. In this post-apocalyptic city, you will battle your way through hordes of zeds to extract VIP's from the area in all hopes to defeat the virus. You will also be tasked on the side if you wish, to help civilians still trapped within the city before it goes up in flames.I put a lot of hours into the original game during my time on the Xbox 360 and I can happily say that the game runs perfectly on both platforms. I don't think I could find a more perfect game when looking at survival a zombie apocalypse.I recommend highly to anyone looking for a challenging experience into the survival of the undead.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												I turned this game on, not knowing what to expect other than zombies. I've only been playing for a little while but I'm hooked. This game is what any game based on AMC's The Walking Dead should have been. The price was right and I love me some zombies. I understand there was a version before this one, I didn't play that version.some good stuff+great mechanics for food, ammo, and medicine caches+satisfying to knee zombies in the head or finish them on the ground+immersive world that changes even when you turn the game off+short, tense dialog, which fits the setting, +cheeseball humor is appropriately few and far between+cars handle differently and driving & mobile combat is fun obviously the game is not without complications-engine endures frequent fps drops-missions can get repetitive-slightly steep learning curve (early on I lost a few characters I liked due to ignorance)-lots of notifications in the journal which feel overwhelmingworth my money.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Do not understand how this review got marked a few times for not being helpful? Oh well..State of Decay: YOSE Day One Edition despite the negativity for this game due to previous owners concerns, it is a great game to play. Purchased the game while on sale and was not disappointed at all with the overall gameplay. While playing the run-through of State of Decay Year-One, it was rather challenging but yet balanced to keep up the stamina of the characters.  The Breakdown edition is very balanced as you get to higher levels. The Lifeline edition is a great story line to follow to the end twice since you need to in order to get both achievements.With the Breakdown and Lifeline DLC with State of Decay Year-One edition is great package.My personal complaints are:Lily broadcasts seems to pester a little too much at times about other tasks when you wish to secure your home site stockpiles. The way I managed to search all the buildings and it helped to level up the characters Maya and Marcus with less difficulties, is to perform those searches before entering the church at the start. After sufficiently searched and found the needed stocks, only then enter the church to continue on with the storyline.The characters and zombies can walk on water and do not swim.My personal suggestions are:The pick-up trucks and SUVs should have more available room then 6 slots since they do have more space in reality to toss the duffle bags inside. Something like 10 would be reasonable.It would have been awesome to have multiplayer sessions of the game. To have a real community together to secure resources and defenses for the home site.Would like to have seen a home site big enough to implement all the facilities that you can add for the site. It could have had a home site requirement of 20 survivors needed and 75 building materials.Having 8 outposts is sufficient but it would have been even better if they were setup as mini-sites that you could lock in survivors into position on the roof to snipe oncoming zombies and you must maintain their stock levels in order to keep up the defenses and not just placing the standard mines for the surrounding area.Even though the game map is big; it just still seems rather small after playing for a while. Having a bigger map area would have been awesome.As mentioned in complaints above but now noted as a suggestion here, the swimming ability. If you were to swim in the polluted waters (filled with dead zombies) you could get sick compared to swimming in clear waters.I could continue to add to the list but it is still a great game to play. I do hope that the developers “Undead Labs” will continue with this game and create a great series/add-ons with it with all the suggestions made from so many players listed here and their forums. Also, thank you to so many players on Steam that created great guides to obtain the achievements, it helped a whole lot.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												(Previously had a 'Not Recommended' review which was rushed and uninformative.)Graphics: 7/10Controls: 8/10UI: 7/10Audio: 7/10Story: 5/10Voice acting: 7/10Port quality: 6/10After completing the main story of the original State of Decay a long time ago, I decided to pick this up and give it a shot again (had the zombie survival itch).I got it for about £10 which is about the same price as the two DLCs for the original game, so a decent deal, considering it is a sort of Redux version of the game.As a user of a 1440p monitor, I found that this game does not support 1440p at all, no matter how much fiddling around with the settings or by using mods, it just doesn't work, yet it supports 4K? Odd indeed... but this wouldn't be too surprising (as it is a console port) if it were not possible on the previous version of the game, which it is by using a simple command. I am unfortunately stuck with playing it in a blurry aliased 1080p which ruins the graphical improvements of this version of the game. Why the ability to use this command was removed is beyond my comprehension.As for the game itself:It is a very good attempt at creating a scenario where one must survive with a group in the event of some kind of zombie outbreak. There are elements of stealth; survival; loss (of valued group members); resource management; and exploration.The game is, however, not perfect. The simple act of collecting resources can be tedious and repetitive, and it is a large part of the game, but the threat of possibly losing a very experienced survivor on any supply run does keep the tension high, at least in the early-mid game.I can’t say much about the DLCs as I haven’t played them yet.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												This is by far one of the best zombie games on the market. I am really looking forward to a new release of this style of game. Possibly a larger world with more one on one interaction between survivors. Make coversations a larger part of the game. also allow for larger communities, maybe a little customization in designs for home base. It would be really cool to pick a place and try to make a base from raw resources (time being key) where you have to defend it as you setup walls, then hope your base is strong enough to defend against what comes at it. Zombie hoards and other survivors attacking it would be interesting. giving the AI more skill in self defense and attack as well as having other survivors attack your base you could be out rolling around doing missions that are so far out it takes days to get back only to come back to everyone being dead. Also allow camps to be setup for long missions that take days your buddies that are with you could stay up in shifts... maybe some of them fall asleep and you wake up to zombies eating them... some cool features this style of game has huge potential I hope to see that capitalized on.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												As a returning player of State of Decay with over 300 hours into the original, I felt I should share my feelings about Year One Survival Edition.  For the people who have played the original and want to know what was polished in this edition, here are the definitive improvements I have noticed so far (in addition to the more obvious changes that were made):-  Ferals are nearly impossible to hit with a car.  They have some very responsive reflexes, leaping multiple times to dodge a moving vehicle and they will jump over your car if you kick it into reverse (so no cheesy brake kills in YOSE).- Characters you've spent Influence on so they will tag along no longer run back to base when they get tired or injured, and they will continue to help out even if you take on a mission while out.  Previously, a lot of missions immediately forced them to run back to base.  I have run several missions and wiped out half a dozen infestations without my companion heading home.Edit:  A friend of mine says his follower just ran off after accepting a Scavenger mission, so there may still be some missions that auto-kick the companion.  So sad.  Did some testing of my own and found that companions tend to leave when doing missions for survivor enclaves (scavenge, beseiged, etc.) but stick around during missions for your own community.  I have run several Ally in Trouble, Missing Survivor, Zed Hunt and 'needs a talking to' missions without my companion bailing.  Hope this elaboration helps.- Juggernauts seem to have less health than before.  I continued my game on BD11 and managed to take one out with less than a clip of .22 bullets to the cranium.  To counter that however, there seem to be more of them out there (at least on higher BD levels) and I had to take out 3 of them on my first Ally in Trouble mission.- Less Bloaters.  They were everywhere in the original on higher BD levels and they seem to have had a significant population reduction.  The number of Ferals and Jugs though seem to be higher than before.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------And for some of the annoyances that still exist:- Zombies still clipping through walls.  I can see their heads but I just wasted a couple shots trying to hit them even though they are on my side of the fence.- Still getting stuck on sidewalks.- Fighting on hills can still be hazardous to your health.- Still having some trouble getting companions to get in the damn car.  Just have to drive back and forth here and there.  There does seem to be a semi-fix added to YOSE where a companion who is running in place due to bad pathing will try an alternate route after a handful of seconds and get in the car.  This is only if they are already in motion (doing the running man on the corner of the car).  A companion who is standing still will continue to do so until you can trigger a new response by moving the car a bit.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------All in all.  I still enjoy this game a lot and I hope they address some of the bugs that have existed from SOD's inception.  But for what it is, I still gave a thumbs up because those glitches were annoying, but not nearly as bad as the completely broken companion AI.  If you were a fan of the game and can look past those glitches, YOSE is still a lot of fun to play.I did have some issues with framerate, but I modified my settings to Maximum Graphics @ 1280x720 and it has become a hell of a lot smoother.  The draw distance isn't the best, but it's still a lot better than the original and the combat is much more fluid, the combat animations look much better and I love the improved variety of vehicles.Note:  I am set up in the Fairgrounds on my BD11 group so I have not experienced the returning Snyder's Trucking Watchtower problem yet, but from what I have read, it still continues to plague that home site.Edit:  I have decided to start over from BD1 on a new profile and will update this review as I progress through the breakdown levels again.

content:
Posted: February 22
												Oh my ♥♥♥♥ing god, they demand 28€ for this?! Im surprised cause I tried it on my dad because it looked promising but..this..its just a mess, AVOIDI played 20min and saw so many bugs and then had a gamebreaking bug by the end. Before I could even play I had another bug! BLACKSCREEN while the game ran. What a good ♥♥♥♥ing game.Seriously, this game is literally in alpha. I dont get how anyone sane can play this.The whole game feels rather clunky, especially the meele combat. Only the shooting felt nice.However, you'll notice so often zombies being stuck or spawned into an object somewhere, animations that get stuck or have someother kind of bug..if you can even play the game and wont be stuck in blackscreen and change your resolution till it works and then back. Wow. ONLY TO THEN HAVE A GAME BREAKING BUG BY THE END..How my 20 min went:Started the game1.*Appreciated the main menu/background*2.Could not do graphic options apart from low to high, im not a console peasent..graphic options not avaible and the menu seems rather bad  with sliders.3.New Game4.Black Screen...3.4.Black screen..Changing graphics solution, Vsycn and such till it worked..changed it back then5. Playing the game, having a clunky meele combat with another guy6. Going into a house while having bad textures all over the place..1080 remasted version totally7. Looking arround, having everything already pointed out for me where to look for..8. Going there then scavaging one item/place literally and then following the quest to free a woman..8.1 -> During all that I killed zombies, had bad textures..when i was at the woman it went so bad, zombies got stuck in objects, could not go over simple objects and I had to squeeze myself into there too to somehow get the zombies..9. Changed to play as the woman then, gunplay felt nice10. Was at public toilets to flush down this bad game but sadly my character got stuck in the exhaust animation and then the game crashed...So hard I had to restart my PC cause altf4 or whatever did not worked anymore28€ right there, quality 100% REMASTERED...The original game must be pre-alpha then.Edit 1 / 24.2.2017So..after I was really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥I tried it some more. I was actually able to play for a hour or two *yay* and my session did not got interrupted by a crash. I was able to play now till the first real village with the church and it looks like the game behaves alot better on the open world than on the scripted missions. At least I haven't seen the game placing zombies that bad again.So far it feels a little average overall, you got your "base" with different characters..do quests and collect supplies. The quest scripts are cool for making me teleport out of my vehicle *cough*I so far really have another big problem, or rather, its more of a game design thing. If I do have multiple characters, how is it that only I can collect stuff if I go out with someone else? At least in the scripted quest they did something as well (but actually brought nothing back that got added to the supplies from what I saw) I will check more into that again soon. Apart from that it was average, had meele combat with zombies the majority of time and I realized that some guns feel a little weak but that is at least smooth, the gore is also acceptable. Stealth seem to work as well, though better change controls for the silent kill then.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												The Good:- Endless hours of fun.- Incredibly terrifying moments when you truly believe that all is lost and there's no point in going on. (Which leads to one of the best achievements involving 1 grenade and many zombies *no spoilers*).- This is a fantastic game for virtual hoarders. (I've spent more time in cars than on foot, hooning around the map picking up rucksacks just to keep my influence in check *Influence is actually a currency in the game which you will need to build or use just about anything*).- A huge modding community which enables you to change the game to suit your own personal play style. (This is a must for any good apocolyptic sandbox).- Awesone game play.- Decent sound effects and music throughout.The Bad:- Yes, the graphics are outdated, even with the YOSE version (Year-One Survival Edition).- Lilly: Your Personal Assistant to "The End Of The World". She's an annoying woman. Does this sound familiar to all you SOD Veterans? "Sounds like they're in a bad spot, maybe you should lend them a hand". Yes, the character audio gets old VERY quickly. But thankfully to the Modding Community, you can shut her up.. PERMANENTLY.- Soul crushingly repetitive quests. Go here, fetch this, kill that and save this person from themself. Again, gets very old.. very quickly.- There are many elements to this game which fell short upon release, but again.. thanks the modding community, a lot of this game has been improved. More inventory slots in vehicles and the ability to slow down (control) behaviour of the zombies is a nice touch.The Horrible:- Lilly. You all know what I'm talking about. She sure as hell doesn't have to keep reminding me that time is short on EVERY single BLOODY mission. I'll get to it ALRIGHT?! It definitely makes freedom hard to bare when you're being constantly verbally carpet bombed by an incredibly up beat woman, who realistically does SFA towards helping humanity during the apocolypse. State Of Decay 2 has been confirmed:Is there anything they should incorporate to improve on the original game? Yes. Many things. Here are some of the main things that need to be improved:- Graphics, obviously.- Sound (character or otherwise). This includes and is not limited to character dialogue.- Music.- More quests. (And a lot more variety).- More vehicles. (Modding them would be great. Let us go all "Dawn Of The Dead" on the apocolypse, heavy plated shuttle busses for everyone!). Oh, and for the record.. there's a big difference between putting 6 rucksacks and 6 stacks of cofee in the back of a vehicle. I'd change the storage slots to a "Weight Limit". It makes more sense.- A lot more base customisation. There's no need to go Fallout 4 on the game, but at least give us some nice choices.- Weapon customisation. (And more melee weapons. Firearms too if they can.)- A larger playable area. The original mad from SOD is incredibly small compared to other modern sandboxes. Think: Day Z, on a much grander scale. Show us what Trumbull Valley really looks like. - A wider variety of buildings. - Possibly destructible environments as well.- And if the developers see fit to release a similar DLC like BD, go a bit harder on the density of zombies. I loved games like Dyling Light that made you really work to get where you needed to get to early on in the game. This made for an excellent challenge and a superb gaming experience all round.And most importantly.. Co-Operative play. MUST HAVE!Yes, I have much love for the Zombie Apocolypse. Many say it's being done to death. The truth is.. you can never have TOO MANY zombies. Bring on the end of the world.I'm really looking forward to SOD 2, and I'm hoping that Undead Labs knock one out of the ball park with it. Come on guys, don't dissapoint us! (No pressure)..Final thought: Would I recommend this game to anyone? You bet I would. 8/10 for State Of Decay - YOSE.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I'll start off by saying that I got the YOSE edition during the steam summer sale and it was worth every ~$8 that I spent on it. At this point I have 38 hours into it after beating the storyline, I haven't even touched the DLC yet. The best thing about this game is the gameplay, I would compare it to Left for dead with a little bit of GTA mixed in. I'll make list of my pros and cons so you don't have to read a wall of text.Pros;Very enjoyable combatBASE BUILDING with some tower defense mixed inDecent ammount of weaponsspecial combat/finishing moves that are learned over timehandful of drivable vehiclesvaried missionslarge selection of playable charactersvaried and unique attributes and quirks for the charactersa few unique zombie typesCons; I'll write a bit more on the cons afterported from console camethe game engine does not scale wellquirkly environmentstupid AIactually looks a lot like L4D2 (could be a pro or con)a few bugsno minimap interactiondraw distance waaaaay to shorttraveling becomes a bit of a chore, a fast travel system of some sort would have been niceinventory management is also a painvehicles don't feel quite rightmenus and team/base interaction is badzero character management if your not playing themI think a lot of the cons boil down to the fact that the game is a console port. I have a beefy gaming PC with a brand new Nvidia 970, 8Gb of ram, and an i5 @3.2 which can run most games at 60fps on the highest settings. That said I had a lot of issues of texture and environment pop in, really poor draw distance, and just overall very poorly optimized for PC. In fact I turned on Fraps to check my frames per second to find out that if Vsync is enabled it locks the fps at 30. The biggest problem that I had was when driving, when moving at a higher speed the draw distance issue was really obvious and the game itself would lag witch made it even harder to drive giving the amount of invulnerable objects that there are to dodge. The other big issue that I started to notice after playing for a few dozen hours was how bad the menu and management system is. There is absolutely zero character management if you are not playing a given character. In a game about survival and asset management that seems like a big oversight and missed opportunity. I imagine it was partially planned that way since many of the missions revolve around helping out or rescuing the other survivors that have left the base but it would have been was more fun to designate certain characters for scavageing roles or to be able to lock more important characters to the base. Special characters actually fill roles in the base and give your base bonuses if they are manageing the kitchen, farm, etc so it sucks to have them go out. I think I logged in one day to find all my neighboring survivors had died while I was out which kind of sucked. But realisticly in my playthrough I think I only noticed one of my survivors dieing and that was because we were on a mission together and he was torn in half by a tank mob. The last think I would mention is that there really isn't a lot of explination for the dynamics of the game. There are a lot of things happening on the map at a given time and the dispatch character will constantly be reminding you that your running out of time to take care of certain things but for the life of me I couldn't tell what the consequences of my action or inaction were. Anyway, the cons seem big but the gameplay is fun enough that you should be able to make it through the campaign without too much work. Also there are some fixes out there for for some of the problems that I pointed out, if you tweak any of your PC games then you should be able to find them. I would highly recommend picking this game up if its on sale and it is probably still worth it at full price. It certanly scratched that Left for Dead itch that I didn't know that I had. p.s. - If they skinned this game with The Walking Dead and fixed some of my cons it would be the ultimate zombie game.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												With all the negative reviews, I feel I have to do this release some justice.I have spent 110 hours on the original and 35 hours on this remastered version already.For newcomers, State of Decay is an innovative zombie survival with an open-world "GTA"-esque vibe to it.There is no other game on the market that fills the gap like this and considering the huge modding community for State of Decay, I strongly believe that this is a "love it or hate it" game. I cannot stop playing Breakdown.The definitive version looks stunning remastered in 1080p with new objectives and game mechanics. You can also import your original save files.As for bugs, there are a few minor which are common to the open-world genre, but there has not been one instance where my gameplay or immersion have been interrupted and there are certainly no new bugs with this release.Having said all that, for those who did not enjoy the original State of Decay, this release will not change your mind.I advise prospective buyers to read up on the new features and watch some gameplay before deciding whether to purchase. Do not be too easily put off by the negative reviewers who were disappointed after asking Santa Claus for too many presents.Sincerely, Aslan

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												What can I say about this that has not already been said? Probably nothing, but as this was one of the games that got me back into gaming after a long hiatus I have to say something.In a gaming market saturated with zombie survival games what interested me about State of Decay was the clear George A. Romero inspiration. The zombies are classic Romero, a slow ponderous mass of dead flesh that are all kinds of messed up, and as such they often lull the player into a false sense of security with their weak, slow movements. This is their weakness but collectively this is also their strength.It is easy to forget than more than a handful of these creatures are much than a match for the average player and often while allowing yourself to get carried away it is easy to overstep and find yourself face to face with a zombie horde. The results of this are obvious and as you struggle fruitlessly for what seems like hours the end is inevitable.And it is an end. Once a character dies they are gone for good and if you have not succeeded in bringing in new survivors the longevity of your community is in real question. This fact, coupled with the need to find recourses and protect your borders, can easily overwhelm even a well organised player; leading to ultimate destruction.There’s a lot good about this game, but I am sad to say it also has a few negatives that grate on the player the longer they play.Characters are almost non existent, use of dialogue is simplistic and does not allow for much variety and the result of this is that missions can become formulaic and lack interest. This is not as bad as it seems, as the open world provides a great deal of interest in itself; but greater character development would have improved my personal enjoyment a vast amount.The worst thing about this game must be the pure stupidity of many of the character, partly this is due to the afore mentioned lack of variety but its also because the random nature of the story means that often characters take up residence in the most foolish of places.This means that the player is sometimes frustrated by the need to protect characters who are simply too dumb to care about. On occasion prompting this particular player to wish I could put them out of their misery (or at least mine).All this having been said, I enjoyed this game a great deal; in spite of some poor storytelling the game mechanics worked well to instil alternating moments of the habitually mundane and the fight-for-your-life terror that makes the game rather unusual. As in the Romero movies that I feel inspired the game, State of Decay is less about the living dead and more about how we react to them, the terror is not about death but about how we live.I, for one, am hoping that the poor storytelling and awful characterisations will either be fixed at some point with future updates or will disappear in a continuation of the game franchise.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												The story is a little under developed. You're pretty often running alone in sandbox or otherwise which is just unrealistic. The map is really bare and pretty small. It gets repetitive quickly.Game looks fine and plays well. I really enjoyed most of the mechanics. Character progression could be a more in depth.There is an influence systems which determines whether or not you can do anything outside of looting and killing zombies. This is a really LAME system. When you do convince someone to come with you it only temporary and they leave you if you start a mission. Overall the game is fine and youll enjoy a single play through perhaps more if you have the time to waste. There is a great idea hidden here in poor execution but any zombie game where it feels like you're alone doing everything is not okay. Give me more character development, more despair, more freedoms and a bigger map, and for god sake if you're going to give me a group of survivors to work with don't make them so freaking useless.Basically take the freedom and level of immersion of a game like Project Zomboid offers smash it into this game and removed a few quirky mechanics (such as influence) and you've got yourself a winner. As it is, this game has a great idea but they just didn't deliver.State of DecayProject ZomboidDayZCombined these three games with an intelligent AI system so it seems like youre living in the zombies world then you've won it. You don't really need a storyline, but give me the freedom to create my own with. This game SCREAMS for a coop or multiplayer mode. It really feels empty most of the time.When it comes down to it, the storyline isnt horrible and you'll get your moneys worth if you like GTA sytle games + zombies. The breakdown DLC is neat but really sort of time consuming and repetitive, the lifeline dlc is meh.

number of helpful: 20 of 46 people (43%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												First off, I ask that anyone who agrees with my review or likes it, please up vote it to help combat the people who're posting negative reviews and downvoting positive reviews to give the game a bad reputation for reasons that have nothing to do with Gameplay.If you enjoy Zombie Survival Immersion, State of Decay is the game for you.State of Decay is a Zombie Survival game that focuses on community building and management rather than pure Zombie Apocalypse Horror. You will have a group of survivors and a Home that you must defend and manage. You have to scavenge for resources such as Food, Medicine, Ammo Caches, Construction Materials, and Fuel. But you have to decide, "am I going to be quiet and take my time searching, or am I going to search really quickly and risk alerting every Zombie in the area that I'm in this house!", believe me, this can lead to many quick and painful deaths, which is only amplified by the fact that this game uses a perma-death system. If you die, then that survivor is dead, they aren't coming back. If you have more survivors back at home, then you can continue playing as one of them, but you won't be bringing back that dead survivor in any way.State of Decay is much more of a casual game that you can sit back and enjoy your Zombie Apocalypse with a few heart pumping moments like when you run out of stamina in the middle of a fight you can't run from.I personally enjoy this game because it has a higher level of immersion than most Zombie Survival games these days. The fact that it is free-roam while maintaining a linear progression so as to keep you moving, only adds to my enjoyment.The survivors have their own quirky little comments that can give you a giggle or even a facepalm moment for how much a survivors comment can annoy the hell out of you. It brings to life the fact that each survivor really has their own personality and brings something new to the community. Beware, vehicles can and WILL be damaged to the point of explosion. And if that happens, RUN FOREST, RUN! Because that particular big bang, will bring the hordes running for a free happy meal.In the main campaign, you start off up north in the woods, I like to call it Camping Central or Ranger Town. You're rather clueless as to what's happening because you've been outside of news broadcasts and such while out camping. You then proceed to the Ranger Station and things start to become clearer as you go, you will meet new people, and have to decide how to work with them. I'm trying to avoid too much info to avoid spoilers. After you get through the basic intro, you will be at a church with your group of survivors. You must protect them, the church and scavenge for supplies. After some time, it becomes your responsibility to move to a safer location, and eventually, leave the town to complete the campaign.In the Breakdown DLC, you're in the same town/map as in the main campaign. Only with a bit more freedom as the main campaign missions have been removed. You start in the middle of nowhere and get given the choice on how to proceed, you can start a new community as a single survivor, or you can join one of three communities that are available from the get go. Items no longer respawn in buildings once you've scavenged them (not like they do in the main campaign). And this time when you leave town, you start all over again, so be prepared for it. Because each level of Breakdown, while there's a better chance for better loot, will also increase the spawn rate of Zombies and Special Zombies. Making it harder as you go along. Giving you more replayability to scratch your Zombie Survival Simulator itch.In Lifeline, you take on the role of a group of soldiers that are trying to recover a means to combat the virus (very Resident Evil like if you ask me). You will be on a new map made up mostly of highways to get you around the map faster due to the lengthy distance for each objective. This DLC is rather fun to play once you've put a bit of time into the main Campaign and Breakdown DLC, it gives you some variety and new storyline and characters to follow.Each character in this game has their own personality, this has only been improved upon with the Year One Survival Edition. What YOSE has brought to the table is some old bug fixes for this GOTY-like release plus many other improvements such as:29 new melee weapons 29 new firearmsCleo Military Supply Drop Missions55 vehicles (34 in original breakdown/lifeline)8,275 new audio lines30 minutes new music This is not to mention the higher resolution availability for YOSE compared to the Original SoD.But the bottom line is, if you're looking for a full blown, balls-to-the-wall action game, State of Decay isn't what you're looking for. I suggest you go and play Killing Floor (Killing Floor 2 is now released as Early Access) or something similar.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												I don't know how to recommend this game enough. If I could impress upon you the "why" you play games, it'd definitely make you feel like a zombie apocolypse was something you could live through... Or not... There's just so much to this game... But here are some things you might be expecting which will dampen an otherwise fun experience...1) The graphics aren't the most amazing. They're perfect for this game, but this isn't made in the Unreal engine and it's not that type of game. It's got a lot of things to put on the screen and very few walls between them, so expect medium view distances, and lots of "adequate" graphics. 2) No seriously, the graphics. This was originally an indy download game on the XBLA, so it wasn't shooting for the stars. There's a lot of short cuts, like how blocky putting up baricades can be. The graphics repeat a lot, Not every limb will fly off a zombie in a unique manner, it's just not aiming for that kind of game... 3) The action isn't fast paced. It can be at times, but for the most part, you're questing in a zombie apoc world. Running errands, or looting to keep your home base in order. That's the bread and butter of the game. If you're looking for scary wall to wall thrills, you'll find this game wasn't designed for you. 4) The game isn't going to tell you how to play. There's a fun leveling up system... it won't tell you how to use it. There's a neat system for maintaining your home base... it won't tell you how to use it. If you're not willing to experiment on the game a bit to figure it out, this can be frustrating. 5) There are glitches. About 4-5 times through a straight play through... you're going to get something that defies physics. Whether a zombie runs through a closed door, A car gets trapped in a porch, or a feral zombie goes flying across the gap between you... I know it sucks, but for the most part, the game is very fun, and those errors won't dampen the experience much if you're ready for them. 6) You're determined to not like new things... If you want a game that could be described as "Like Call of Duty with..." or "Like Resident Evil... ", then this is the wrong game. I've honestly never seen such a good blend of action and strategy. You're gonna have to come up with a plan for how your team gets by. And your second play through will be more enjoyable than your first. Honestly, I'm on my fourth, and it's the most fun yet. You have to learn what you can slack on, and what you can't put off. It's a unique experience, and that's probably its best quality. If you keep all that in mind, and don't forget that there's mods you can pick up on Nexus and stuff, this game is great. It's one of the only games I've bought that I keep returning to play. I play it again and again. I love the DLC... I love the alternate modes. And I love the voice acting. This game can be greatly engaging... Or it can be a disappointment, depending on if you're open to what the game is, and not what you hoped it would've been instead.
