number of helpful: 24 of 56 people (43%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
Summary- If you don't own the original SoD, read on. The game is solid.- If you own the original SoD, this is just a minor update. Read below to find out what changed, and decide based on those and the current price tag.- Shortly after release, there are bugs. New ones. I trust they will be fixed soon.EDIT: A year later they seem to have gone. Either a fix or other changes in my PC got rid of them - for me, at least.ReviewThere are many negative reviews from people who actually like this game, just expected something more from this new release of their old favorite. To them: please remember that Steam users might decide on purchasing the game based on your reviews. Your review should be about the game, not the maker's way doing business. This game is solid. Some say this is the best single-player zombie apocalypse survival game in the Steam market. I agree with them.SoD:YOSE won't bring much for the owners of the original game though. These new features are:- High-res menu items and icons- Better lighting- One new car type (SUV)- Varied car paintings- One new hero- Many cool new weapons- Some new combat moves- Some new textures and 3D models (don't expect a lot!)- You can re-case ammo in the original campaign and 'Breakdown' too, not just in 'Lifeline'- You can find and use the military vehicle from 'Lifeline' in the original campaign and 'Breakdown' too- Some new bugs, hopefully to be fixed soon (nothing game breaking to me)About the game:SoD is a third person open-world zombie apocalypse survival game, unfortunately only single-player, where you can manage a small survivor community, build and upgrade base structures, and research new items for your ongoing combat against an unlimited zombie horde. The game has perma-death, some RPG elements, a wide variety of weapons and you can use the environment to fight the hordes too.The main campaign provides a mediocre story with a good atmosphere, and introduces you to the gameplay.'Breakdown' is a sandbox version of the main story - you play on the same map, without the storyline. You start in a random location, find and join a community, and then take on its management. When all resources were used up, or you are just bored, there is a broken RV you can fix and use to take a few key members of your community to another area. It will be the same map, with all resources respawned randomly, where you will start in a random point (from your broken down RV) and have to build up everything again. As you repeat the previous steps, the horde gets stronger and stronger, and you will receive new, stronger survivors to reinforce your team. This is my favorite game mode.'Lifeline' takes place on a new map, is more military-oriented and as such provides a different experience. It is a mixture of the previous two: there is some story, but you can decide to stay and continue saving people at an increased difficulty - with a global leaderboard.Would I recommend this game?- If you don't own the original, but like what you have read here, definitely.- If you own the original and like it, maybe. You won't get much extra, so decide based on what I wrote earlier. Or wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: April 13
												Personally I do enjoy this game and while this game certainly does have its ups and downs, I am not here to praise or criticize this game. I am here to offer a phenomenal 4 Cheese Ravioli recipe!Here are the ingredients you will need!Ravioli Dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 pinch salt, 1 teaspoon olive oil, 2 eggs, 1 1/2 tablespoons water.Ravioli Filling: 1 (8 ounce) container ricotta cheese, 1 (4 ounce) package cream cheese, softened, 1/2 cup shredded mozzarella cheese, 1/2 cup provolone cheese, shredded, 1 egg, 1 1/2 teaspoons dried parsley.Pesto-Alfredo Cream Sauce: 2 tablespoons olive oil, 2 cloves garlic, crushed, 3 tablespoons prepared basil pesto sauce, 2 cups heavy cream, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1 (24 ounce) jar marinara sauce.1. Mound the flour and salt together on a work surface and form a well. Beat the teaspoon of olive oil, 2 eggs, and water in a bowl. Pour half the egg mixture into the well. Begin mixing the egg with the flour with one hand; use your other hand to keep the flour mound steady. Add the remaining egg mixture and knead to form a dough.2. Knead the dough until smooth, 8 to 10 minutes; add more flour if the dough is too sticky. Form the dough into a ball and wrap tightly with plastic. Refrigerate for 1 hour.3. While the dough is resting, prepare the ravioli filling. Combine the ricotta cheese, cream cheese, mozzarella cheese, provolone cheese, egg, and parsley and mix well. Set the filling aside.4. Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add the crushed garlic and pesto sauce and cook for one minute. Pour in the heavy cream, raise the heat to high, and bring the sauce to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 5 minutes. Add the Parmesan cheese and stir until the cheese melts. Remove the pan from the heat and keep warm.5. Meanwhile, in a separate saucepan, warm the marinara sauce over medium-low heat.6. Preheat an oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Beat the egg with the tablespoon of water to make the egg wash.7. Roll out the pasta dough into thin sheets no thicker than a nickel. To assemble the ravioli, brush the egg wash over a sheet of pasta. Drop the filling mixture on the dough by teaspoonfuls about one inch apart. Cover the filling with the top sheet of pasta, pressing out the air from around each portion of filling. Press firmly around the filling to seal. Cut into individual ravioli with a knife or pizza cutter. Seal the edges.8. Fill a large pot with lightly salted water and bring to a rolling boil over high heat. Stir in the ravioli, and return to a boil. Cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, until the ravioli float to the top and the filling is hot, 4 to 8 minutes. Drain well.9. Grease a baking sheet. Place the cooked ravioli on the sheet pan and bake in the preheated oven until brown, about 4 minutes.10. To serve the ravioli, divide them among four warmed serving bowls. Drizzle the marinara sauce over the ravioli and then top with the cream sauce.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												So what is this game?It's a zombie apocalypse open survival game.Enough said to be honest.Story: X/10So why a X instead of a number?Well, it might be because I really don't know which mission is the story, and there's basically no story at all at the same time where there is one. The game throws a x amount of missions at the player at roughly the same time. Gameplay: 8/10The gameplay is good, really good and addictive but it ha it's rough edges. The game starts with introducing the settlement mechaninc a settlement is a place where the survivors that you found live. For them to be able to live, they need food, medication and a place to sleep. Food and medication is able be found within the world itself, while you need to build a place for your survivors to sleep. Each settlement has it's own selected areas where you can choice what you want to build. If you want to have a survivor with you, well you gonna want to do a lot of side missions so you can rise your morale in your settlement, a low morale will make people leave your settlement.Looting is a big mechanic in the game, you do it like 80% of the time. It works but it's kinda weird. For some reason rushing a looting process makes more sound than shooting a zombie with a shotgun. The "fighting" mechanic works more or less. Shooting feels good but actually fighting feels awkward most of the time. You need to earn fame before you can take a weapon from your settlemet, yes you can find a gun and ammo in the world itself.Music: 7/10It's nothing special, but it's quite impressive when you can hear a gun shot in the distance.AI: 5/10This is the "best" thing in the game. If I could earn steam money for every time where an AI used their gun instead of melee a zombie. Sometimes they shoot when a zombie is not aggresive, and making them and every zombie within 20 feet aggresive on you.Total score: 7/10It might seem like I'm hating on the game, and in a way that's true. The game is really good, but it has it's rough edges. I'm on a "mission" to find the perfect survival game and this game is on the top three on my list. It's funny and challenging at the same time. It could have been so much better if they had fixed some of the things that have told you about in this review.

number of helpful: 10 of 27 people (37%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												For new players interested in SOD, yes I would reccomend this to you. For the vet players who own the original SOD and are debating about buying this one, think about if the new additions are worth the price tag to you. The game itself is basicly the same except with a few tweaks, visual improvements, new characters in breakdown and some of the breakdown challenges changed.For new players:State of Decay is a sandboxish zombie survival RPG. You switch between different survivors that have their own perks and personalities and try to gather supplies to help your group survive. There are lots of different weapons to use and there is a small RPGlike skill system. For example, if you spec a survivor in using blunt weapons then when that skill levels up enough you can pick 1 of 2 attacks for the survivor to learn. With firearms depending on what type the survivor specs in you can get better firerate, longer distance lockons, etc. The game also features perma-death so if your survivor dies, they are gone for good which adds a bit of tension when your trying to escape a horde or dealing with one of the "freaks".There are 3 modes in the game that you can play and they are:Storymode:The one you want to start with as it explains how you play the game. You follow the story of 3 survivors and without any spoilers, basicly work on surviving and expanding your base as you help other survivors out and start learning about whats going on in the world.Breakdown:The main survival part of the game. You start out with a random survivor, pick an enclave group to join, then get to work surviving. The main goal is to find an RV and fix it up. Once you do that you pick which survivors you want to take with you to the next level and repeat. With each level resources become more scarce and zombies become more populated. There are also challenges that when you complete them, unlock hero characters which have their own special perks and bonuses. Theres a small escort quest to bring them to your base and from then on if you restart breakdown you can then choose that hero to start with instead of a random survivor.Lifeline:This mode is unique because you take on the role of the army inside a city crawling with the infected. Your job is to simply scavenge supplies while extracting key VIP targets and any civilians you find. The key difference in this mode is that after a period of time you have to fight of a siege of the infected which gets steadily more difficult as you move on.To sum it up, State of Decay ( or SOD ) is one of the best zombie games out there at least in my opinion. If you've never owned the original SOD and were interested in grabbing it, then yes I would reccomend this to you 100%. As for vet players though, I know alot of them are angry about the support being dropped for the original and they do have a right to be. Its purely up to them if they want to buy this version for only a few new features.For new players this is perfect for you. For the old vets, again just think if spending the money is worth for the extra features that they threw in.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												This is a really great survival/management/exploration zombie game.  It's -almost- the perfect combination of different genres.  It only falls a little flat on the looseness of it's excecution.  A really terrible quest log makes your goals confusing, with missions and morale issues popping up and disappearing quickly while you struggle to figure out where you're even supposed to be headed.  If the combat controls were a little tighter, and the management tools were more powerful, this would be a perfect zombie survival game.  Why not emulate Assassin's Creed for fighting and exploration?  And your fellow survivors are almost useless because they will only scavenge buildings when you are already there - Why can't I tell someone to take 3 people and go grab the medicine we spotted in the pharmacy last week?  What about a contruction tree, rather than vague descriptions and no hint at what you are building up to?Hopefully there will be a State of Decay 2, and it will combine aspects of tighter, more specialized games into a really fun symphony of death and destruction.  8/10 would send Alan to his death again.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												This game does have many glitches and graffic problems; like "occasional zombie popping through closed door/gate, or even jumping through barricaded windows" and " bumping into a guard rail in your favorite car causing massive damage/ random flip into the sky then rolling out after it crashes back down into a horde..." -Whatever the case may be.Concept is strictly survival on a team basis. The game practically throws you into a situation right from the start where you help your friend and anyone else you come across to form a team of sorts. if you dont switch between members of your gang your fav characterruns out of stamina and is useless in a fight and you cant make your character rest while your playing him/her, also you home base "Moral" is a continuous battle because its falls to you to make everyone happy in the apocalypse.Even with all of these things the game likes to throw at you-it is awesome Harsh reality and constant threats keep even the most experienced survival gamest challeged for hours of gameplay in this huge sandbox.  the combat is more realistic to real life expectations and the "leveling" is purely experience with tasks or previous life knowlage. it has a lot of strong points to counter its weaker pointsafter 50 hours of playing the hardest thing to deal with in this game is the loss of your "hero" The first person you play as. Death is without a doubt the most annoying thing for characters you like because they dont come back theres no reloading and if the game saves you will not see that character again unless you restart from the very begining.I totally recomend this game for the shear joy of running hordes of zombies over with a fast sports car and bashing in countless skulls.7.5/10 is my take.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Okay, something none of the negative reviews seem to understand here. You have to realize what you're buying here. This is not a new game, never was advertised as one. If you spent five seconds researching what this new edition consists of, it is essentially a GOTY edition that you've seen on a hundred other games before. For those that already have the game, there will be little gained aside from minor visual and technical fixes alongside what could be considered a slight DLC addition, the new weapons/vehicles/etc. For those that don't have the game, it's a complete steal to pick it up now.This game is as awesome as it always was. Considering the size of Undead Labs and the size of the crew that made this game, it is a very well done job. Considering the fact that I picked up the first game for $20 and this one for $20, I don't think I was ripped off in the slightest. This game is by far worth $40.To all the people that hated all over this game, let me put it this way. Does it have paid mods? Does it have microtransactions? Was it made by EA? Shut up and enjoy an amazing game that is worth every cent charged for it.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												If you have played the original game, you may be wondering if the remastered version is worth buying. There are no significant improvements to the game, it's still the same game with a few nice changes. These changes do make the game more enjoyable but are probably not worth the full price. Improvements include:-Enhanced graphics and draw distance, and new textures. The graphics aren't significantly better, but the difference is noticable.-Improved effects, with dust, fog, and fire effects...-More animations have been added. Zed's move differently, and they changed the unarmed combat.-Cleaner looking interface.-Some of the features in Lifeline have now been added to the main game and Breakdown.-A new mission type, with new special weapons.-Grenade launcher attachement and incendiary shotguns.-More vehicles and some new skins.-One new character is included (if you bought the original game).-You can now play as Hawkes, Kilo, Vince and Sasquatch. (More dialogue was recorded for Breakdown).-More music in game.-Increased number of Zeds.There are still some problems with the game. Zed's can pass through doors, and there are pathing problems (Surviors can get stuck when trying to enter vehicles).  Unfortunately there is still no support for 4k or 2k monitors. I have a 1440p monitor and I find it dissapointing (and I'm sure I'm not the only one) that I have to play the game at 1080p.It may be better to wait for a discount, before considering to buy this game. Having glanced at some of the negative reviews, I agree that this game is not a major improvement, and there are still the same bugs. I suggest you buy this game if you haven't bought the original (or you bought the base game but not the DLC). For others, I suggest you wait for a discount. I still like this game and the improvements (particularly the new mission type), but graphically I expected it to be better.

People who already own the game and who are upset with the new verison, understand State of Decay was released for xbox live and the PC, you couldn't go into the store to buy it. The cars and trucks have new skins as wellNew CharactersA bonus drop system called CLEO is in the game which is going to play into state of decay 2...You learn nothing about it.If you really enjoy the game, get it for breakdown. Being able to make your own bullets now made guns a great weapon now and you feel like this bad a$$ pulling combos than going to slow-mo and killing zombies wtih your rifle...Rifles are the only guy really worth having in the game.The game is a bit easier because of this, but also more fun. If you don't own the game buy it! If you want to go back to state of decay it's worth picking up, I bought it at full price because I'm crazy about the game, but I can see waiting for a big sale on it if you already own it.I do wish they added a different type of Zombie, or opened up a few buildings, like the movie theater you can't get in, as well as just added some extra buildings.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Disclaimer: I'm reviewing this game as its own thing. IMO if you already own State of Decay and its associated DLC this is nothing more than a 1080p graphical update and is not worth the upgrade. PC Specs (just in case):AMD FX6300NVidia GTX7608GB of RAM Played on a Microsoft Xbox 360 controllerWhat can I say about State of Decay other than it is the best zombie survival game in the market. It does a number of things really well:1) Make every character feel uniqueWhile you will always start with the 3 same characters, the community members you can acquire and how you build your characters can differ tremendously playthrough to playthrough. My first go at this game (in the 720p version) is completely different than my just finished 15 hours of playthough (on the Vanilla campaign). This game rewards smart play, some characters are more suited to melee and some for gunplay and building your characters around these strengths can help greatly or you can take the added risk of building evenly on every character. By the end of the campaign, I had three characters suited for gunplay, three for melee and two all-rounders and tasked each group to specific mission types. Everyone had a backstory and I tried to incorporate this into my decision making as I roleplayed them for what I thought each character would do in real-life. Each character also suffers permadeath and nothing is more heart-breaking than watching a character you build get destroyed by a silly move in a routine scavenging mission although after one or two deaths, you'll usually know when to pick your fights.2) Simulate a zombie apocalypse. Resources are scarce and while there are ways to end up not having to worry about resource A or B more often than not you'll run short on Resource C or D (there are five in total Food, Medicine, Ammo, Materials and Fuel). These resources are also consumed as the game is turned off meaning that you'll have to log in to check on the health of your community and to scavenge what you need. Which segues well into my next point. This game requires resource management. While you may be overflowing with food, not having enough medicine to stave off the flu or materials to maintain your defenses can and will spell certain doom. Adding to that is the fact that you can and will run out of resources, so it is a battle against time to stockpile resources and find a way out. Additionally, you will need to balance your time out as well. You will need to decide whether you want to clear the path around you or pursue story or community missions or scavenge for resources. You can roleplay as the hero of the community or the leader of your own isolated community depending on what you choose.3) Combat is kinda awesomeThere is nothing more awesome IMO that kneeing a zombie's skull open, or taking an oar and beating the crap out of multiple zombies. Melee combat in this game is great! You have your attack, dodge or (as I call it) space making moves that allow you to dictate melee fights with zombies. However, get overrun and surrounded and you will die. On the controller the Left Bumper (forgot the keyboard equivalent) allows you to add more power to your attacks, dodge further and finish grounded enemies all with the added cost of more stamina meaning that you can't just spam the attack button all the time. Gunplay is tight as guns react as you'd expect forcing you to choose the range of engagements depending on the weapon you choose. Pistol's can't one tap enemies from as far as a rifle can, but rifles don't have the rate of fire as pistols do. Assault weapons are a happy medium but ammo for them is scarce and automatic firing will burn through ammo. There are plenty more weapons and I enjoyed using all of them, none of them felt particularly overpowered (though any weapon that can take a silencer should be top priority picks) and filled each niche appropriately. 4) StoryThe story was in my opinion strongly average, there are some bits where you have to fill it in with your imagination but the game's narrative is relatively realistic with well-written dialogue. Needlessly to say, this is the most subjective part and I'll leave you to make this decision on your own. In short, this is in my opinion the best zombie game out there and you should buy it if you are new to the series. Hordes of zombies can be either terrifying or exhilarating to fight against depending on how prepared you are to face them. In between all the fighting there's managing your community, resources and characters. Sprinkled on top of all this is a great melee combat system and great gunplay. The story is what you make of it honestly, I found it adequate to keep my playing and motivated to finish the game but it isn't going to win awards. Some technical stuff below.Technical stuffGraphics: Decent looking. I had everything on the Max preset (there's the Ultra preset after Max) and the game looked beautiful at times. What really detracted from the experience was the game slowdowns as you moved from area to area. It almost felt like the game kept reloading assets of the upcoming parts of the map leading to some noticeable stutter. Sound: I liked how everything in this game sounded. Zombies whether aggressive or not sounded suitably dead and menacing. The guns sounded great, melee weapon effects were also pretty good. The ambiance came together very well for me.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												The State of Decay: YOSE is an up-rezzed version of State of Decay. What you get in YOSE over the original is as follows:Base game and all DLC in one package.Edged Weapons now have a different basic attack animation to differentiate them from Blunt Weapons.CLEO Supply Drops that act as short events. They give you some weapons and supplies if you can collect them.The "Unarmed" kick has been replaced with a Knife. Fighting with a knife is more viable, but its still not as strong as actual weapons.A few new characters in the Breakdown "Survival" Mode.Up-rezzed textures and graphicsIts still the same great but slightly flawed game, with some minor tweaks and additions. The discounted price of reentry was worth it for me since I just so happened to feel like replaying the game anyway and I liked the new additions.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Summarized: Haven't played State of Decay before and have a love for zombie games? Buy it. Definitely worth it. Have played it before, have money to spend and like minor changes and tons of minor extra stuff? Buy it. Cause they've added a lot of new things. Have played it before while liking major overhauls or major changes? Then don't buy it. Nothing major has changed.[/b][/list]Review:I bought the original title without any of the dlc's 2 years ago and first played about 2 months ago. Then I saw that a newer, more well done version of the game was coming out.  After seeing the discount and thinking about how addicted I was to State of Decay I decided to buy it.If you're new to State of Decay or you've played the original State of Decay without the DLC's and/or you love zombie games like I do, you'll definitely like this game and it's going to be worth it if you have the money for it. It may take a little bit of getting used to but it's such an elaborate and amazing game. If you've played the original without the dlc's, it wouldn't be a bad deal to buy it since it includes the DLC's.If you're not new to the game.. It may feel like not much has changed at all OR it may feel like a lot has changed. I thinkthe texture overhaul, extra weapons, extra survivors, extra mission, extra combat mechanics, better UI and extra cars are awesome and enjoyable. Most of the game has indeed not changed, but those extra things really make it feel like it did to me.If you want to see a State of Decay that has undergone major changes, you shouldn't buy it. Cause it hasn't.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												It's hard weather to recommend this game or not for me. To begin, THIS IS MY FAVORITE GAME EVER. No doubt about that. I love every inch of it. It's got everything I love in video games: freeroam, zombies, guns, scavenging, base-building, leveling up, permadeath, stealth, and that's just to name a few of my favorite aspects of it.Now to my suggestion... Should you buy it or not?Well let me answer that with another question, do you have the original game or not?If you do not have this game already, get it. Get it now and don't think about any other game. This game is absolutely amazing, and in this pack, you get all of the DLC's. It's fantastic! :) You can spend many many hours playing this game without boredom (at least for me). I can do the same stuff over and over, and it's a crazy fun experience each and every time. So great.If you already have the old game, I would waste your time on this "upgrade" if you even want to call it that. I paid $20 (33% off for having the original) for very slightly better graphics, one or two new finishing moves, and a new character. That was not something that I was pleased about. I had the old one too, but I personally loved the first game so much, that this version is more of a collectors item for me. But from a player's point of view, if you're not 100% crazy about this game, I wouldn't waste your money.More of my thoughts on THIS VERSION OF THE GAME and a gameplay video are below.--------------------------------The graphics in this game don't seem to have improved that much. They seem like the same ol' graphics from the original, just a bit brighter and now you can see guts in detail. It's not that big of a difference.The combat had a few new added techniques. You can now slice down on zombie heads and there are some new finishing moves based on the melee weapon you're using. Which is pretty cool. You can also chop off body parts it seems. Also pretty neat.I heard there were new weapons, which I never really got to find during this 45 minute session, but I'm sure they're there somewhere. The new weapon you get from the van is cool enough, though it shoots like a normal gun.Honestly, the coolest thing for me was the new character, Gurubani Kaur. She was pretty bad♥♥♥♥♥ wielding her suppressed rifle and sword. Very cool!Would I suggest this game? Well, it depends. If you do not have State Of Decay already, GET IT. It's awesome! This version in particular will even save you money if you plan on getting the DLC's with it. However, if you have State Of Decay already, it's more of an opinion type thing. If you REALLY care about graphics and stuff, go for it. Because that's really the only major change (although the UI looks pretty neat too). If you truly love State Of Decay like I do, get it. It's like a collectors thing at this point, though.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												I haven't played the original game, but I can understand why people who bought it, and then bought this version would feel cheated. I just found out about State of Decay, and so far the game is quite good. TL;DR The game doesn't really match the complexity of other open world survival games, and the PC-port is subpar.The game is focuses more on being a sandbox. The story is very light, and dialogues brief. The voice-acting is good most of the time. Graphics are ok, but animations are quite cartoony, and there's never any really scary environments or events.The world seems kind of small, most locations are just a stone's throw from the base, and distant locations take less than a minute to drive to. Scavenging is mostly about finding special lockers (about 2 or 3 per house) and looting them. There's no way to gather natural resources, or construct makeshift weapons on your own (ie. no crafting). Focus here lies instead on maintaining base happiness, upgrading facilities and managing resources. This is not entirely obvious how it works though - the interface is clunky, uninformative and its far too easy to misclick and start deconstructing rather than upgrading, thus wasting precious resources. The interface and controls are painfully poorly ported. They do the job, but it's obvious that it was designed for a console controller, and very little effort was put into adapting it to a mouse and keyboard (even Skyrim did it better).When it comes to zombie survival games, my main go-to game is Project Zomboid. In comparison, this game is easier, more cartoony; but also more immersive with the 3D environments, has some good NPC dialogue and adequate AI. For these reasons I think this game is entertaining enough to recommend, although some better controls would make it easier to recommend.

If you liked the original and still fancy playing it, there's enough mixed around in the bag to warrant another round of play-throughs with this purchase.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												Whilst a very obvious console port, if you can forgive the game for it's poorer aspects (melee combat doesn't feel completely fluid, zombies don't render well at distances, blurred textures, low dynamic shadow distance), you will have a blast. Big map, driveable vehicles, lots of items, customization, base/community building. Definitely worth the price in my opinion. Far from an 'AAA' title, but it has it's own charm.Pros:*Graphics are better than original release (albeit not significantly)**Seems better optimized than the original release (from what I've tested I'm getting pretty-much a solid 60fps on Ultra)***Very easy to mod (hordes of zombies, zombies do more damage, remove lit-up containers, remove zombie radar icons)****Mods for the original game work on YOSE too*****Map is a decent size******Breakdown especially is very fun, lots of different characters, difficulty increases*******An abundance of different items, weapons, levelling********Different zombie types, adds to the excitement/fear without being too far-fetchedCons:*No anti-aliasing**Assisted-aim with a controller can't be turned off***Lootable containers (wardrobes etc) glow white, which kills immersion. Google: No More X-Ray Eyes to disable****A hunger system would've been cool, but stamina forces you to eat which is an okay compromise*****Can be buggy, can't climb on certain objects, etc******I sometimes encounter a bug where if I die, and start a new character, a sound repeatedly replays which is incredibly irritating. Restart game to fix.7/10. Not the best game I've ever played, but worth it for a cheap price. I'd happily pay £20-$30 for it. Can definitely get a decent number of hours out of it. Just don't expect perfection.

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												There was a bit of debate and some doubt in my mind whether or not to get State of Decay: YOSE after reading a bunch of the reviews and seeing all the thumbs down. I have the older State of Decay and all the DLC for it already and I did enjoy that one greatly.I also had a few mods installed and I feel Yose adds what I already added in mods for the first State of Decay, which is a good thing. Now I don't have to add mods to get the experience I wanted with the first State of Decay. I like what they did with their zombie game, third person, having perma death, having to run a community of survivors the whole lot. I have gladly wasted many many hours. I certainly recommend the first one. If you are on the border about getting or not getting this. just go to youtube and watch a few videos and or reviews, find out with your own opinion about this game by seeing actual gameplay.After playing this one for a bit I have no problem recommending this one as well. Sure i've seen a few weird zombie glitches, maybe a zombie gets stuck or you hit C to dodge and he grabs you anyways or you swing and somehow he manages to hit you brushing off your hit as wind in his hair, not really game breaking in my opinion, makes your odds less and in my opinion more fun as I welcome the challenge of staying alive. I also noticed the zombies like to spawn pretty fast even though I dispatch a ton and feel the area should be clear they keep on coming in waves appearing from thin air right in front of me. But I don't mind Killing zombies, it's fun and gets your stats up.Most people say the game has frame drops, that it isn't optimized, the previous game ran smoother and it doesn't look better than the previous State of Decay, or it's not worth $20 for the "exact" same game. I have not had any of these problems. I don't know what hardware people are using. I am on a modern mid level gaming computer ($600), I have my game settings maxed out. It does run smoother, it looks better, I have no problem with any lighting or shading, everything renders fine, and there is no black border in full screen as I read in one or two reviews, I also saw that people don't like the load screens or the load screens take too long. I have not encountered a load screen that was longer than a few seconds 20 or 30 seconds if even that, at the most, besides those everything is pretty instant in my experience. All I can say about this is make sure your computer meets the requirements.Onto the $20 is too much. I like what the devs made as a game and I am willing to support them so they will continue to make more for this game, or more games in general, sure you could argue this should be DLC, there's not enough content to resell it at this price etc. I haven't gone through everything in the game and encountered every single bit just yet, but so far I have used the SUV, I have an SKS w/ 40mm grenade launcher, i've used the new melee weapons and the new character which has new animations. I like what I have seen and used so far and I have confidence I will like the rest of the game just as much if not more as I reintroduce myself to State of Decay.Conclusion: If you don't already have State of Decay and you like zombie games along with slight base and resource management, pick this up. If you want to upgrade and relive your older State of Decay adventures, pick this up.Review Update: 5/21/2015I would like to address the people who are "stuck" in windowed mode and have incorrect mouse coordination in game, simply hit alt+enter to go full screen and fix the mouse. Simple fix.Another thing almost everyone is complaining about the fact they are buying the "same game" and it's not updated enough to be worth buying again. Why is everyone so surprised when they buy it? Guess what? it IS the same game, it is remastered, aka they added slight improved graphics, textures, more weapons, characters etc. but it is still State of Decay. This is not a new game, it is not State of Decay 2. Just like when they patch an mmo. Same game with a little more than before the patch.I have not had any game breaking problems with bugs, glitches, or crashes as of yet. I played through the first two levels of breakdown and have not lost any survivors, heroes, vehicles, whatever to any bug or glitch. I have completed all my sieges and have not had any special zombies come through closed doors. No followers get stuck due to bad path finding, or die from bad path finding. I have used the incendiary shotguns and the knife fighting which are both really fun in my opinion. I have also encountered most if not all of the vehicle paint jobs and vehicle variants which I find sort of funny and nice to see at the same time. I like the new variety, but I feel some of the paint jobs are a little much, but still fun.I am still enjoying the game as I wrote in my first part of the review. and I still recommend the game if you have not owned the original or if you enjoyed the first and are buying it for a second time.

												Great game! The only complaint I have is having to listen to the repeated nagging from the girl that sits on her fanny talking on the radio.  It's virtually impossible to become friends with her and even though all you have to do is take a look at the map, she's right there nagging you about things that should be done. 												I'm going to preface this by saying that I did not own the game when it first came out. This is my first introduction to it and for the price it is phenomenal. content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												State of Decay (including its DLC) is a great game and YOSE brings new additions to game but on release it has a few annoying bugs.If you never owned State of Decay or don't have the DLCs before this is a good purchase Yose edition gives you both the DLC with the original game.If you already owned State of Decay with all DLC I recommend waiting for it to go on sale, you wont be waiting long State of Decay has been on sale on steam over a dozen times at one point the biggest discount was 80% off. Some of the new features added to the game by YOSE include A new mission that appears in all 3 game modes where mystery supply drops appear drawing hoards of enemies, that even the most experienced players will have a challenge beating. A handful of unique skinned cars which perform slightly differently to their original including slightly faster but take more damage.  New fully voiced characters to unlock in the breakdown mode. One new vehicle type the SUV. Returning players who decide to purchase Yose will find More enemies to deal with than before being loud and reckless is much more risky. Special infected such as the Feral appearing far more frequently and in greater numbers (especially in breakdown) Ferals are now far more evasive when trying to run them down in a car Facilities in the original campaign and breakdown now have the features of making snacks and ammo. New sounds and weapons and voiced dialogue. The journal/menu is noticeably better looking with sharper images on items. New combat animations with edged weapons and unarmed combat being particularly brutal.As i said at the top of my post the game does have its bugs and some can be quite annoying a few close to game breaking. Bugs worth mentioning I had to manually set my resolution and screen aspect using the in game menu. Sometimes when alt tabbing the game goes into a windowed mode. Zombies occasionally clip through doors Friendly AI can be slow or unresponsive, especially when they really need to be. small frame drops when the game loads up the city areas as you drive into them.My Computer is running Windows 7 64bitIntel(R) Core(TM) i7-4770K CPU @ 3.50GHz (8 CPUs), ~3.5GHzNVIDIA GeForce GTX 77016GB RAMThe game runs at 60 FPS on the in game ultra settings for me almost consistently except for the brief second it takes when loading up the city areas while driving a fast car, but after its loaded its back to a solid 60 fps.I recommend this game if you haven't played State of Decay before, otherwise wishlist it and wait for a sale.

Posted: June 9, 2015
												I bought this game with a grain of salt as there were literally "mixed" reviews on the page but I am surprisingly impressed. The original State of Decay (which I own and have played thoroughly) did have some performance issues even on good rigs, especially if the ultra setting was on but the Year One edition runs at a smooth 60FPS for me apart from some hitching when loading textures but this doesn't effect my experience.This is a good purchase especially if you haven't ever played the game but even if you own the original (more so if you haven't played any of the DLC's like me) I would still recommend this. Some of the reviews aren't correct from what I have experienced, this versions performance is much, much better than the previous one and it does look a little better but personally, I would purchase this edition purely for the performance boost.Overall, this is a brilliant game and also a brilliant edition to release, the only problem that I would raise is that the discount for previous owners could have been a little more, maybe 50% but oh well, it's still worth the money.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												State of Decay: Year One Survival Edition is an "HD" re-release of 2013's State of Decay, an open-world survival game very clearly inspired by the success of the Day Z mod for ARMA II. This version includes the two DLC game modes released for the original State of Decay and features improved graphics, making this the definitive version of the game.As of this writing there are many negative reviews for this new version focusing on the fact that there isn't any new content for players who already own the original State of Decay and its DLC. So first let me be clear: If you already own State of Decay and the DLC, there is nothing new for you here. However, for "zombie survival" fans who missed out on one of the best very games in the genre, YOSE is the definitive version and well worth the price. One need only look at the very positive reviews for the original State of Decay to see a more honest and accurate representation of this game's merit.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Notice:Now understand before reading this two key facts: first and formost that I've only played 6 hours at the time of writing this. I will likely edit this review down the track if my opinion changes due to future gameplay. Secondly, that I have only invested $25 into State of Decay (paid $5 for the old one).IntroductionNow onto the review itself, state of decay is a zombie survival game. You play a community trying to survive in what ever ♥♥♥♥♥♥ walled building you can lay your hands on. The game itself is split into three gamemodes if you will: the main story, breakdown (loot the map and move onto a harder version of the map) and lifeline (I have played much of the last). GraphicsSimply put the visuals feel clearer and more polished then the original game. There are a few dodgy textures here and there that feel like temp/hold overs but with some luck undead labs or modders can fix them. Also now supports 1080p which is nice.GameplayGameplay is much the same, you'll get the same dialog as before and you'll likely ignore it now like you did the last 100 times. A few new guns have been added (least I've been told) and there seems to be a pre-order character you can play now.OverallI'm not going to go nito the debat about if this one's better then the original or not. State of Decay: YOSE is a HD remake of one of the best zombie survivals (most likely the best one) that brings this two year old classic back from the dead (no pun intended =P).What remains to be seen is what Undead labs will do with this new version of their game? Will they add more content (hopefully co-op, not holding my breath there though)? or just leave this game to rot in gaming hell (ok, that one was intended :D)?

Posted: April 30, 2015
												For the current prize if you want something a bit more casual to play for a time i recommend this game. But with a fair warning that you also need some casual patience with it's performance. It's a fair price i can't complain about that.here's why:Still got a bunch of bugs in it. Optimization leaves a bit to wish for. I have crashed twice, some serious pop in and stuttering issues when entering a new area or moving to fast in a car. It's not that good of a port. Controls and UI not to mention camera can at times be frustrating but you quickly get used to it.  On average it's an okay zombie survival RPG it's not great by any means but it's heading in the right direction. And it's sort of meant to be played a little bit each day instead of sinking hours upon hours into it. This helps with keeping the patience to.Luckily if you want to spend some time on it there seems to be optimization mods around doing what the developers could not. And there is even some nice candy options to give it that nice PC master race standard looks.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Read the pre release info. Decided to go ahead and get the game. Not a 100% bust, but it really needs fixes, as did the previous version. Glitches, unexpected vehicle, item, and general game issues cause me to lose more people from my community than anything else. Also, even after clearing buildings, icons still show as though something is there when the building is clear. Bonus Survivors no longer populate and the "Saving" feature will no longer turn off, causing lag every few seconds, making the game nearly unplayable. I waited until now to watch the forums and see what dev's do about any issues. To be honest, I have not seen much change. You got my money (twice). How about fixing the game issues and addressing the reasonable player questions?Overall, I do love the game for what it is intended - an open world Single Player Zombie Apocalypse World. A couple of things to make the game better - 1. Multi-Player (at least LAN-Based) Of course if you add Lan, Online play is right there as well.2. Expansions outside of the Valley. Let's face it, Breakdown is by far the best of the three choices. Keep expanding the Valley. If I can play for hours, killing zombies, collecting supplies, and rescuing others, I think I can skirt around a few vehicles blocking the road to leave the Valley. Maybe add a Tow Truck so I can clear it? Just a thought.3. Dont hype up what you know has issues. Fix the issues, Beta Test them with players like me, then release when it is ready.4. Workout, Take your Vitamins, and Eat Right.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												So, as an owner of the original game, I was pretty excited to see the XOSE Day One Edition released. Then I saw all the negative reviews, and really didn't know what to think. All the improvements tehy made (https://forums.undeadlabs.com/threads/everything-we-know-about-state-of-decay-year-one-survival-edition.47074/) looked pretty cool, but the reviews were all pretty bad. I decided to buy it nonetheless, especially since I didn't own Lifeline, so I thought "why not?"So here is what I think:All in all, if you're new to State of Decay, go buy the YOSE, it's great. On the otherhand, if you own the original and both DLC's, I'm not so sure. All I can say is, I didn't regret buying it, but I only owned one DLC before.Technical problems are still there, but all the small changes and improvement make it worthwhile for me. Game looks better to me, I get a lot less graphical glitches, I like the new unarmed knife mechanics, I noticed some ncie new animations, Gurubani Kaur is awesome, and the overall gameplay feels the same, if not better to me. Also: blood and gore looks better now. That's really cool. I don't know if its worth 20 € for you, but I most certainly don't regret buying YOSE.I hope this helps if your unsure.Best regards and have fun smashing zombieheads :)

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												State of Decay is a great mix of 3rd person zombie action and survival role playing.   Play is fairly open as to how you go about doing things (slow, stealthy, fighting everything in sight, etc).   To me, it feels more like being in a real situation as compared to some of the "action only" zombie games out.  Graphics are good, I much prefer the lighting in the YOSE version compared to the original, much better for my old eyes...  There is some clipping at times, nothing worse than I've seen in other games and nothing that bothered me.  I've not had any crashes (except vehicles..hehe). I highly recommend State of Decay.   If you don't have any version yet, go with YOSE version.   If you have the original but not the DLC from the original, this is still a good deal  (if you haven't played it to death).  If you have the original and the DLC you won't get as much out of this version so it's kind of iffy.    For me, the graphics make it worth getting, but others may just mod the original and they could certainly pass on this version.Overall a SOD is a nice addition to the genre and I hope to see more from UL.

number of helpful: 5 of 19 people (26%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												In light of the bad reviews I've seen for this game, let me give a positive one. Disclaimer: I've only had a chance to play breakdown thus far, so I have no comments on the main game quest or on lifeline, but I expect like everything else they will be like the original.Summary:  If you enjoyed the original game, this version gives improved graphics and perhaps a tiny bit more gameplay stuff.  If you expected anything different than that, I don't know what to tell you.The game plays like the original game, because *gasp* it is the original game.  All that was promised was improved graphics and a few little tidbits to make the game more fun.  It's basically a textures overhaul mod you'd expect to see for Skyrim, except its official.I've heard complaints about the bugs, and all I can say is that they were neither better nor worse than the original game.  I'm guessing they were bugs that are driven by intricacies of the Cryengine version used be SOD, but that's just conjecture (it's all physics related and a few random crashes that honestly shouldn't happen, but I couldn't care less.)As for the improved graphics, I noticed a huge improvement.  Everything was far less dingy, and undead labs seriously toned up the lighting.  While I can sort of get the realism of not being able to see at night, I'm glad they fixed it because for me the game was virtually unplayable during 'night'; if you want to be unable to see for 50% of the game I would then of course recommend the original.They probably added new character traits, and definitely added new shirts and pants and hats.  This mixes up what sort of characters you will see and increases playability.  Similarly the vehicles were diversified and given new textures, which again makes for more replayability since there are more than 6 distinct cars in the valley.I did in fact notice the higher res textures.  The original was grainy as heck.  The menu and maps have been cleaned up significantly, which is really good.  I'm so glad they kept the physical journal interface (the game menus look like pages in a notebook) ====== very cool UI.  Plus you can now tell which item you have selected!In closing, the Year One edition is worth it if you liked the original game (or if you never played it, I suppose).  If you go in expecting a vastly different setting and feeling and a bug free game, then you'll be disappointed.  Good luck, it's a brutal game.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												I purchased the original State of Decay, and I have many hours on it.I pre-purchased this game, and was amazed to see that I had 33% of the price deducted from owning the previous game! I also received an awesome in-game character, special to only previous supporters of State of Decay!I have to start of with the STUNNING graphics. Somehow, these amazing graphics run on my computer (more like a toaster, but ya know what I mean) with very little lag.The gameplay is FAR, and I mean REALLY FAR, smoother. There is no glitches that I've found (yet), which is awesome. The game actually looks epic, and the gameplay is too. While my game was downloading, I was reading the reviews, and was not feeling to good. I started to regret buying it, but now that I've played it I know how full of dog turd some people are. Whether it's your first time joining the State of Decay or you're rejoining it from the previous game, this is WELL worth the 29.99 USD (or the 19.99 USD for returning players).I'm looking to enjoy hundreds of hours on this within a couple of months.If you are looking at this game and want it, DO NOT hesitate. It's amazing. You WILL NOT regret. There is one thing about that though, this game is not for people who only have 5 minutes of game play time a day and who want to be an OP 'boss' in 2 minutes. You can't buy premium stuff, only the DLC for 2 extra game modes (Well worth the money).This game WILL get boring over time. It did for me (with the original game, but it will with this one too), but I KEEP coming back for more. So the difference between this and your mom is...well...this one costs a few extra bucks! (It's just a joke, please take no offense).I will probably be updating this comment at least once to let you know over time if this game has changed (for better OR worse), enjoy!

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												I read these recommendations and lament; that in a world where hours are measured in dollars, I've owed thousands to this series compared with what I bought.For two years I've played from Vanilla, to Breakdown, to Lifeline - sweeping the hordes on rusted-steel saddle, with a lasso burst from gunpowder, and a mania forged from clout. I've burned, I've savaged, I've salved, I've saved, I've cried, I've praised. It is the community by which we're raised. It is the loftiness of support, it is the understanding shoulder, the irrevokable lamplight in an otherwise sullied seam...You can play your other zombie games, with an endless struggle of manacled, aging reflex against a toe-tapping slumber party of shamble crumblies with a penchant for frame-skipping in your general, meandering, stumbling, blathering direction, or you can drop that market wholesale and quaff the star motes of an untapped dream.---You take that entire genre, you break it down, and make it drown, then throw it a lifeline. Strip away all the non-essentials and see it for what it is. You take away its pretty vestments, its mini skirts and tube tops and stone-washed jeans. You strip away what society has made it, you strip away the old, superfluous tools of survival in whatever culture's theme, from the drip of alchohol to the baker's creme.Crushing down all the trappings, enigmatically removing much, towards making whole.Peeling off its Grecian idealism, its mustered motion of messosoprano Machina (Deus Ex), of lights at ends of tunnels, of softly spoken "It'll be alright."You take the pseudonym you once knew, you make it real, you care for it kindly, you watch it grow. You slave and love and praise its wishes, you listen to its dreams, you fight you die you live you tell you lie - from the 13th canto do these mountains rise.Until in nonchalance it's bitten, dragged home, bleeding in your bed. You swallow your tongue crying, empathetic solution's liquefaction - seeping heartward, salting now-ephemeral human wounds.You stop.Strike out!Sweep the cliffs, sweep the shallows for some poultice, for some penitent panacea - an herb, a vial, a bottle, a philosophy - anything...everything...something.Each footstep first thundered, in passion, now's a noose, each footstep strung in heart sinew, stumble's pounds to bear, whimpers come in volley, tears trailing from trebuchets, splashing hard around the ears. Til each wail's a windlass - descending downwards with a knell...cranial crevasses calmly creeping, knowing naught is all's been found.This is your world, is your misery, is your mercy shot against your once-loved friend. This is horror...is honor...is triumph...is survival...is your mind's eye into this world.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												I understand why there are so many bad reviews for this game. But many of those "bad reviews" recommend purchasing this game if you have not played the original. I agree with them to purchase this addition. Pro:1. they have updated the User Interface. Not to say the original was bad, but it was too gritty, along with much of the graphics.2. They are still updating this game. That means It is just going to get better.3. They added new content, that doesn't include the pre-orders, the bonus of purchasing the game early or the bonus of having the original game.  They added new gear. and added some characters from the last DLC to the second DLC. Cons: 1. they do have some glitches and bugs. I encountered much of them, but what makes it better is all the fun they are, much like skyrim. They are not game breaking glitches, they are just something that make you laugh. Like for example I had someone floating while sitting down. or had a zombie fly against the ground against it's back. 2. I do admit that the graphics may not be as advertised, but it is still much better than the first game. the opening background is much cleaner and more interesting then the first.  3. there was one glitch that I did encounter that was rather upsetting, but upon further review I realized I may have caused the glitch and it can be avoided. I began a mission and then immediately I started another action (searching a cupboard) that made it impossible to finish the mission. I just simply restarted and it came right back before I started the mission once again.Overall, if this game seems appealing, or at least the first one did and you are thinking about buying this game. I would recommend it. I already put around 25-40 hours into this game in a week and I am still enjoying it. I just cannot get enough from this game.

												For anyone who hasn't played this game yet then this edition is well worth picking up. State Of Decay is one of my favourite games and this new version adds new weapons, characters, missions etc as well as adding beter textures and lighting to the game (also fixing the dreaded crushed blacks some users had). content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												State of Decay Year One Survival Edition is the most enjoyable single player end of the world Zombie game available. Period. Part simulation and all action the game looks good and the Gore is very abundant. The controls are quick and responsive and the fear of character permadeath keeps you on your toes. There is a bit of clipping and a few isolated graphical bugs that some people cry and complain about but these do not stop or distract from the immersion or enjoyment of the game in any way. I owned it first on my Xbox360 and then purchased it for my computer. Don't listen to the fussy detractors. They are nit-picking and looking for things to criticize in this good quality budget game. If you think you'll enjoy a captivating open world head popping Zombie smashing simulation then State of Decay might be your game.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												There's been some remarkable customer backlash over this being 'the same thing as before'. Well. State of Decay is a great game. This, right here, is a new edition of a great game. There aren't too many changes - this is, after all, a very slight upgrade which is primarily to make State of Decay available to X-Box One owners. On PC, the changes aren't too obvious, but there's a different engine running things in the background. There's a new knife-wielding mechanic for characters without weapons. There are new bits and bobs in various game modes, but again, they're marginal - new heroes, some bits of hardware from DLC being offered across all game mods, that kind of thing.The 'consumer revolt' is entirely out of proportion with what this is, and with what this is advertised as. It's State of Decay running on an updated engine - same game, significantly different back-end... but it's the same game.And it's a really, really good game. I bought it as an excuse to replay it, and I'm enjoying it. I think the developers did a pretty good job.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												While I do agree that this is how the PC release should have been to begin with, I'm not going give a negative review based on that fact as it would be petty.   Because the truth is, if you've never played this game or you own the original, I'd recommend it nonetheless.  Its the only real single-player driven zombie survival experience you're really going to find that delivers on the survival front AND gives you some interaction with the world itself in the form of other NPC survivors.While I've played 7 Days to Die (and I do recommend that game) and Project Zomboid (another great game but it still has a long way to go) and a few others, I found myself playing this one out of the batch the most.  Mostly because the worlds in those games are...well, empty currently, though I intend to revisit them when NPCs survivors are added.While the world itself is solid and interactions with it are limited (you can board up houses, establish outposts, rescue other survivors but you can't say, build an entirely new building from the ground up) it delivered what I had hoped and that was a zombie experience with some drive beyond, "I'm going to go on and on and on..." because while survival is fun, it is not inherently interesting if that is all you're doing (in a virtual space, mind you). Plus, the game gets downright difficult as time progresses; there are some serious heavy weight zombies that you don't even want to run into while you're driving a vehicle.  Your insurance won't cover it, trust me.TL;DRDay Z (can't blame you, its a long♥♥♥♥♥deathmatch not a zombie survival game) not your thing but you want a zombie focused survival game? Pick it up.  Already own it? Pick it up on sale because the fix to the draw distance, graphical tuning are good but not worth the full price if you already own the original and all the expansion packs.  I agree with the notion that this is how it should have been to begin with but I disagree that the developers should be "punished" for that, especially since they were primarily focused on a console released way back when.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I've seen a lot of blasting in the negative spectrum for this game. I really just couldn't disagree more. I played a LOT of the original version of this, and there is clearly a great improvement on the graphics qualities. Texturing of wood is noticeably better, and details and shadowing of characters and zombies are improved as well. The trees look fantastic (not that they were bad before.)      It's easy to hate on a game, but you won't see me doing it with this one. There are new animations, new sound effects, vehicles... the menus have been revamped (i.e. inventory)        I love it. I've experienced no glitches yet either. And if they arise, Undead Labs has always been good about fixing problems. Love it. Thanks guys!

number of helpful: 6 of 23 people (26%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												This game is a very fun game and I like it quite a lot. It's a clever idea that still holds a lot of potential, the devs could still do very much with this game especially since they just 'remastered' it.I played the original and I deffinately notice a difference with graphics and frame rate, mainly because I have a computer that wasn't exactly built for gaming. I can run the remastered game on ultra and 1080p just fine without frame drops, in comparison to me running medium to high graphics with violent lag and occasional crashes at times in the original.However this does not constitute the developers charging (quite a bit) for a remake, several bugs are still present from the original but overall it's still very nice. It would have been nice if this remake was a free upgrade to whoever bought the original and It would also be nice if the devs were to add more content in the form of updates (In all seriousness, this is a huge oppurtunity to release some more content).Overall, I'd say proceed with caution. This is still a very fun and enjoyable game. The game runs a lot smoother for me in comparison to the original and I noticed a few little changes. I'd say that if you didn't buy the original, buy this version. If you have the original, stick with that because you might be disapointed.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I find all these negative reviews a bit unfair and misleading for the game and for new players as almost everyone base their negative review on faultered/not reached hopes and hypes. If we are to review ONLY the new parts of the game, then it's one thing. But if we are to review this as a whole game, for new and unaware players, then all this criticism are misplaced. Therefore these negative reviews is a shot to the head on a really great game.If you are new to this game and you like the Zombie/survival genre, then this is (in my opinion) one of (if not THE) the best game there is to date. You get to survive/live in a pretty realistic interpretation of a post-apocalyptic zombie-virus outbreak. Vehicles, basebuilding, team-management, permadeath and scavaging. Done in a really genial way. Even with some RPG elements!What needs to be fixed is the framrate/optimization issue. When travelling by car the game does not run very well, a problem I never had with the original. And a very personal opinion of mine, as I understand the hordes (maybe zombie overall) spawnrate has been increased. One of the (by me) strongest sides of SoD compared to other games in the same genre is that there is peaks of intensity. Your not overun 24/7, the world can seem silent and peaceful one minute and then hell breaks loose the next. I really hope it will stay that way.So. If your into the Zombie/survival genre, for the survival ideas, this is a ♥♥♥♥ing awesome game and worth every penny! Can't wait for the sequel!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												First impressions:When I got the game, I expected the game to play like GTA and Project Zomboid had a baby. Instead it felt more like Dead Rising and Saints Row had a baby. The graphics are similar, and the car controls are about just as clunky when it came to sticky acceleration and steering delayed by milliseconds.As far as I know, you can't loot the occasional weapon from a zombie (police/security zombie/randomly armed civilian). You have to search boxes within structures for loot instead. I don't own the original game because I got this one by mistake (I meant to get the first game), but it still plays great despite it's quirks. Not to mention killing the zombies feels great. I'm on the fence about recommending State of Decay: Year One to anybody else, but if others say the first game is better, I can't argue with it since I don't know.I'll see about editing this reveiw with an update later once I've completed the game.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												So first off, I'm not kibitzing about the YOSE - I have both the original and the remastered as it's kind of like the GoTY edition - those aren't given out to original purchasers either so I personally don't see the issue. I've played the hell out of this game and I love it even with its flaws.The game looks nice. Maybe not 2015 Assassin's Creed, Witcher 3, Dragon Age Inquisition, etc. nice but it's not terrible. The effects are overall better and I enjoy the new look a lot. Unfortunately the textures break a lot and flatten out to look very low-res. Cars handle better. Now that being said, they still handle really wonky at times. Car drives beautifully for a while and then you hit a small pebble or stick and car shoots into the air, slingshotting my character into a swan dive. Sometimes it does this for no reason at all. Textures on the cars break when my character is in them. Going from decent to low-res the second my character climbs in and sits down. There is no reason why a car sitting still should develop a case of the blurries. I do like the new vehicles UL added, they give the game a bit more variety and flavor.Some pathing has improved. Some hasn't. I still get stuck on curbs and sandboxes and anything that is ankle height. I think my characters must all have weak ankles and thus have developed a fear of short objects. Game difficulty seems cranked to 11. I started over instead of importing my save and opened up Breakdown lvl 1 (I prefer Breakdown to story TBH) and I was getting swarmed constantly. I lost one guy to a feral which is totally something that happens but a lot of survivors are getting mauled by packs of two and three zombies who glitch through doors and seem to hit like they migrated from a much higher difficulty. And OMG HORDES. Upon starting my game and moving into the Alamo, 6 hordes spawned. And each time there is a horde announcement, there are between 7 and 8 hordes. Half of these will almost instantly infest a house. It's kind of daffy. Overall however, I feel this game is still wonderful. I do wish there were more features added - more home base sites, perhaps city access like when you choose to move on in Breakdown you could wind up in a Breakdown version of the city instead of the valley - more base-building freedom (Seriously. I'm looking at all this negative space in my bases wondering WTH I can't plop a garden planter here or more beds there..) and maybe a toggle on mission frequency. (STHU LILY. I'M BUSY!) But it's still a terrific game overall and I love it just as much as I did when I first played it.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												From someone who has played the original SoD on 360, PC and the DLC. A majority of the negative comments are going to be from people holding grudges against Undead Labs for a "paid upgrade". Something people do not realize is nobody is holding a gun to your head, dont want to pay for this edition, then don't buy it, its that simple. With that said, in terms of graphical improvements, from the original PC edition it is crisper and smoother lines all around, not enough to be called a full HD remaster (IMO) but decent enough from where it came from. The gameplay is still a bit rough around the edges and zombies still bug out (gametime only 20 minutes and I saw 1 stuck in ground and another in a tree). The sound from what I heard is cleaner and the control input is smooth with no input lag (I use 360 controller).Overall I would recommend this game to someone who has never played SoD before. The people who have bought the original can probably bypass this version as your not getting much of an upgrade.

												I've had this game for so long and I never gave a review.  Here we go.Let's just say the first impression of SoD is addictive.  I remember getting this game on the xbox for like $10.  I played it and had to leave the next few days to Canada on a business trip.  I kid you not, I couldn't wait to come home and play.  Then the game was released for PC.  WHOAAAAA!!!  I just had to get it.  Need I remind you, I never finished the game on the xbox.  Here I am running around building base and gathering resources.  Man the game is so much fun.  I'm following the missions and storyline just having a blast.  BAM!  Game over!  I win!  WTF!!!!!  The shortest game you'll ever play in your life without warning.  I felt like I was ripped off.  I thought this was a survival game.  Turns out it's a small tiny map and the game ends right when you setup your second base.  Total rip off.  SoD 2 I will not be buying because I don't trust this company nor do I support them.  Purchase at your own will.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												YOSE is State of Decay's GOTY.  And it is a damn good one.PROs:+Butter-smooth framerate and animations+Crisp graphics.  Textures are far less muddier than the original.  The world is more vibrant+UI looks cleaner+New unarmed knife combat is pretty slick+The mods I had installed have worked right away (though icons need to be edited)+Literally picked up in my Breakdown game exactly where I left off in the originalCONs:-Zombies still pop in.  Not a con for me, but worth noting for others-Still can't use the Court House as a Home!  In fact, I don't think any new potential homes were added-Still can't put a rucsac in the bed of a truck without a modTL:DERRRRRR- A great game made better.  If you're not burnt out on SoD, there is no reason not to own this iteration of it.  It does not feel like a completely different game, but it does feel like the original greatly enhanced, which was what this iteration was aiming for.  For an XBLA title, this game is really freakin' sweet.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												A good game and a better PC port than the original State of Decay.  Still needs a better graphics menu as at the moment there's really no way to tweak things like AA etc.  Would be nice to have these options.Performance isn't bad consideing it uses the CryEngine, but it does stutter a little bit here and there. However I haven't yet played enough of this game to give it a full on review.A few problems- There was a mission where the army had two surviors on the floor but said survivors were invisible and it looked like the soliders were talking to themselves. - Graphics menu isn't that great. We can't adjust anything such as AA.- Frame rate can vary wildly.  Although on my system this isn't game breaking its something to consider.- Car handling is a bit weird.  They seem to turn a bit slow.A few good things- Gameplay seems a lot better compared to the last State of Decay.  Doesn't feel as clunky.- Graphics have seen a decent overhual.  Looks a lot better than the previous State of Decay.My recommendations to the developers- Give us more options to tweak. The slider doesn't really tell us anything. This may even help the performance of the game for a lot of people.

												You will love this remastered vesion of State of DecayThe game was always beautiful to look at, but now it's breathtaking, every detail has been graphically detailed from the buildings to the leaves on the trees.The combat is much easier more fluid too, with new enhanced combat , which is needed as the difficulty of the game has been raised in the original game and both DLC'sAs the developers said, "it is now the game, they wanted us to have back in 2013."I have over a 1000 hours of gameplay between Xbox 360 and PC , I love the game, but always played with caution, mainly because my ppl never seemed to move quick enough in battle,I been playing YOSE Breakdown levelling up Gurubani ,  Wow I just slaughtered about 150 zeds using hand to hand combat- at the Grange . You will love playing as her, she is a thank you gift from Undead Labs, for buying and supporting the franchise over the past 2 years I just love the game and what they did with it , not fond of the loading screens but I can forgive that , it is now the best zombie survival game on the market ever, nothing will ever best it . 10/10.

												Really loved the game; still do, but I'm disappointed the graphics aren't as good as I hoped. I would also have liked some AA settings, or any graphics configuration settings to tinker with. The only really noticable upgrade is the UI/Journal screen...gr8!Considering this remaster doesn't add much content and was marketed as a purely graphics upgrade (which is why I bought it) I am, actually, REALLY disappointed. I still recommend it though, but only if you haven't played it before.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Note: I'll be reviewing this in terms of changes compared to the original.I'll start off by saying that this IS the definitive edition of State of Decay. The game looks nicer (goodbye, harsh shadows), the animations are slicker, and the colors are more vibrant. They've added a new set of animations for "unarmed" (now knife) combat, which seems to include some takedown animations, which is a welcome additions. There are new vehicles, weapons, and a character. Overall, it also performs better.The only major problem I've identified so far is the fact that it lags horrifically when driving. Hopefully this will be patched, but until then, it's REALLY bad. There's also a really stupid motion blur effect when your vehicle is in motion. It blurs the car itself, and nothing else. Seriously?If you already own the game, get it. $20 for the game and its DLCs are completely worth it. If not, $30 is still the most cost-effictive way to play.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
State of Decay: YOSE - What's new in this version?!State of Decay: YOSE is the remake for State of Decay Undead Labs worked on.What a great game, YOSE Day One Edition adds so much to the game, even if you played State of Decay and all the DLCs like I did there's still so much stuff to do, I totally recommend getting it! Undead Labs added so much stuff, if it's in new challenges and Achievements or in features like new DVR, knives, vehicles, weapon add-ons, new music, unlockable characters and more! There's even a 33% discount for users who own State of Decay if you buy until June 30, 2015 - just purchase from the account that own the original game! There's new knife animation, YES the default melee is a combat knife! good for 1v1 but not for more than 2 zombies at once! (so it's not OP and there's still reason to carry a melee weapon!) And the graphics looks AMAZING!, the developers did great job with bringing State of Decay to the 1080p. plus there's an improved lighting, textures, and shadows which makes the game beautiful more than ever before. Also the UI looks so clean and good, really love it! :D To sum up, you're going to enjoy the game so much, there's a lot of new stuff to do and much to discover! :)Reviewed on http://scop3scout.webege.com/State_of_Decay_YOSE
